FOREWORD 


O N October 23rd 1945, a few days before I was due to go. into 
hospital I received from Captain J. L. Shaw of the Historical 
Section of the War Department, Delhi, the follotving invitation 
written from the India Office in Whitehall; 

‚ÄòThe Government of India wish to publisli the story of India‚Äôs 
efforts during the war in the form of a popular novel, but strictly 
accurate as to detail. For this purpose they wish to secure the 
services of an author of repute in the historical field, and would be 
grateful if you would consider the proposition. 

‚ÄòA book of 90-100,000 words is envisaged with approximately 
32 pages of illustrations. All material available with the Govern^ 
ment of India would be placed at your disposal, and you would have 
a completely free hand in ^vhat was selected. The War Historical 
Section in Delhi is now engaged on the co-ordination of material. 

‚ÄòIt would be necessary to do a certain amount of preliminary work 
in Dellu, and the Government of India -would secure air priorities 
both ways. The amount of research needed there, or whether the 
book was completed there, -will be at the discretion of the author.‚Äô 
I replied on the same day: 

‚ÄòI should have been proud and happy to undertake the task 
suggested, but I fear that my health wll not allo-w me to make the 
journey to India. It‚Äôs most disappointing for me to have to refuse, 
but I fear it is inevitable,‚Äô 

Captain Shaw was not prepared to take ‚Äòno‚Äô for. an answer for 
which I shall always be grateful to him, and, after an interview, asked 
his chief, Lieut.-General T. W. Corbett, to decide whether my -visit 
to India could be postponed until the end of the summer next year. 
The reply came in a telegram from G.H.Q,., India: 
‚ÄòCommander-in-Chief hopes you will accept writing of Indian

FOREWORD 


XV 


I wish to thank H.H. the Maharaja of Nepal for granting me the 
privilege of visiting Nepal and Lieut.-Colonel Sir George Falconer 
for the trouble he took to make that visit such a valuable experience. 

I owe much to Licut.-Colonel A. E. Cocksedge and all the 
British and Indian officers at the Historical Section- in Simla for the 
trouble tlrey took to plan my movements and provide me with 
information, and a special word of gratitude to Mr. Philip Woodruff 
Mason, I.G.S., in Delhi. 

Finally, I must record the devoted help of Lieut.-Colonel J. G. 
Thomson, I.A.M.C., and Major Peter Goodwin in helping to make 
many arduous journeys so conafortable. 

This tale of the effort by India and the Indian Army in the 
Second World War is not an official history. The Government of 
India gave me tire opportunity to reach places many of which would 
have been impossible for the ordinary traveller to reach. What 
I made of that opportunity was to be my own affair. I have tried 
to repay that generosity and trust, but I am only too sharply con- 
scious how far my work falls short of the ideal military history. 
Nevertheless, I humbly venture to hope that those of my own 
countrymen who read Eastern Epic will apprehend by the time the 
second volume is concluded that in the Second World War the old 
Indian Army played as vital a part as the old British Regular Army 
played in the First World War. That wonderful old Indian Army no 
longer exists, but its traditipns survive and will survive in the new 
Armies of India and Pakistan. I have heard from every observer 
qualified to judge nothing but enthusiastic praise for the spirit and 
discipline of those new Armies. I have been particularly moved by 
Field-Marshal Sir Claude Auchinleck‚Äôs recognition-of that spirit and 
discipline because his devotion was an inspiration to the old Indian 
Army, and the Armies of India and Pakistan are still proud of his 
example. 

The great act of statesmanship which secured the good will of 
both India and Pakistan by an Imperial abdication unmatched in 
the world‚Äôs history has not even yet been appreciated in' all its virtue 
except in Asia. If these pages should contribute so much as a mite 
toward a keener appreciation throughout the British Gommomvealth 
they will not have been "written in vain. 

In that hope and with deep reverence I dedicate Eastern Epic to 
tlic noble memory of the old Indian Army and to the glorious future 
of the young Annies of India and Pakistan.

PROLOGUE 


T he beginnings of the Indian Army may be traced to the Indian 
watch-keepers who served the East India Company as guards 
for their trading-stations. Gradually as the Company expanded 
battalions were formed and ultimately these became the nucleus of 
the three armies of the Presidency of Madras, the Presidency of 
Bombay and the Presidency of Bengal. These armies were separate 
establishments, but in 1748 they all came under one Commander- 
in-Chief, Major Stringer Lawrence, who may be considered the first 
of that long line which ended with General Sir Claude Auchinleck 
a few months from exactly two centuries later. 

Stringer Lawrence gave a chance to the genius of Robert Clive 
ao in Bengal in 1757 was the first to organise sepoy battalions with 
ixropean uniform, training and arms and commanded by British 
Beers. Until then the Indian troops of the Company had used their 
vn weapons and dress and had been commanded by Indian 
officers. Madras adopted Clive‚Äôs system in Bengal with six battalions, 
raised in 1759; Bombay followed suit in 1767. 

After the Great Mutiny, which it should be realised, was closely 
bound up with a revolt in parts of India against British dominion, 
all the troops of the Company were transferred to the Crown and in 
1861 there was a general reorganisation of the Army in India in the 
course of which the regular cavalry regiments, except three of the 
Madras cavalry, were abolished, and the rest of the cavalry was 
based on the sillidar system by which for a sum down and a mainten- 
ance grant, every man provided his own horse, his ovra arms and 
his own military attire. British officers in such irregular regiments 
were very few, and in infantry battalions they were reduced from 
22 for a battalion to six. The Indian artillery was abolished at 
the same time. The Presidency armies remained and the units of 
the Indian Army as a whole, including the Punjab Frontier Force 
and the Hyderabad contingent, amounted to 42 cavalry regiments, 

. 142 infantry battalions and three corps of engineers, about 135,000 
men in all. 

In 1 886 the Punjab Frontier Force, hitherto controlled by the 
civil authority, was placed under the Commander-in-Chief, and in 
1895 the Presidency armies were abolished in favour of geographical 
area commands. Regiments descended from the old P.P.F. were 
called ‚ÄòPiffers,‚Äô and - that famous nickname is. still affectionately 
preserved in the Pakistan Army of to-day.

INDIAN REARMAMENT 


3 


The Committee went on to say: 

Already drafts from the British Army from the United Kingdom 
on arrival in India have to be retrained in the use of obsolete 
weapons and outworn tactical methods, while British units on 
leaving India have to be taught afresh before they can take their 
place in British field formations. 


Ail high explosive has, at present, to be imported, and there is 
no production of motor vehicles, wireless sets, power tools or 
machinery in general. 

The conclusions reached by the Auchinleck Committee formed 
the basis for the recommendations made by the Expert Committee 
on the Defence of India under the chairmanship of Admiral of the 
Fleet Lord Chatfield which were published on September 5th 1939 
and in which it was announced thatH.M. Government were prepared 
to provide a total net capital cost of ;^34,330,ooo, three-quarters of it 
as a free gift, for the modernisation of India‚Äôs defences under a five 
years‚Äô plan. 

So rapidly was this five years‚Äô plan put into motion for fighting a 
war which had already begun that a first instalment of ;^J200 ,ooo for 
cavalry reorganisation had already been paid by the War Office 
when the Committee‚Äôs findings were published. 

It should be noted at this point that plans for the modernisation of 
the Army in India were all based on the defence of the North-West 
Frontier and the equipment of one division for service overseas ‚Äî one 
division. 

The Modernisation Committee had said in 1938: 

The amount of mechanical transport which it is suggested 
should be provided for the modernised army has been based on the 
maintenance of a force approximately one cavalry light tank 
brigade and 10 infantry brigades with artillery and other troops 
attached, as well as the necessary protective troops for the lines 
of communication, up to a distance of 100 miles from the nearest 
, railhead. It is also proposed to keep a future reserve of six 
mechanical transport sections in the General Reserve to meet 
, unforeseen emergencies. Field ambulances will be required on the 
scale of one for each war brigade in the Army. Ambulances 
serving mechanised formations or formations with mechanised 
first-line troops must also be mechanised. 

Yet even that one light tank brigade could not be equipped until 
the third year of the war. . 



4 EASTERN EPIC 

In April 1939 the Indian Army Ordnance Corps took over the 
workshop services of the Royal Indian Army Service Corps and 
assumed responsibility for the maintenance and repair of all mecha- 
nised vehicles. This transfer involved trebling the IA..O.G. and 
entering upon an extensive building programme of repair shops and 
training establishments which heavily handicapped the corps at the 
outbreak of war. 

Transportation services did not exist before May 1940. The 
Movements Organisation was in a rudimentary stage represented by 
a second grade staff officer in the Directorate of Movements and 
Quartering. There were embryo embarkation staffs at Bombay, 
Madras, Calcutta and Karachi, but there was no control staff for 
internal railway movement. 

The munition factories of India, some of which went back to the 
days of the East India Company, were administered by the Master- 
General of Ordnance. They %vere few in number and, although most 
of the basic metallic ores for armament existed in India or adjacent 
territories, there was no means of converting them to use and all 
vital raw material had to be imported. There %vas no factory for 
motor vehicles; only vehicle bodies could be produced, and these 
on a very small scale. The aircraft industry did not exist, and anti- 
aircraft defence was not contemplated as even a contingent necessity. 

The oil needs of India could be partially met by the fields at 
Attock and Digboi, but petrol was imported from Abadan. There 
was no tankage for strategic reserves of petrol and aviation spirit, and 
there were not enough tank wagons to ensure the rapid transport of 
such supplies from the ports. 

The shortage of supply in every direction had been appreciated by 
1938., No attempt was made to assess the needs of essential civil 
industries. H.M. Government was consulted in 1938 about priorities 
of supply to and from India and other parts of the Empire, but no 
practical scheme had been fixed when ffie war started- 
Thc principle of Indianisation for officers of the Army in India 
had been accepted in igi8, but it was a slow process. The first step 
was to provide for a small quota of Indian cadets at Sandhurst which 
tvas increased a fw years later. The choice svas skilfully made and 
many of the high-ranking officers of the present armies of India and 
Pakistan began their brilliant careers under this scheme. In 1922 
eight units of cavalry and infantry were chosen for complete 
Indianisation and at last in October 1932 the Indian Military 
Aodemy at Dchra Dun was opened. From there Indian com- 
missioned officers passed directly into the Anmy, and Indianisation 



INDIAN REARMAMENT 


5 

was extended to provide for a division of all arms mth the ancillary 
services and a cavalry brigade. 

At this time it was proposed to eliminate the Viceroy‚Äôs com- 
missioned officers who had been a unique feature of the Indian 
Army since its reorganisation in 1857-8. This remarkable body of 
men, promoted from the ranks and for the most part sons of small 
landlords and peasant farmers, had formed an indispensable 
link between the British officer and the ranks, and it was generally 
considered that the elimination of such experienced material would 
be a profound mistake. The question was still being deliberated 
when the onset of war made it vital to speed up the process of 
Indianisation, and provide the British and Indian officers necessary 
for the expansion now envisaged. The scheme for an all Indian 
division was laid aside and the proposed elimination of Viceroy‚Äôs 
commissioned officers was abandoned. The risaldars and jemadars 
of the Indian cavalry and the subadars and jemadars of the Indian 
infantry stand beside the warrant officers of the Royal Navy and 
of the British Army ‚Äî paragons all of arms and the man. Without 
them the bright pages of this history would be less bright and the 
sombre pages more sombre still. 

During the First World War the Royal Indian Marine had done 
much good service, but it was not until 1928 that it was restored to 
combatant status, and not until 1934 that it was raised to the status 
of the Royal Indian Navy. A policy of Indianisation was introduced 
in 1929 and recruitment was extended to the Punjab, In the same 
year India assumed responsibility for coastal defence and the annual' 
subvention of ^120,000 paid by India for such defence to the Royal 
Navy was no longer demanded. An expansion of the Royal Indian 
Navy was planned in anticipation and completed by June 1937; 
but the subvention was paid until April 1938. Late in 1939 regula- 
tions for the Royal Indian Naval Reserve, the Royal Indian Fleet 
Reserve, and the Royal Indian Naval Volunteer Reserve were 
approved; but at the outbreak of war there were no R.I.N.R. 
officers, no R.I.F.R. ratings, and recruitment for the R.I.N.V.R. 
had only just begun. There were two fairly modem sloops ‚Äî 
H.M.I.S. Indus and H.M.I.S. Hindustan, four old sloops H.M.I.S. 
Cornwallis, Investigator, Lawrence and Clive, and one fast patrol boat 
‚ñ† H.M.I.S. Pathan. ‚Ä¢ , 

The Indian Air Force was formally constituted on October loth 
1932; and it came into operation in April 1933 with a single flight. 
A second flight was formed in 1938. In July 1939 there were 16 
officers and 662 airmen in the Indian Air Force, and three Indian

cadets were training at Cranwell. On the recommendation of the

It was based on the organisation of civil flying clubs, and about

Allusion has been made to the Ghatfield Committee. This Com- 
mittee under the chairmanship of Admiral of the Fleet Lord 
Ghatfield came to India in November 1938 and submitted its report, 
at the end of January 1939. The findings were approved by H.M. 
Government in due course and the publication of them coincided 
almost exactly %vith the outbreak of war. They are of considerable 
interest, tinged mth melancholy, as an expression of expert opinion 
on the brink of the greatest war in history. 

The Committee found that India‚Äôs drfence plans must provide 
not only for the contingency of aggression from the North-West 
coupled with widespread tribal disturbances, but also to an increas- 
ing extent for the protection of sea communications in eastern 
waters and the strate^c points vital to their security. 

The definition of the role of the forces laid down by the Garran 
Tribunal was no longer accepted: 

The general principle that we would put for\vard in its place is 
that the forces maintained in India should be adequate not 
merely for the narrower purposes of purely local defence, but also 
to assist in ensuring her security against the external threats that 
we have described; and further, that India should acknowledge 
that her responsibility cannot in her own interests be safely 
limited to the local dtfence of her own land frontiers and coasts. 
. . . The principle on which the financial arrangements between 
the two Governments should be based is that India should bear 
some share in the joint responsibility for her external security. 

The Committee rejected the plan to form an Imperial Reserve 
Division: 


The forc^ that can be made available from India to assist in. 
the protection of her external interests should, in our opinion, form 
an integral part of the forces in India as a whole. We assume that 
India would normally have, over and above the forces regarded 
^ the mimmum necessity Ibr keeping her frontiers and coasts 
mtact and ensuring internal order, forces available for what we 
have called the external defence of India, which we regard as a 
matter of common and direct concern to both Governments. That 
being so, the ‚Äòobligation‚Äô on the Government of India is no longer 
a contract to perform something outside the sphere of their normal 



GHATFIELD COMMITTEE 


7 

duties; it becomes an integral part of those duties. We assume 
. further that both Governments would collaborate in preparing 
plans which, as regards India, would take account not only of 
India‚Äôs local defence and internal security, but also of the threats 
to, and perhaps not even localised near, her frontiers and coasts, 
instead of treating them in isolation. 

The Committee recommended that aU forces provided for such 
external defence purposes should be called ‚ÄòExternal Defence 
Forces‚Äô and so far as the Army alone was concerned ‚ÄòExternal 
Defence Troops.‚Äô Modernisation should be on a uniform scale both 
on general grounds and to ensure that the British forces in India 
were interchangeable with those on the Imperial establishment. 

The allotment of troops in four categories, namely. Frontier 
Defence troops. Internal Security troops, Coast Defence troops, 
and a General Reserve (including Air Defence troops) with the 
numbers suggested by the Commander-in-Chief for each category 
was accepted, and from the surplus units were to be drawn to form 
the External Defence troops. Such troops should consist of one 
British cavalry regiment, three British infantry battalions, and seven 
Indian infantry battalions. 

Under this allotment one cavalry regiment, three Royal Horse 
Artillery batteries, one field artillery regiment, one medium 
artillery regiment, and two infantry battalions of the British troops 
in India should be withdrawn. The three Indian cavalry regiments, 
four companies of sappers and miners, and 14 infantry battalions 
surplus to requirements should be disbanded unless they could be 
employed at Imperial stations or otherwise. To anticipate any hostile 
criticism of these recommendations the Committee expressly stated 
that it had weighed the serious strategic considerations then existing. 

External Defence troops were to be somewhat more highly and 
expeditiously equipped than the remaining forces, and the process of 
modernisation was to be completed in five years. Of the policy of 
Indianisation the Committee observed: 

The crucial stage will not be reached until 1945, when the 
British officers (in Indianised units) will begin to disappear 
entirely. When that stage is reached, the whole experiment may 
have to be reviewed, and it would be unwise to forecast the result. 

For the reorganisation of the Royal Indian Navy the plans 
drawn up by the Flag Officer Commanding were accepted in 
general, and the construction of four escort vessels and four trawlers, 
was recommended together %vith the rearming of Indus and Hindustan.

It will be clear from the facts given above that not only was India 
entirely unprepared for a major war when war came, but that there 
did not exist any glimmering notion of what India's part would be 
when war did come. The bright spot in a prospect of almost tm- 
mitigated gloom was the existence of a highly trained army, many 
,units of which had had practical experience; of warfare on the 
Nortli-Wcst Frontier, commanded by probably tlie best. regimental 
officers in the world. Like the British Army in 1914 it was a small 
and extremely efficient army of professional volunteers; but it was 
hot equipped for modern war, and therefore it could not match 
its efficiency with its effectiveness. . ; 

Although H.M. Government‚Äôs approval of the Chatfidd Report 
was not reedved in India until the outbreak of v/ar, preparatory 
steps to modernise the Army in accord witli the recommendations 
began early in 1939. Orders for necessary vehicles and equipihent 
were given and plans for the redistribution of the Army were pre- 
pared; but without the modern weapons and equipment little could 
be done to train troops in the new way of warfare. The Army 
consisted almost entirely of horsed cavalry, unmechanised infantry, 
and horsed artillery. There were no anti-tank units, arid in the 
whole of India there were only eight anti-aircraft guns. There were 
some motor transport companies in the Royal Indian Army Service 
Corps, but most of the transport still depended on animals‚Äî mules, 
camels and horses. The division of External Defence troops had 
not been formed, and in the event the troops sent overseas before the 
outbreak of war were mostly those which hadnot been allocated for 
external defence. So far as the futiure was concerned the Indian 
Army was at an awkward stage of transition. Iridianisadon as 
regards officers affected comparatively few units. The Army was 
still dependent on British personnel. There was no Indian artillery 
except the volunteer batteries and one experimental Indian field 
regiment. There were no Indian engineer units except the sappers 
and miners. A proportion of Indians were included in brigade 
signal sections, but. signals as a whole was entirely British; Supply . 
and transport, medical and ordnance services were all dependent 
on British warrant officers and non-commissioned officers, and those 
were already too few for the needs of the pre-war Army. ‚Ä¢ 

No approved plan for a general expansion of the forces existed, 
and even when war came there ww no idea of; how great that 
expansion would be. The Chatfield Committee, under the depressing 
influence of the financial bronaide which the National Goveriurient

The disastrous events in Europe which ended in the fall of France 
blew up complacency about the likely course of war all over tire 
world, and in India it was recognised that the military situation 
rendered it ‚Äòmost desirable to build up afield army in India for use 
either for the defence of her frontiers or for employment overseas as 
the situation might demand.‚Äô 

In 1940 it was planned to train and equip a field army of one 
armoured division, three infantry divisions and one extra brigade,

Two more infantry brigade groups were offered for service

The centralisation of production in Great Britain prevented any 
productive effort in India, and when in June the Mediterranean was 
dosed by the entry of Italy into the war the very small quantity of 
armament that was being sent to India shrank to almost nothing. 
India was driven to produce for herself and the slightly increased 
output which had been, it seemed grudgingly, accepted by H.M. 
Government in August 1939 in the event of war in Europe was now 
to be as sviddy expanded as possible. The Department of Supply, a 
new organisation set up at the outbreak of war, took over the 
ordnance factories, medical stores, mathematical instruments and 
the capadty of several railway workshops. 

India invited representatives from Australia, New Zealand, 
South Africa, East Africa, Southern Rhodesia, Ceylon, Burma, 
Malaya and Hong Kong to take part in a conference in the autumn 
of 1940 in New Delhi at which the co-ordination of the existing and 
potential capacity for war supply could be discussed vdth a view to 
meet die needs of each as far as possible and make surpluses available 
to Great Britain. 

The sequel to this conference was the establishment of the 
Eastern Group Supply Coundl, and the resultant steps which India 
took toward industrialisation made at this conference marked a 
turning point in the history of India's economic devdopment. 

By the end of 1940 the existing hve sloops under the command of

And now before we follow the 4th and 5th Indian Divisions along 
the path of glory overseas a glance must be taken at the North-West 
Frontier. 

Wise after the event we arc inclined to wonder how it was possible 
for the military imagination of India to preoccupy itself so much 
with the North-West Frontier and practically to ignore the North- 
East Frontier. If we look back to that August day in 1939 when 
we heard of the agreement reached between the Germans and the 
Russians and remember the shock to our nervous system in Great 
Britain we shall hardly blame the Army in India for their appre- 
hension. If we remember the effect produced at home by the Russian 
invasions of Poland and Finland we shall hardly blame the Army in 
India for concentrating upon the defence of India against an attempt 
by Russia to exploit the situation. It was a menace almost a century 
old. 

The North-West Frontier is a mountainous strip of country along 
the boundary line between Afghaiustan and India except in the 



OPERATIONS ON N.W. FRONTIER 15 

north where it touches Russian Turkestan, It stretches for about 
1,200 miles from tlie Pamirs to the shores of the Arabian Sea and has 
a total area of 26,000 square miles inhabited by about 3,500,000 
tribesmen whose only allegiance is to their rifles. Russian influence 
had been predominant in Kabul since the Third Afghan War in 
1919 which cost the Army in India such heavy casualties. In 1939 
and 1940, German, Italian and Japanese agents were fomenting 
ill-feeling between Afghanistan and Britain; Russian agents were 
more actively mischievous. The attitude of Afghanistan, the state of 
the tribes, and the prospect of invasion were all factors in planning 
for the defence of India, and no criticism can be levelled against the 
determination of the High Command in India to make and keep the 
Frontier ready for tlie worst. Only an insensate optimism would 
have adopted anotlier course. 

In Wazirist^, under the inspiration of the Faqir of Ipi, raiding 
gangs had been active all through 1939. With the outbre^ of the 
war special measures had to be put in hand for the protection of 
military traffic on roads within the administrative district of Bannu 
hitherto considered safe. In Waziristan convoys demanded close 
escorts of armoured cars and lorried infantry with the co-operation of 
the South Waziristan Scouts and aircraft. At the beginning of 1940 
air action against the Shabi Khel Mahsuds discouraged the Mahsuds 
from further hostile activities, and the general situation in South 
Waziristan improved. However, on the administrative borders of the 
Bannu and Kohat districts It deteriorated owing to active raiding 
from the Ahmedzai Salient, and operations against the tribes had 
to be carried out between February and May 1940. Before they 
were concluded at the time of the German invasion of France 
these operations involved three R.A.F. squadrons, 16 Indian infantry 
battalions and two mechanised cavalry regiments with equivalent 
artillery, engineers, signals and supply services. The 8th Cavalry and 
the 1 6th Cavalry were still horsed. 

By September 1940 frontier Defence troops and their reserves 
amounted to three armoured regiments, four mountain artillery regi- 
ments, nine engineer units and 60 infantry battalions. An observer 
corps had also been formed. 

In December 1 940 operations in Waziristan were on a fairly large 
scale; but in the words of the General Staff: ‚Äòthe Mahsuds thought 
better of it when they saw the number of troops we had concentrated 
to deal with them and gave in. We can never afford to neglect our 
. Frontier problem and we doubt if it is realised at home, how low our 
reserves have fallen in trying to meet ah the demands made'upon usl‚Äô 



i6 EASTERN EPIC 

This state of affairs was liable to grow worse all the while because 
anti-British propaganda was persistent, and malcontents like the 
Faqir of Ipi were now being subsidised Iry Germany and Italy, and 
continuously encouraged by Russian and Japanese agents, ' 

It ‚ñ†will be seen from the quotation above that the Frontier always 
meant the North-West Frontier. The Eastern Frontier was accepted 
as something perfectly secure and at this date did not enter into 
India‚Äôs military preparations and defence organisation. 

Perhaps it was as well. If a vision of tvhat was to happen at the 
end of 1941 had been granted to the General Staff in Delhi there 
might have been no Indian divisions sent overseas in the first year 
of the war, and Egypt and the Sudan might have been lost.

T he I ith Indian Infantry Brigade sailed from Bombay on August 
1939 to arrive in Egypt before the dark cloud over Europe was 
riven by the lightning of war. 

It was joined early in October by the 5th Indian Infantry 
Brigade and a Force Headquarters under command of which the 
two brigades were combined to form the 4th Indian Infantry 
Division, Neither of the brigades had any modern equipment. They 
were without motor vehicles and trained drivers. The' men had 
never seen a mortar or an anti-tank rifle; the officers had never 
handled them. In Egypt training started for each unit when weapons 
and vehicles were issued to them, and the rapidity with which they 
adapted themselves to novel tactics, the use of modern weapons, and 
the driving and maintenance of modern vehicles jusdfied the confi- 
dence, the pride and the affection of their officers, ‚ÄòNo wonder these 
Indian Army officers are so cocky about their men,‚Äô wrote a subaltern 
in a British battalion. 

Early in October 1939 the British Army in France lacked animal

Force K6 disembarked at Marseilles on December 25th 1939, It is

expression of gratitude for their safe escort in convoy by‚Äô the Royal 
Navy. , ,

The men were not allowed to leave camp until they could read

over Great Britain and everywhere made a profound impression on 
the people with whom they came into contact. One of the units was 
stationed at Lairg in Sutherland for several weeks before it was 
ordered to move for the pre-invasion of France. The commanding 
officer received a letter from prominent citizens asking for the move 
to be cancelled because the people of Lairg were so much enjoying 
the presence of the Indian troops. It was explained that a military 
order had to be obeyed, whereupon a letter signed by a large 
number of people was received in which it was said that they under- 
stood tlie position but they wished it to be put on record that there 
would be an empty chair in every house in Lairg when the unit 
departed.

Mussolini‚Äôs conviction that Hitler had won the war and would 
presently be the sole victor of an imposed peace unless he pushed 
himself into a prominent place beside him led to the declaration of 
war by Italy on June loth 1940. This action by Mussolini, who 
bears the prime and almost the sole responsibility for it, has been 
likened to the behaviour of a jackal, but that is to insult the animal 
world by comparing Hider to a lion. Europe had been terrorised by 
gangster methods. The Munich surrender had encouraged the 
gangsters to believe that Britain and France were fundamentally 
weak and their belief seemed confirmed by the course of military 
events. It would have taken a major prophet to avoid the mistake 
Mussolini made, and on the evidence before his eyes, if the propo- 
sition of sacred egoism was a valid one in 1915, it was his duty to do 
what he did just a month over 25 years later. 

‚Ä¢ A week after Mussolini‚Äôs decision Marshal Petain asked for an 
armistice. Fortunately, as is now clear, General Weygand, the 
Supreme Commander of the Allied Forces in the Middle East, 
obeyed the Marshal and did not encourage General Nogues 
commanding the French forces in North Africa or General Mittel- 
hauser commanding them in Syria to refuse capitulation. At the 
moment it seemed a disastrous surrender; but if the French had 
stood firm Hitler would have been compelled to employ the full 
strength of Germany to secure Africa and the Levant. As it was, the 
capitulation of the French made the British position appear hopeless: 

It was not an imreasonable supposition.

CAMPAIGN IN SOMALILAND 23 

main attack being directed from Jijiga in Abyssinia along the road to 
Berbera, the port and capital. Two days later Hargeisa, the Govern- 
ment hill station, had fallen and by August nth five Colonial 
brigades, three Blackshirt battalions, three Banda groups, and 100 
armoured vehicles including 27 tanla and 20 guns were streaming 
down the slopes toward the plain 60 miles from Berbera, 

Tlie small force, outnumbered by ten to one, entrusted with the 
task of making the conquest of British Somaliland as costly as possible 
for the enemy, had taken up positions in the hills that ring Berbera 
in order to cover the passes, the chief of which is the wide sandy 
river-bed known as Tug Argan. In the exhilaration of their much 
superior strength the Italians repeatedly attacked the thinly defended 
posts in close formation under cover of artillery, tanks and air 
support and, fighting with courage and resolution, sustained heavy 
casualties. During the darkness the Imperial troops would retire 
from one position to anotlicr and the enemy losing contact would 
find himself faced with stiff opposition from an unexpected quarter. 
However, numbers were bound to tell in the end, and though the 
advance was an expensive business for the enemy it was steady. 
During that fighting retreat the Indian troops came under dive 
bombing for the first time; they were naturally shaken by the infernal 
experience at the beginning, but once they had discovered the 
protection of a slit trench dive bombing seemed less terrific. 

Meanwhile, the Navy had erected an all-tide jetty at Berbera and 
the evacuation of the civilians and administrative officials from that 
shimmering, rust-red, sunstruck coast was carried through until the 
embarkation of the troops began at i p.m. on August i6th, lasting all 
through the night and completed by the afternoon of the following 
day. A bayonet charge by the Black Watch at Barkasan had finally 
taken the heart out of the Italians, who had already suffered heavy 
casualties, for any attempt to harass the operation. During the 
‚ñ†withdrawal to the port, one company of the 3/i5th Punjab Regt 
holding out against a particularly heavy enemy assault was cut off 
from the main body and believed to be lost. However, it eluded the 
enemy by a skilful night march and was able to rejoin the rearguard 
two days later, . . 

Our total casualties were 38 killed, yt wounded and 49 missing. 
The Italian casualties were estimated at ten times as large; when 
Berbera was re-entered on March 16th 194^ hy the same troops who

found suggested that the Italian casualties were nearer twenty _

The move from the delta to the desert was made partly by rail, 
partly by vehicles. It was a tribute to the skill of the Indian drivers 
that only i per cent, of these vehicles broke down even temporarily 
on that 250-miIe drive first across the sandy desert and then across

which lasted for two months. In September the division was joined

1st Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders. 

On September 13th 1940 two Italian divisions crossed the 
Egyptian frontier and three days later halted at Sidi Barrani, the 
small British force having withdrawn from Solium eastward along 
the coast. Instead of attempting to advance farther the Italians got 
busy with the construction of a series of fortified camps round Sidi 
Barrani, which ran from Maktila 15 miles east on the coast, and 
southward through the Tummars and Nibeiwa to Sofafi on the 
escarpment south-west. These camps were strongly defended with 
mines, anti-tank obstacles, trenches and barbed wire, the largest of 
them being Maktila, garrisoned by the ist Libyan Division with 
many guns and some tanks. Tummar East and Tummar West 
sheltered the 2nd Libyan Division. Nibeiwa, the strongest of all, 
was held by the Maletti Mobile Group of 4,000 men with a battalion 
of medium tanks, and many motor vehicles. The Sofafi group of 
camps comprised four strong positions on top of the escarpment well 
supplied with tanks and held by a division of Italian regulars. 
Behind this outer line of defences there were Blackshirt divisions at 
Sidi Barrani and Solium and a regular division at Buq Buq. The 
Italians built a good road from Fort Capuzzo through Solium and 
Buq Buq nearly as far as Sidi Barrani and laid a pipe-line for water 
from Bardia.

OPERATIONS IN THE SUDAN

Cairo, Syria to Abyssinia, and the true Middle East of Iran and Iraq, 
undoubtedly caused much confusion in strategic thought from time to

When in that fateful June of 1940 Mussolini put his black shirt on 
Germany‚Äôs victory the Imperial forces in the Sudan were as inade- 
quate as elsewhere. To be precise, there were three battalions of 
British troops and the Sudan Defence Force numbering 4,500 men 
without tanks or guns, except two fixed 6-inch coastal guns at 
Port Sudan and four small obsolete howitzers at the Governor- 
General‚Äôs palace in Khartoum used for firing salutes. Seven ancient 
aircraft were at the disposal of this force for the reconnaissance of 
1,200 miles of frontier. The Italians had at least 250,000 men with 
400 guns and 200 aircraft. 100,000 troops with powerful artillery 
were available along the frontier with many points of entry by which 
an invasion of the Sudan could have been made with reasonable 
ease. Fortunately the enemy lacked transport for the grandiose 
operation he supposed an invasion of the Sudan would entail. There 
is one advantage in starting a major war with almost notliing; the 
enemy cannot believe that there is almost nothing. Hence tire 
failure of the Italians to strike boldly both in Cyrenaica and Eritrea. 
The Kaid, Major-General W. Platt^ lost no time in trying to suggest 
that greater strength, and the motor macliine-gun companies of the

O N October 28th 1940 Mussolini had aspired to show Hitler how 
to run a war in the Mediterranean by sending the forces of Italy 
in Albania against Greece. On tlie night of November g/ioth the 
Giulia Division, the crack division of Alpini, was driven back along 
the valley of the Sarandoporos by two battalions of Evzones, and the 
invaders failed to reach Metsovo and break through into the 
Thessalian plain. On the night of November ix/i2th, Admiral 
Cunningham‚Äôs Fleet Air Arm crippled the Italian Navy in the 
harbour of Taranto. 

As early as October 20th General Wavell had instructed General 
Wilson to consider the possibility of an attack on the enemy forward 
camps in Libya with the intention of exploiting such an attack if 
successful with the 7th Armoured Division northward toward the 
coast and with the 4th Indian Division westward. At that date Mr 
Eden, the Secretary of State for War, was on a visit to Egypt, 
according to Radio Roma in order to organise a last desperate 
attempt to defend that country. Wavell told him of his plans on 
condition that he would say nothing about them until he could 
communicate them to Mr Churchill by word of mouth. Thanks to 
Mr Eden‚Äôs support, reinforcements of aircraft were promised to 
make good those which had been sent from Egypt to Greece. The 
despatch of those precious squadrons, as well as troops, armament 
and transport to occupy Crete, had made it look as if the plan to 
attack the Sidi Barrani forts would have to be abandoned: in the 
event it was only postponed from the last week of November to the 
first week in December. Secrecy was so strict that hardly a detail of 
the plan was put on paper and scarcely a dozen senior commanders 
and staff officers knew of the plan until just before it was put into 
execution. The strength of the enemy was believed to amount to 
80,000 troops with 250 guns and 120 tanks against which the force 
to be disposed was 31,000 men, 120 guns, 275 tanks (of which more 
than half were light tanks, 50 were Infantry tanks, and the rest 
cruisers) and 60 armoured cars.

Wavell had for some time been planning to send the 4th Indian 
Division to the Sudan for a possible offensive against tlic enemy, and 
to relieve it in the Western Desert by the 6th Australian Division as 
soon as tliis was I'cady. Wiiile the battle of Sidi Barrani was in

the Red Eagles because owing to the shipping problem he had to do 
it at once or wait perhaps for many weclts for another opportunity. 
On December loth he gave the fateful order that two days later the 
4th Indian Division would move back to its old positions. The 
idtimate destination of tire Red Eagles was a secret, and their 
‚ñ†withdratval from what now seemed certain to be a glorious campaign 
caused a good deal of depression. It was hard to know that their 
best-loved and most admired comrades of tire incomparable 7th 
Armoured Division were westward bound rvithout them ‚Äî ^the 7th 
Armoured Division which, after tlrrec days of continuous movement 
and fighting in a heav^' dust storm, had filled up with petrol, food 
and water and on its own initiative gone off into the dark over

camps and put many more thousands of prisoners into the bag. 
Still, the Red Eagles could flap their wings. In three days the 
division had taken over 20,000 prisoners with many guns, tanks and 
stores. Three enemy divisions and the Maletti group had been 
destroyed. The cost had been less than 700 casualties. The Red 
Eagles had aclueved something larger than that; they had set the 
hopes of the British Commonwealth soaring witli themselves. They 
had handed to the people of Britain jdroboams of champagne at a 
time when they were growing tired of flat ale, even when the Prime 
Minister from time to time put a head on it with his inspiring words. 
Solium, Bardia, Tobruk, Dcma and Benghazi were still to come, but 
, Sidi Rarrani made them possible. And what made Sidi Barrani 
possible? The defiance of Churchill when in that desperate June he 
ordered the reinforcements for North Africa to go on, the transports 
to head southward to the Cape of Good Hope at a moment when 
Britain herself was almost disarmed; , the defiance of Wavell when ‚ñ†

The original plan had been only to drive the Italians out of the

General Frusci, who had commanded an Italian division in the

Eritrean northern front, had been so much harried by Gazelle that he 
began to be anxious about his communications with Kassala from

Serobatib and Adardet and concentrated a mobile force in Sabdaret 
itself to meet any serious threat. In Rome early in December, the 
new Chief of the General Stag; General Ugo Cavallero, after the 
^saster in Libya, had convinced the High Command that it was 
time to abandon any notion of invading the Sudan and to concen- 
trate on defending the Empire of Ethiopia. Nor did the Greek 
victories along the Alfaaman frontier make for optimism. So orders 
were sent to Frusci to withdraw from the lowlands of Kassala and 
Metei^a and to hold the mountain passes from Agordat to Gondar. 
rmci argued that such a withdrawal would involve loss of prestige: 
e ad issued a proclamation to inform his troops that the English 
were on the point of attacking Kassala and that he intended to 
scatter them like chaff.

The decision of General Wavell on that December night to 
withdraw the 4th Indian Division from the triumph of Sidi Barrani 
and send it to wage an offensive campaign in East Africa must rank 
with any major military decisions which have set the course of 
histoiy‚Äô. Such a decision required imagination, faith and a plenitude 
of moral courage. He dreamed of the impossible: his dream tvas 
fulfilled by men who achieved the impossible. And what men they, 
were! 

Lieut.-General Platt allowed his two divisional commanders a 
freedom of initiative which not every corps commander is willing to 
grant. Major-General Beresford-Peirse and Major-General Heath 
handled their two great divisions w‚Äôith unfailing resource and 
determination, and svith a comradeship of arms that was never 
marred by jealous rivalry. The latter was a tactician of quality the 
whole of whose long career had been spent in the Indian Army, in 
the course of which he had seen a great deal of active service. It 
was he who first realised the necessity of capturing Fort Dologorodoc 
and afterwards of making that supreme effort to drive through the 
Dongolaas Gorge.

The unfortunate licence of wartime propaganda allowed the 
British Press to represent the Italians almost as comic warriors; 
but except for the German parachute division in Italy and the 
Japanese in Burma no enemy with whom the British and Indian 
troops were matched put up a finer fight than those Savoia battalions 
at Keren. Moreover, the Colonial troops, until they cracked at the 
very end, fought with valour and resolution, and their staunchness 
was a testimony to tire excellence of the ItaUan administration and 
military training in Eritrea, wliich made the excesses of Graziani in ‚Ä¢ 
Abyssinia a blunder as well as a crime. 

Furthermore it must be stressed that tire Indian and British 
soldiers who won that tremendous victory against odds won it at a 
period in the war when equipment was at its lowest, and if the 
difficulties of the attackers are added to the vital results achieved by 
overcoming those difficulties at that date, the fall of Keren can claim 
to be considered one of the truly decisive battles of the world. 

Alffiough there was still some hard fighting before the Italian 
Empire in East Africa finally collapsed, the fall of Keren followed 
^most i^ediately by the capture of Massowa freed the Red Sea 
or t e American ships bringing the precious munitions of war to 
aid the struggle for North Africa. ‚ÄòIf‚Äô is an arid conjecture and 

is usually fruitless. Nevertheless, one can

The fighting troops did all that was asked of them during that

condition after that heavy campaign, and the R.I.A.S.G. drivers and 
the I.A.O.C. mechanics combined endurance with skill in the way 
vehicles were driven, maintained and repaired, urgent hour after 
urgent hour.

left the hills and assembled at the Togora Pass at 6 p.m., leaving the

white flag, but as the Piffers advanced to accept his surrender they 
were greeted with a shower of grenades and suffered severe casualties. 
This strange episode has never been explained, but it may be that the 
Italians suddenly panicked under the impression that the Frontier 
Force Rifles were the dreaded Abyssinians whose murderous forces 
were by now swarming in the neighbourhood, completely out of 
hand. Under cover of a dense mist on the hill tops the Italians were 
able to assemble for a counter-attack which recaptured Castle Hill, 
though the other objectives were all held. 

In the centre the Garhwalis kept up such a sustained fire that the 
enemy remained apprehensive of an attack in that direction, and in 
the East Fletcher Force by tireless and gallant aggressiveness 
completed the capture of the Falaga Pass by May 9th with many

escaped to join the East India Company‚Äôs forces under Lake and in 1809 raised the 
corps which became the 2nd Lancers and was ultimately amalgamated with 
another old regiment of the Bengal Army, the 4th Cavalry. 

The military history of Gardner‚Äôs Horse had been long and gloriotis. This was 
not their first experience of North Africa; they had fought at Tel-el-Kebir. The

On March 31st 1941, four days after the Italian withdrawal from 
Keren, the enemy counter-offensive in Cyrenaica began. The 6th 
Australian Division, the and New Zealand Division and a British 
armomed brigade were in Greece; the 14th British Infantry Brigade 
was in Crete. They would have been of inestimable value in Africa 
at that moment to stand against the 5th German Light Armomed 
Division and two Italian divisions, one armoured and one motorised. 

The Imperial troops too miles south of Benghazi were driven 
back toward Dema and Tobruk. The Germans despatched a large 
armoured force to the south to cut off the troops retreating along 
the coast road by the same route as the 7th Armoured Division had 
driven on to cut off the Italians retreating from Dema to Benghazi. 
The only place on this route rvith water was Mechili and the 3rd 
Indian Motor Brigade was ordered out from Tobruk to hold this 
vital bit of ground long enough to allow the Cyrenaica garrison to 
reach Tobmk. 

El Mechili lies 100 miles west of Tobruk, right out in the 
desert; a little stone and mud fort, quite useless for defence, was 
the only building for many many ntdles in every direction. Imagine 
a saucer of sand nine miles in diameter with a rocky uneven edge 
running up in places to a height of 800 feet. To the west the 
saucer edge is broken aivay and there the country is flat and opM. 
The fort is about a couple of miles from the northern rim, while 
rather more than half-way across is a landing ground, or what 
passes for one in the desert. The fort itself^ which contains the 
wells, had trenches dug round it by the Italians, but after the 
svinter storms they were silted up with sand. A desolate, forbidding 
place, it is normally visited only by a few wandering Bedouins, 
but by a strange chance it now became for a short time the most 
important spot in North Africa, after which it relapsed once 
more into its normal loneliness until December 1941.^ 

The move was made on April 4th, the brigade bring reinforced by 
mmc Austrahan anti-tank guimers and a few infantry of the Rifle 
Bn^dc. There was a night and a day in which to put the four-mile 
perimeter into a state of defence by clearing old trenches and digging 
nciv ones.

Motor Brigade was likely to find itself by trying to deny the enemy

columns were converging upon it east and south. Soon after this a 
German staff officer drove into the position under a white flag in an 
armoured Mercedes-Benz touring car and courteously demanded 
immediate and unconditional surrender^ pointing out in good 
English that the brigade was surrounded by greatly superior forces 
and would be bombarded out of existence if it tried to hold out. 
Brigadier E. W. D. Vaughan refused to consider surrender, and when 
the envoy returned again at noon the refusal was repeated. In the 
course of the afternoon a heavy bombardment was started which 
lasted until sunset. During the lull which succeeded there were 
infantry attacks by the enemy which were all beaten off. At 10.30 
p.m. the bombardment was renewed, and the position being 
obviously untenable it was decided to attempt a break out at dawn 
through the enemy lines southward. Two infantry attacks were 
repulsed during the night, and at daybreak of April 8th a squadron 
of the 1 8th Cavalry in 24 trucks with a cruiser tank commanded by 
Captain J. M. Barlow charged the enemy‚Äôs line of guns east of the 
camp. The tank was immediately knocked out, but the 24 trucks 
drove down in line on to the guns, and halting half to the right 
half to the left the sowars jumped out and went for the gun crews , 
with the bayonet. After knocking out three of the five guns the 
squadron with 27 casualties out of the 100 who charged remounted 
their trucks and drove on. 

The main body tried to break through southward imder cover of 
this gallant diversion. 


It was just daylight, but clouds of dust, pierced only by the 
glare of bursting shells, the red streak of tracer bullets and the 
flames of burning trucks, reduced visibility to a few yards, while 
the crash of gunfire, the rattle of maclrine-guns, and the howl of 
fast ‚Äòrevving‚Äô engines deafened and bewildered. To proceed as a 
formed body was impossible. Soon the trucks were driving though 
the enemy lines like a herd of stampeding cattle, swerving to the 
‚ñ† right and left as they ran into obstacles or into the mouths of 
enemy guns. Many never got through, but many more did.^

INDIA‚ÄôS CONCERN OVER FRONTIERS 77 

patient!) Hitler relieved titc tension on the Nortli-Wcst Frontier by 
invading Russia two days later. When the German troops were 
driving toward the Caucasus tlic menace seemed more serious than 
before, and the lack of anti-tank guns, air power and anti-aircraft 
defence perturbed tlic Indian General Staff. 

In spite of the confident belief in London that Japan would not 
enter the war it sv.as impossible in India to share tliat confidence and 
the problem of defending the North-East Frontier presented itself 
more urgently. Burma was foolishly retained .ns a separate command 
from India, and therefore no provision was made for an air striking 
force. However, an Air Defence Plan was made for the protection 
of areas producing vital necessities, and it w.as hoped to provide 
fighter squadrons for Calcutta, Tatanagar, Asanol and the Digbot 
oil, together with anti-aircr.aft guns and equipped observers. It was 
estimated that 234 heavy and 153 light anti-aircraft guns would be 
required, and 48 heavy and 180 light mobile guns. Wlicn this 
csrimate was made in March 1941 tlicre were available for the 
defence of the whole of India 1 7 anti-aircraft guns. 

When the forces sent to rescue Iraq were despatched India was 
left with four infantry divisions in the process of being raised and an 
incomplete armoured division from wluch tlie 3rd Indian Motor 
Brigade had already been sent to play its part in the Western Desert. 
It must be added that all these divisions vvcrc starved of vital 
equipment. 

Every effort was made to expand tlie Royal Indian Navy. The 
two new sloops H.M.I.S. Jumna and Sutlej were completed and 
fully commissioned. After playing a part in the Battle of the Atlantic 
they were sent to the Red Sea. The shipbuilding programme 
provided for the construction of 40 various types of vessels in 
addition to the 27 already building ‚Äî H.M.I.S. Travancore, the 
first vessel of the original construction programme was launched 
at Calcutta on July 7th 1941 and H.M.I.S. Baroda, the second, in 
October of the same year. Besides the ships being built in India four 
sloops were on the stocks in Britain and four vessels of the Bathurst 
class in Australia. There was a large increase in recruiting both for 
officers and ratings. Instructional establishments were increased. 
The building of a new signal school to accommodate 70 officers and 
over 900 ratings was begun in Bombay, and a gunnery school in 
Karachi. New naval barracks for 400 men were opened in January 
1941. Naval bases at Cochin and Vizagapatam came into being, 
and important work was started on, the bases at Karachi, Madras, 
Bombay and Calcutta.

SHORTAGE OF EQUIPMENT 79 

locusts of the National Government had eaten since 1931, but 
justice and truth demand that the implied slur upon the Indian 
effort should be answered. 

By early April in 1941 the position in the matter of equipment 
was so grave that India had to telegraph that certain forces which 
had been asked for were not fit for overseas service and that unless 
anti-tank and anti-aircraft units could be provided the Government 
of India would not agree to despatch a force likely to be engaged 
with an enemy equipped on modern lines. We have already heard 
what happened to the 3rd Indian Motor Brigade at Mechili exposed 
to German armour against which it had no defence except the 
gallantry of its officers and men: we shall hear presently of the 3rd 
Motor Brigade‚Äôs final tragedy. And that is but one comparatively 
small tragedy. We shall have to contemplate too many tragedies 
much more grim and much more prolonged whose authors were not 
incompetent commanders in the field or troops without the heart to 
fight, but politicians serving a recreant time and catching votes 
from a torpid and unimaginative electorate. We can blame General 
Staffs for want of foresight and determination and ask why they 
lacked the courage to resign as a body rather than become accom- 
plices of that abdication alike of imperial and of democratic duty. 
We can stigmatise the moral cowardice of Cabinets and the thin- 
lipped caution of Treasuries; but in the end the blame for them all 
rests upon ourselves. It was we who were weary of responsibility 
like the Romans once upon a time. 

Under the principle of replacement four new divisions were to be 
raised in 1 941 , but in the event the Indian Army rose from a strength 
of 400,000 at the beginning of the year to nearly a million at its 
close. The Royal Indian Navy grew in 1941 from the 170 officers 
and 1,500 ratings with which the war steirted to over a thousand 
officers and 8,000 ratings. The Indian Air Force expanded to tliree 
squadrons and six coastal defence flights. 

On May 5th 1941 India informed H.M. Government that if the 
demands for personnel were fulfilled and if the outstanding orders 
for equipment were executed- one armoured and four higher scale 
infantry, divisions -would be ready for the defence of India by the 
latter part of 1942. Their availability for overseas would depend 
upon their proper replacement. This offer was accepted three 
months later and India was notified for the first time that equip- 
ment would not be a grave difficulty, though India was warned 
that the provision of essential British personnel would be more 
difficult than ever. By October 1941 the shortage of officers had 



8o

become acute and by the end of the year the deficiency of oflScers and 
cadets would be 2,820 and 670 respecdvely. The C.I.G.S. was

having enough officers able to speak the language of their men. 
This shortage of officers and technical British personnel was one of 
the main causes that contributed to the disasters of 1942 when the 
whole expansion programme was disorganised by Japan‚Äôs entry 
into the war. 

The preposterous inadequacy of the air forces in India has already 
been noted. Nevertheless, early in 1941, India was asked to lend her 
only uvo modem squadrons to Far East Command until aircraft 
from the United States became available; and when Indian troops 
in Iraq required air support repeated requests for the return of these 
squadrons was refused. Eventually they took part in the Malaya and 
Burma operations.

^vas^ not impressed by this proclamation at the time because the

diSicult to see how that boast could have been falsified.

COUP JfJiTAT. IN IRAQ 83 

' In 1933 King Faisul died and was succeeded by his son Ghazi ‚Äî a 
young man of twenty-one. That was the year in wliich the Germans 
began the process of infiltration which was another expression of 
their dream of the Berlin to Baghdad railway dissipated by their 
defeat in the First World War. In 1936 there was a military coup 
d'etat which resulted in die formation of a strongly nationalist 
government, and although this government declared its intention 
to observe the provisions of the Anglo-Iraqi Treaty it was largely 
composed of men responsible for the Assyrian massacres and tolera- 
don of it seemed to many in the Near and Middle East evidence of 
British weakness. In Iraq a local Nazi parly began to function. A 
youth movement was developed on Nazi lines, and several, news- 
papers were subsidised in the German interest. The Nuremberg 
rally was attended by an Iraqi delegation and free educational 
facilities in Germany were offered to Iraqi students. In 1939 die 
ex-Mufti of Jerusalem with various adherents from Palestine and 
Syria arrived in Baghdad and began to work for Germany, and by 
1940 Rashid Ali el Gailani who had become Prime Minister early 
in the year was seducing prominent officers in the Iraqi army and 
air force to work with the Axis. 

When war broke out the Iraqi Government agreed to close the 
German Legation in Baghdad and intern aU German subjects; but 
when Italy entered the war Rashid Ali‚Äôs influence was strong enough 
to prevent the closure of the Italian Legation, through which he was 
in communication with Hitler. The young King had been killed in a 
motor accident, and the new one was only six years old, the country 
being ruled by the pro-British Regent, the Emir Abdulla Illah. 
Rashid Ali was eliminated as Prime Minister because the country 
did not want the war into which it was felt he was draggirig it. 
From that moment Rashid Ali with four military officers of high 
rank known as die Golden Square prepared for a coup d'etat. On 
April and 1941 the Regent fled from Baghdad to the R.A.F. station 
at Habbaniya whence he was flown to Basra and finally took sanctu- 
ary in H.M.S. Cockchafer. On April 3rd Rashid Ali became one 
more dictator as ‚ÄòChief of the National Defence Government‚Äô with- 
out a cabinet. How far Taha El Hashimi, the late Prime Minister, 
acted in collusion with Rashid Ali is not certain. In any event the 
prospect was ugly at a moment when British and Imperial troops 
were fully occupied in Cyrenaica and Greece. The vital oilfields and 
the vital line of our communications with India were now definitely 
threatened. 

To deal udth the emergency thus created the R.A.F. had a training

compames of the Iraqi levies of whom only the foxir Assyrian com-

air force had 6o bombers and fighters, all of superior performance 
to any of the R.A.F. aircraft except the Vincents, Gladiators and 
single Blenheim.

PLANS TO SAFEGUARD OILFIELDS 85 

evacuated in tlie event of ‚Äòtrouble in Iraq.‚Äô Lord Londonderry, the 
Secretary of State for Air, in his reply, pointed out that such a 
situation was not envisaged. The National Government was already 
ambling downhill, and, true to its motto Safety First, in blinkers. 

With the worsening of the international situation tentative plans 
were made for the reinforcement of Iraq from India in the case of 
emergency. The original plan was for a brigade group to secure the 
southern oilfields against local risings, this force to be employed 
under the Air Officer Commanding in Iraq but to be maintained by 
India. The General Staff in India did not consider such a force to be 
adequate even for so comparatively limited a commitment. With 
the outbreak of war an A.O,C.-in-Chief, Middle East, was appointed 
with operational control (to wliich administrative control was added 
later) up to tire frontiers and shores of India. 

At the end of December 1939 the Chiefs of Staff issued a directive 
on military policy in tlic Middle East which envisaged a much more 
ambitious plan to defend both the Iraqi and Persian oilfields with 
three divisions and mobile troops based on India. This scheme was 
known as Sabine. 

Early in 1940 active planning began between India and Mideast 
Commands on the first phase of Sabine known as Sybil. This involved 
the preparation of a division from India, the establishment of a base 
for a larger force at Basra, and the possibility of an opposed landing 
on the Persian side of the Shatt-el-Arab. At this time the preoccupa- 
tion behind the planning was an attack on the Anglo-Iranian 
oilfield by Soviet forces. Therefore the force from India was cither to 
go first to Basra and operate later from there or to secure Abadan 
and the Shatt-el-Arab first and thereafter operate towards Ahwaz 
and beyond. The advance was to be determined by the political and 
military situation. It was understood that later on the forces from 
India up to a total of three divisions would be based on Basra and 
would operate in a presumably friendly Iraq in conjunction with 
air forces to the north of Baghdad. 

It must be borne in mind that all these plans were prepared before 
the collapse of France and all the changes which that calamity 
. entailed including the increasingly unfriendly attitude of both Iraq 
and Persia. The Commander-in-Chief, India^ did not feel that the 
part assigned to India in Sabine was either clearly enough defined or 
practically enough conceived. He made several criticisms, one of the 
most mgent being that every European power would be solely 
concerned to deny the use of the Anglo-Iranian oilfields to us

because without shipping in the Persian Gulf it could make no

He further pointed out tliat although India was to be responsible for 
organising, despatching and maintaining the force its operations 
were to be controlled by Mideast which created dangerous oppor-

When General Auchinleck became Gommandcr-in-Ghief, India, 
in February 1941 he caused an appreciation which had been drawn 
up by the General Staff for General Cassels in July 1940 to be 
reAused in accordance with the latest developments of the situation 
and incorporated in a memorandum which was sent on February 
2ist 1941 to General Wavcll in Egypt and to General Dill, the Chief 
of the Imperial General Staff. 

From that appreciation the ultimate conclusion emerged that 
detailed plans were at once required as follows: 

(i) A plan for the initial occupation of Basra and Its vicinity on 
the assumption that the landing might be opposed both by Iraq 
and Persia with the aid of enemy forces whether German or 
Russian, 

(ii) A plan for the early reinforcement of the leading echelon 
and for the establishment of a base at Basra. 

(iii) After the occupation of Basra and its vicinity and the estab- 
lishment of a base at Basra alternative plans were required for 

(a) Further operations in Iraq. 

(b) Operations in the oilfields of south-west Persia, should 
they be necessary. 

It was stressed that these plans should be prepared by the force 
commander under the direction of G.-in-C., India. 

General Auchinleck emphasised to the G.I.G.S. that since India 
would be responsible for the maintenance and reinforcement of the 
force the task of occupying Basra should be delegated to G.H.Q,., 
India. He pointed out at the same time the necessity for a corps 
H.Q.., to carry out the detailed planning. In asking Wavell for 
agreement to bis proposals Auchinleck added that if it was decided 
that control , of operations should remain with Mideast he would 
gladly work under any directive thit General Wavell might issue.

planning should be done in India and that initial control of the

Lord Linlithgow felt as strongly about the position as Auchinleck . 
did, and on April 13th he sent Mr Amcry' a telegram with which the 
Secrctai'y of State for India was able to galvanise tlic Chiefs of 
Staff who immediately signalled permission for the Basra expedition 
to proceed. Cornwallis hoisted Rashid Ali with his own petard who 
with no time now to parley had to consent to the landing at 
Basra, There on April 18th the convoy arrived without incident and 
simultaneously the 1st K.O.R.R. landed at Shaiba aerodrome. 

The initial landing from the convoy was made by 200 men of the 
2/8th Gurkha Rifles^ and by that night the battalion had seized the 
whole dock area. Next day the rest of the 20th Indian Infantry 
Brigade consisting of the 2/7th Gurkha Rifles, the 3rd Sikh Regt and

Desert were hard pressed and the British forces in Greece w'crc being 
driven out of it to take advantage of the situation as soon as possible. 
Nevertheless, the pressure by India on the Chiefs of Staff to do what 
she could at once and risk disaster undoubtedly saved the real 
Ivliddle East and provided the first occasion during the Second 
World War when the Germans were anticipated by us; indeed, on 
reflection it is difficult to name another. 

On April 25th a secret treaty was signed in Baghdad by Rashid 
Ali and tlie Italian Minister by the terms of which Germany and 
Italy undertook to supply financial and military aid to the Iraqi 
Government for a war against the British Empire. Furthermore, 
Germany and Italy recognised a future union between Iraq and 
Syria under the King of Iraq in return for which they were to 
receive oil and pipeline concessions, the lease of three ports on the 
Syrian coast, and the right to construct air, naval and military 
bases on this leased territory. 

A day or two later Cornwallis notified Rashid Ali, who had 
already demanded that no more troops should disembark at Basra 
until the present force had passed across the frontier of Iraq, that 
three transports carrying ancillary troops of the first force were 
nearing Basra. Rashid Ali, no doubt emboldened by his secret 
treaty, refused permission for them to land. Cornwallis told him that 
the troops would disembark and that his government would be held 
responsible for any hostile action. India strongly supported the 
Ambassador‚Äôs firm attitude and urged London to agree to tlie use of 
force if necessary. On April 2gth the convoy reached Basra and the 
troops were disembarked without incident on the day that the last 
remnants of the British Expeditionary Force were being rescued 
from the mainland of Greece. 

Rashid Ali now decided to precipitate the issue, whether because 
he had received a definite promise of German air-support or 
because he hoped to force the Germans to provide it immediately 
is not certain. Ever since the disembarkation of the 20th Indian 
Brigade Iraqi troops which had been concentrated round Basra in 
early April had been steadily moved north. By the last day of the 
morith the river bunds had been cut and the countryside round Hab- 
baniya was made inaccessible to infantry by flooding, thus making 
any move by the 20th Brigade to relieve the garrison impossible. 
An Iraqi force of something over 6,000 with thirty 3.7 howitzers, 
4.5 howitzers and iS-poundcrs occupied the plateau commanding- 
the Habbaniya aerodrome. The Air Officer Commanding Habbaniya 
received an impudent message from the officer commanding the 



94 EASTERN EPIC 

Iraqi force to say that the Habbaniya plateau had been occupied 
for a training exercise and forbidding aircraft; and personnel to 
move out under penalty of shelling. 

The A.O.C. sent a suitably defiant reply and asked the Air 
Ministry for an immediate directive. He received it from the Prime 
Minister personally on May Day: 

If you have to strike, strike hard. Use all necessary force. 


The A.O.C. struck next morning by bombing the Iraqi land 
forces and within five minutes the first Iraqi sheik landed on the 
Habbaniya aerodrome.

Mention has already been made of the obsolescent aircraft on 
which the Air Officer Commanding had to rely. Of these only 56

in-G., Mideast on April 14th had promised a small reinforcement in

SIX Gladiators escorted by one Wellington. Three more time-expired 
Gladiators arrived in time for the battle and almost as soon as it had 
started further reinforcements came. 

To fly the obsolescent aircraft of No. 4 Special Flying Training 
School at Habbaniya A.O.G, Iraq had 35 pilots, of whom the greater 
number were instructors who had done nothing but circuits and 
landing since their original training some years before. Of the rest a 
few were pilots who had been returned from squadrons as unsuitable 
lot operational flying, others from the headquarters staff had done 
hardly any flying for several years, and tivo or three were pilots who 
after doing an excessive amount of operational flying had been sent 
to Habbaniya for rest. There were tivo observers and two air 
gunners. What those 35 pilots achieved wth the ancient craft and 
what their pupils achieved with the bombs was a display of courage 
and skill which the present chronicler can only salute with awe as 
he passes on.

For four days the air battle against superior numbers continued, 
the aerodrome under shell fire all the while. On the fifth day Colonel 
Ouvry Roberts,^ the G.S.O.I. of the lotli Indian Division who had 
been flo^vn in to take brilliant command of the ground troops, 
ordered a sortie. On May 6tli the King‚Äôs Osvn supported by the 
Assyrian companies of tire Iraqi levies, some armoured cars, and 
two 4.5 howitzers, survivors of the First World War which had been 
decorating the entrance to the officers‚Äô mess and had been put in 
order by some British gunners, reached tire plateau to find the 
enemy still there but badly shaken and waiting for reinforcements. 
He was badly shaken by those two old howitzers which he supposed 
to have reached Habbaniya from Basra. After some hard fighting 
the Iraqis quitted the plateau before their relief arrived, and it was 
at once occupied by tlie King‚Äôs Own. Then news came that large 
enemy reinforcements with guns and armoured cars were moving 
toward the plateau from Falluja. The advancing and retreating 
forces met on the road about five miles east of Habbaniya just as 
every available aircraft arrived to attack tlie advancing column. 
When the bombs fell on tire first vehicles the rest instead of dis- 
persing closed up and stopped head to tail. The attack lasted nearly 
two hours and the road was a sheet of flame with exploding ammuni- 
tion and burning cars. That day 408 prisoners were taken by the 
King‚Äôs Own and the casualties of the enemy were over a thousand. 
The Assyrian levies fought splendidly. 

Next morning on May 7th when the armoured car reconnoitred 
the plateau the enemy had departed leaving belrind him a quantity 
of arms, ammunition and armoured cars badly needed for the defence 
of the camp. 

\Vhile the battle of Habbaniya was in progress a battle of another 
kind was going on at top level. India strongly opposed the idea of 
negotiation rvith Rashid Ali which would be considered a sign of 
weakness and likely to damage our prestige throughout the East. 
Auchinleck could hardly agree to Wavell‚Äôs suggestion that the troops 
at Basra should be moved to Palestine while we parleyed rvith 
Rashid Ah. The maintenance of a strong Basra base had been the 
first object of the despatch of troops from India. 

Wavell, on the other hand, considered that the reply of the Chiefs 
of Smff to his suggestions had failed to face the awkward facts. He 
felt it was his duty to warn them in ‚Äòthe gravest possible terms‚Äô that 
the prolongation of the fighting in Iraq would endanger the defence 
of Egypt and Palestine. The political repercussions would be

By this time the British colony in Baghdad had taken refuge in the

On the pressure of the Chiefs of Staff Wavell assumed command 
of land operations in northern Iraq from noon of May 5th, and of 
those in southern Iraq on May 9th. 

Auchinleck had been hammering away at the C.I.G.S. He did not 
believe that either in London or in Cairo was there a clear view of 
the situation. He argued that if Alexandria and the Canal were 
closed to us by enemy action the loss of Egypt would not be a major 
disaster, though the importance of continuing to hold it could not be 
minimised. Yet even if Egypt were lost we should still be able to hold 
the Sudan and deny the use of the Red Sea to the enemy. If Turkey 
was not to subside into passivity under a German advance it was 
essential to deny Syria, Palestine and Iraq to the enemy, and as this 
might soon become the primary strategic object in this theatre the 
development of Basra as a base for lines of communication was an 
urgent necessity. At present only India could produce the troops 
required to occupy Iraq, and, now came the sting, Indian troops 
could not perform the task unless they were provided with the modem 
weapons and aircraft that India was unable to supply. This argu- 
ment was backed up by a formal offer by India that in view of the 
‚Äògrave situation in Iraq,‚Äô if shipping could be made available, the 
Basra force would be brought up to five infantry brigades with 
ancillary troops by June lOth. These troops would lack anti-aircraft 
and anti-tank artillery and armoured vehicles, so that India would 
have to take serious risks to make them available. Nevertheless, the 
risks were worth while. The Chiefs of Staff accepted with gratitude 
tliis ‚Äòbold and generous offer,‚Äô and asked that the forces be prepared 
as a ‚Äòmatter of urgency.‚Äô

On May 8th General IVavcll tvas still unconvinced by General

Cornwallis could not be consulted over the course to be adopted, 
being out of communication by cypher. Auchinicek continued to press

the risks she was prepared to take could be justified only in support

controlling the situation by scndingaforce from Palestine had passed. 
IVe were firaaly established at Basra. The immediate policy should 
be to establish ourselves in force at Baghdad and other key points 
like Kirkuk and Mosul. The Iraqi air force and the Iraqi army had 
suffered a severe setback at Habbaniya, They were short of ammuni- 
tion, and bold action held every prospect of success. India would 
provide the troops. Indeed, it was only lack of equipment which 
prevented India‚Äôs offering more troops, but not for a passive and 
defensive attitude at Basra. 

The Viceroy was in accord with the Comraander-in-Ghief. He 
insisted that, however much we might choose to represent our 
position in Iraq as facilities granted by the treaty we must be 
prepared to contemplate effective occupation of Iraq for the rest of 
the war.

After the ignominious Iraqi retreat from the plateau the R.A.F, 
made concentrated raids on Iraqi aerodromes and landing grounds 
in the course of which they destroyed 1 3 aircraft and put another 22 
out of action. Those losses on top of previous raids on the Raschid 
aerodrome at Baghdad and the airfield at Ba‚Äôquba practically 
annihilated the Iraqi air force as a fighting unit. 

Then on May loth, three Heinkel 1 1 1‚Äôs arrived at Mosul followed 
two days later by 12 more Heinkels and 14 Messerschmitt iio‚Äôs. 
These German aircraft had reached Mosul by way of Syria where 
they had been given all facilities by the vitiated French. From 
that date onwards these new arrivals bombed and shot up the 
Habbaniya camp regularly. 

At this grave moment when the objective of the German para- 
chute troops mustering in Crete was still uncertain and when 
German personnel in Syria were awaiting their instructions a 
Heinkel arrived over Baghdad bearing von Blomberg, the com- 
mander of German air forces in the East and head of the German 
mission to Iraq. Rashid Ali and his nunisters were on the airfield to 
receive him; Iraqi troops and police were guarding it. One excitable 
soldier or policeman food his rifle to salute the circling Heinkel, 
and the bullet killed the son of Field-Marshal von Blomberg 
instantaneously. It might be rash to claim that this fantastic accident 
detemuned the bsue; but undoubtedly it did cause such confusion in 
the German plans that by the time it was cleared up the hour for a 
decisive German intervention had passed.

The rest of the Iraq story may be told briefly. The small mecha-

Known as Kingcol after its commander Brigadier Kingstone,' 
Kjngcol had arrived at the banks of the Euphrates from the shores

miles downstream from the cantonment, where the river was 750 
feet wide %vith a strong current. Bridging in the time available 
rvas out of the question. A ferry was made with a 1,500 feet wire 
rope to hold the raft. This involved floating that large coil of cable 
across the river, fixing the ends on both banks, holding it taut, and 
strengthening it against the strain of the ferryman‚Äôs hooh holding 
on against the current. Vehicles had to be loaded on rafts and helped-'

over other water obstacles before Falluja was reached. The task 
called for many hours of wading, towing, pushing and battling 
against the stream, and the Madras Sappers and Miners were always 
in the forefront of it. 

The first experimental trip over the ferry was made on the after-

On May 27th the noth Indian Brigade left Shaiba with orders to
