On June 22nd Hider invaded Russia. The pattern of German 

were the first troops to enter Baghdad in 1917. They made a famous charge against 
the Turkish position at the battle of Istubalat on April sand 1917 when all the 
officers and nearly all the sowars became casualties. In 1919 they had hard fighting 
in the Kurdish rebellion when without water and short of ammunition they resisted 
for three days a force of Kurdish tribesmen several thousand strong. The 13th 
D.C.O. Lancers was one of the first two Indian cavalry regiments chosen for 
mechanisation. Tire last mounted parade was held on April 9th 1938, their com- 
manding officer then being Lieut.-Golonel F. W. Messervy who displayed such 
prowess as a cavalry leader new style ‚Ä¢with Gazelle Force in Eritrea. It is worth 
setting on record that when Messervy tried to train his men for tank warfare, 
using red flags for tanks, he was forbidden to continue because he and his men 
would never be likely to meet tanks in the role designed for them by H.M. 
Government, should war come. The effect on the dashing Messervy himself was 
more like St Vitus‚Äôs dance than catalepsy. 

The old blue signal standard of the 1st Bombay Light Cavalry, the Kala Baba, 
was believed like the green fairy flag of the Macleods to bring victory in the field, 
and for many years after it was too frail for battle recruits held the fringe of it in 
their right hand when being sworn in until it became too frail even for that.

I N September 1936 a treaty was signed betivccn France and Syria 
by which the French mandate gave way to Syrian autonomy. 
Under the terms of this treaty France xvas entitled to maintain 
armed forces in Jcbcl cd Druzc and Latalda and two airfields. 
After the Franco-Gennan armistice in 1940 S&gt;Tia remained tvithin 
tlic orbit of Vichy, and after Rashid Ali‚Äôs coufi d'itat in Iraq the 
Germans decided to use the Syrian airfields. Early in May General 
Huntziger, tire Vichy Minister for War, infonned General Dentz, 
the French High Commissioner, tliat Admiral Darlan having 
conceded the use of the Syrian airfields he was not to oppose the 
landing of German aircraft. The first of these reached Syria on 
May 9th 1941, and a few days later others arriving at Mezzo and 
Palmyra went into action against Habbaniya as already related. In 
addition to the landing grounds the Vichy authorities allowed the 
Germans the use of tlte Syrian railways to send aviation petrol, arms 
and ammunition to Mosul. These passed drrough Turkey as French, 
being ostensibly sent to meet the threat of a mythical Kurdish revolt. 

On May 15th Mr Eden stated in the House of Commons tliat tire 
Syrian airfields were being used by the enemy and he warned the 
Vichy Government of the consequences. The Frencli affirmed that 
the S'jrian airfields had been tised by the Germans only in forced 
landings, but the strategic implication was menacing, not only in 
Iraq and the Russian oilfields but also to Palestine, Suez and Cyprus. 
The best that could be hoped from the Turk was that he would 
mot enter the war beside Germany. There was no likelihood that 
he would attempt to resist the movement of German troops and 
material with a view to occupying Syria in strength, and the only 
course for the British Government was to invade Syria first. Prepara- 
tions for this were ;started in die .middlc of May, and the invasion 
‚ñ†began on June 8th, with an advance from Palestine on Damascus 
-and Beirut by three lines. 

Tlte Vichy military forces were estimated at fi-om 40,000 to 50,000 
, men, the remnants of Weygand‚Äôs army, mosdy well-trained and

But what of the defenders of Mezze House whose valour had made 
the capture of Damascus a not very difficult operation for others? 

All through the night of June tglaoth they were being hard 
pressed; the tired sepoys and riflemen at the loopholes and the 
breaches always had to fire with careful aim because not a roimd 
of the fast-failing ammunition could be wasted. The enemy took 
advantage of this to get within grenade distance of the house, and 
one grenade burst in a tall window of the salon on tlie left in which 
a conference was being held. The morning wore on. The relieving 
coliimn could be heard fighting its way up past the airfield. 

Then at 1.30 p.m. the enemy brought up their 75‚Äôs and began to 
shell the house at point blank range. A part of the roof coUapsed and 
while ffie wounded were being rescued from the debris the enemy 
scaled the walls. They were driven back; it was for the last time. The 
decision w‚Äôas taken to ask for a truce to evacuate the wounded, for al- 
though by now ammunition was exhausted and the garrison had been 
rvithout food for more than 50 hours it was hoped to delay surrender 
xmtil Burke‚Äôs relieving column could reach them. However, the 
enemy on seeing the white flag supposed that the garrison was 
surrendering and rushed the gate. What was left of a company of 
the Rajputana Rifles tried to bayonet their way out, but they were 
overpowered. 

When Burke‚Äôs column which had been reinforced by one 
Australian battalion recaptured Mezze at 7 p.m that evening Mezze 
House was empty except of the dead. 

For 36 hours the enemy continued to shell Mezze from the high 
ground to the W‚Äôest, but eventually he was pushed back towards 
Dimas on the road to Beirut.

T he fall of Damascus was far from being the end of this struggle 
so wantonly provoked by the Vichy French. On June 2ist they 
still held four-fiflfe of Syria including the ports of Beirut and Tripoli 
and the entire railway line north of Damascus. The thrust from 
Palestine was but one prong of the trident. Habforce was the prong 
of the second thrust at Palmyra. The third and decisive thrust was 
made by the Indian troops in Iraq. The loth Indian Division 
commanded by Major-General Slim consisted of Weld‚Äôs 21st 
Brigade and Mountain‚Äôs 25th Brigade with the 2/8th Gurkha 
Rifles from the 20th Brigade. Slim‚Äôs main object was to capture 
Aleppo and thereby threaten the rear of Vichy‚Äôs forces in Beirut, 
which from the River Damour were holding up the advance of the 
Australians. Powell‚Äôs 20th Brigade less 2/8th Gurkha Rifles but 
with the ist Frontier Force Regt and 5th Frontier Force Rifles from 
Gracey‚Äôs 1 7th Brigade of the 8th Indian Division was to capture all 
territory in the north-east of Syria including the railway. 

The area in which these operations were to be carried out was 
rolling desert through which the Euphrates flowed from the north- 
west. The railway northward from Damascus branched at Aleppo, 
one branch running west to Anatolia, the other east along the 
Turkish frontier into Turkey, back into Syria and finally joining 
the Baghdad railway at Mosul. The only sea-port in this area was 
Latakia, of litde importance even to smokers nowadays; but the oil 
pipeline from Haditha to Tripoli traversed this area, and that was 
of great importance. 

The 20th Indian Brigade wth the tivo battalions from the 17th 
Brigade was to operate independently of the loth Division and was 
to be under H.Q,. British Troops in Iraq for the period of operations. 

Before the advance began Haditha was stocked with 15 days‚Äô 
supplies and with enough petrol for two lorry-borne infantry 
brigade groups, one armoured car regiment and one squadron of the 
R.A.F. Shortage of transport made the first forward moves difficult. 
There were one and a half general purposes transport companies

available. Neither H.Q,. Palestine and Transjordan nor the R.A.F. 
in Iraq could help. The second line transport of all but one brigade 
in Iraq was called upon and efforts ivere made to hire civilian 
transport. 

The first move forward was made from Haditha on June 27th by 
two compam'es of the 2 /4th Gurkha Rifles svith a squadron of the 
,13 th Lancers, and next day Abu Kemal was oaptured without 
opposition apparently. By June 30th the rest of the 2/4th GurlAa

H.Q.. of the 10th Division handed over the command of the column 
to G.O.C, Palestine. ' 

On July 1st the 2/ioth Gurkha Rifles moved forward at da^vn 
along the river route. The road was bad and in many places im- 
passable off it. Vichy aircraft bombed the column, causing casualties 
to men and vehicles. Then a heavy dust storm slowed progress. 
However, by 2.30 p.m. the column was nine miles from Deir ez Zor, 
the chief town of east Syria, with two bridges across tlie Euphrates. 

The advance of the 4th Frontier Force Rifles (Wilde‚Äôs) progressed 
satisfactorily, but wireless contact was lost with tlie brigade com- 
mander who was vrith the a/ioth Gurkha Rifles, and on top of that 
for the same reason the whereabouts of the 13 th Lancers could not be 
ascertained. Brigadier IVeld therefore stopped the advance of the 
2/ioth Gurkha Rifles in order not to upset the original plan -of 
enveloping the enemy. Contact was re-established late that night, 
and the 4th Frontier Force Rifles were ordered to move to Mayadin 
near the river because they were short of water and also the escarp- 
ment south-west of Deir ez Zor made it impossible for their vehicles 
to get round to the north of the to%vn. This return to Mayadin by the 
Frontier Force Rifles ^and also foe 13th Lancers used up more petrol 
than was safe, and the intended wide movement to bring this 
column round to the enemy‚Äôs rear would have left it almost dry 
vvhen it arrived, which if French resistance were at all tough , might 
mran immobilisation when in contact with the enemy. .The 
brigade commander therefore ordered the 4th Frontier Force 
Rfles to get astride of the Palmyra road on the flank instead of die 
Raqqa-Aleppo roadin the rear ofDeir ez Zor. This change was not 
approved by Slim who had gone forward to brigade headquarters on 
July and. Hcdecid^thattheriric of the petrol‚Äôs running short was a 
better one than losing the chance of a complete surprise by holding 
the enemy on the Palm&gt;Ta road approaches on the alert. The final 
plan for operations on July 3/4* was for the 2/ioth Gurkha Rifles 
supported by all the field artillery except one troop to move direct on

Beir ez Zor during the night and be ready to attack at 9 a.m. when 
the enveloping movement ought to be having an effect; for the, 
4th Frontier Force Rifles, with one troop of artillery and the 13th 
Lancers (less one squadron) at 4.15 a.m. on July 4th to move wide 
round the enemy‚Äôs southern flank, gain the Aleppo road and advance 
on Deir ez Zor from the nortli; for one squadron of the 13th Lancers 
to demonstrate on the plain south-west of the town; and for the 
2/4th Gurkhas Rifles to be in brigade reserve. 

Slim was justified in taking the risk he elected to take; it was a 
foretaste of that much wider and much longer sweep of 400 miles to 
the Irrawaddy which he would make nearly four years later when 
his rope uncoiled and began to strangle the Japanese in Burma. 

At first the Vichy 75‚Äôs firing from concrete emplacements south 
and west of Deir ez Zor and outranging our 1 8-pounders made the 
move forward by the 2 / loth Gurkha Rifles none too easy;'fortunateIy 
the enemy‚Äôs fire was directed on the road instead of on the troops 
moving between tlie road and the river,, so that casualties were 
light. Meanwhile, the flanking column left Mayadin at 4.15 a.m. on 
July 3rd, crossing the Palmyra road about 20 miles from Deir ez 
Zor. The squadron of igth Lancers quickly drove off eight armoured 
cars that threatened opposition. The column reached the Aleppo 
road by 10.30 a.m. and its arrival from the north, completely 
surprised the enemy, who offered no opposition until the barracks 
on the outskirts of the town were reached. The cars, pushed on down 
the main street and cut off a number of vehicles trying to escape 
across the Euphrates bridge leading to the Souar-Hassetche road, 
the only escape route not covered by the encircling movement. An 
attempt was made by the enemy to guard the demolition of the 
north-east bridge, but the 4th Frontier Force Rifles, rapidly cleared 
the houses on either side of snipers and seized the bridge intact. The 
2 /loth Gurkha Rifles who had worked up close to the enemy‚Äôs 
positions by 1 1 a.m. saw him abandon those positions in the dismay 
caused by the attack from the north and pressing enjoined up with 
the Frontier Force Rifles in the town. 

Only a hundred prisoners were taken because the bulk of the Syrian 
troops changed into civilian clothes and eitirer hid theinselves in the 
tow'n or cleared off to their villages. However, nine guns, five 
aircraft and 50 lorries were captured and a big haul of arms, 
ammunition and petrol was made. 

Our troops clearing the town had to put up with a heavy attack 
that morning by ten Vichy bombers escorted by seven fighters, and 
suffered considerable casualties in men and vehicles. It was 3.30 that

afternoon before the last opposition inside the town was finished and

On July 5th the 2/4th Gurkha Rifles with a squadron of the 13th 
Lancers and a troop of the 157th Field Regt took Raqqa without 
opposition. Here, too, they were heavily attacked from the air, and 
supply columns had to move by night. 

Meanwhile, the third move through the Bee du Canard province 
to seize the Mosul-Aleppo railway had begun. The Vichy command 
under pressure had started to withdraw their forces through Tel 
Abiad toward Djerablous on the Turkish frontier. In order to 
intercept this movement the 2/4th Gurkha Rifles and a squadron of 
the 13th Lancers were ordered to move from Raqqa to Tel Abiad, 
and garrison duties in Raqqa were taken over by a company of the 
4th Frontier Force Rifles, but on reaching Tel Abiad they found 
that the enemy had already passed through. The Lancers with a 
platoon of the Gurkhas set out in pursuit and attacked the enemy 
with machine-gun fire as his rearguard was crossing the Euphrates 
at Djerablous. Air attacks on the troops in Tel Abiad were frequent. 
They were frequent, too, on the little garrison occupying Raqqa, 
which was also heavily shelled on July gth. That night the garrison 
was attacked by a large band of Arab tribesmen with automatic 
weapons and a certain amount of mechanical transport. These 
Arabs were driven off by the armoured cars of the 13th Lancers and 
tivo bayonet charges by the Frontier Force Rifles.

Zor from the south might well have failed completely in view of the 
Vichy superiority in the air. As it was he captured all but two of the 
enemy‚Äôs guns&gt; and most of his ammunition and transport. Moreover^ 
he was able to inspire the spirit of taking risks in his garrison com- 
manders. That little column of the 1 3th Lancers with a platoon of the 
2 /4th Gurkha Rifles which covered 200 miles from Deir ez Zor to 
drive the enemy across the Euphrates and Djerablous was the last 
straw which broke his back and, with the vision of Aleppo lost, 
made him ask for terms. 

The failure of the R.A.F. to provide more than a few fighters 
which were eitlier shot down or unable to operate against aircraft 
at once more numerous and more modern was less serious than it 
might have been because the Vichy French foolishly concentrated 
their air attacks upon the forward troops. If they had concentrated 
upon the even more vulnerable administrative organisation in the 
rear there might have been a different story to tell about that 
campaign in north-east Syria. 

It is an ungracious task for tlie military chronicler to cast reflec- 
tions upon the R.A.F., but tite fact remains that the R.A.F.' did 
accept responsibility in Iraq, in Burma and most gravely of all in 
Malaya which it was unable to sustain. We forget the muddles and 
maladministration in the Crimea and remember the. Charge of the 
Light Brigade at Balaclava. Our future as a nation demands that 
the Air Ministry should not build its reputation on heroic feats in 
the air but more solidly upon a co-operation with the service too 
often called upon in the Second World War to imperil the military 
situation by trying to defend aerodromes occupying indefensible 
sites and by counting on help from tlie air which in the hour of need 
was wanting. 

Tt is unfair and unwise,‚Äô wrote Slim, ‚Äòto push forward mecha- 
nised columns without adequate air support. Extreme dispersion 
(200 yards between vehicles) was forced on units by the scale of air 
attack. This rendered protection against ground attack as was shown 
in the night affair at Raqqa most difficult. Dispersion was in fact 
overdone. Dispersion in a unit area need not be more than too yards 
between vehicles, but it is advisable when tactically possible to have 
500 to 1,000 yards between unit areas. If closer, an attack on one 
unit has an adverse moral effect on its neighbours.‚Äô 

Slim went on to stress tlie importance of giving every armoured 
car an, anti-tank weapon. It was not enough to have one anti-tank 
rifle to a section. The 13th Lancers were operating wth wretchedly 
armed Chcvrolcts the engines of which were five years old and the

August-October, 1941. Siimlion in Persia‚Äî Anglo-Soviet decision to

H ITLER‚ÄôS attack on the Soviets dissipated the Indian High 
Command‚Äôs recurrent nightmare over many years of Russians 
on the North-West Frontier, but it made the German menace to the 
Middle East even more possible as a decisive strategic stroke to 
influence the whole course of the war. The situation had been saved 
in Iraq chiefly, it can be asserted, owing to the obstinacy with which 
the Viceroy and Auchinleck had refused to be diverted from the 
urgent necessity of establishing Basra as a base. If that had not been 
done when it was by one of the superlative achievements of admini- 
strative units history can record, not merely would Iraq have been 
exploited by the enemy, but it may be doubted whether Syria could 
have been saved in time. The signature of that ten years‚Äô Treaty of 
Friendship between Germany and Turkey four days before Hitler 
turned on Russia was a clear indication of what the Nazi plan was. 
Those three words of Euripides "Afyqs oruyet ixehXovras The God of 
War abhors procrastinators uncomfortably nearer to providing yet 
another example of their truth in April 1941, and it was Linlithgow 
and Auchinleck who won a grim smile of approval from Ares. 

However, beyond Iraq was Persia, and with at best a flaccid 
Turkey the German threat to Persian and to Russian oil was grave 
enough. It was estimated that nearly 3,000 Germans were already 
in Persia that July. Technicians and commercial agents held key 
positions in railways, ports, factories, posts, telegraphs and railway 
stations. They controlled stores of arms, ammunition and explosivesi 
and they had just been reinforced by a huge German mission from 
Ankara. The atmosphere of Persia was evident from the fact that 
Rashid Ali and several of his supporters had taken sanctuary in 
Tehran when they fled from Baghdad. His Majesty‚Äôs Government 
pointed out to Riza Shah‚Äôs Government what an unfavourable 
impression was being created by this infiltration and asked for the 
great majority of the Germans to be removed. The Persian Govern- 
ment made excuses, and was obviously playing for time. No doubt 
Hitier‚Äôs invasion of Russia followed by that German sweep down

German hold over the Persian imagination. It was clear that the

action as the Axis.

These two battalions of the 24th Brigade embarked in naval craft 
after dark at the R.A.F. wharf in Basra and landed at Abadan at 
dawn of August 25th. Some of the boats ran aground on the way 
down the river with the result that the second wave of troops got 
ashore first. The landing was a complete surprise to the Persians, 
most of whom were asleep in their barracks. When wakened by the 
noise of the naval guns a' large number of the garrison boarded 
lorries and escaped across the Bahamanshir Creek, but well-placed 
machine-gun posts along the wharves put up a strong resistance, and 
Lieut.-Colonel Ridley, the commander of the Qnd Rajputana Rifles, 
‚ñ†was wounded. A certain amount of indiscriminate shooting followed, 
in the course of which three British employees of the Anglo-Iranian 
Oil Company were killed and several wounded. These ‚ñ†^vere moving 
to their allotted positions in the refinery on hearing the alarm 
siren being blown, and some of them being in the blue uniform 
worn by the Company‚Äôs janitors the Rajputana Rifles supposed 
them to be soldiers. Further along the river front where the ist 
Kumaon Rifles was mo'ving on the refinery through the fringing 
groves of date-palms a few more employees were wounded. 

Apart from these unfortunate incidents the capture of tlie refinery 
was carried out much more quickly and with much fewer casualties 
than seemed probable when the troops set out. The aerodrome was 
soon taken, but when the column moved against the town there 
was a good deal of street-fighting and it was difficult to dislodge the 
Persian defenders without damaging the precious refinery; they were 
not driven out of the buildings until evening. It was then too late to 
clear up the town, and a cordon was formed round the refinery, the 
troops bivouacking for the night. Next day the whole of Abadan was 
cleared up. Our casualties were two British officers, one Indian 
officer and eight Indian other ranks killed and one British officer 
and 1 1 Indian other ranks wounded. 

Force of 1856 and in the storming of Reshire Captain J. A. Wood won the first 
Victoria Cross ever won in an Indian unit. The standard captured that day is still 
preserved by the battalion. In Kut the battalion held the Woolpress ‚ñ†village out- 
posts through the ao weeks of the siege, and after the surrender a new and 
Rajputana Rifles was formed which went to South Persia. Now here they, were in 
South Persia for the third time.

While Abadan and Ahwaz were being secured other operations in

British and Indian women and children from the main fields at 
Masjid-i-Suleiman to safety there. Three of the Valentines tried to 
land at the same moment, but although two of them crashed there 
were fortunately no casualties. Moreover, the situation was com- 
pletely tranquil and there was no need to move the women and 
children.

The country for which we were making ourselves responsible for 
order included Persian Kurdistan where the Km-ds, having secured 
some arms and ammunition from Persian deserters, decided that the 
British invasion was a good opportunity to declare their national 
aspirations and encourage the Kurds in Iraq and Turkey to do like- 
wise. The Persians hoped that the British would assume responsi- 
bility for the Kurdish rebellion: the British preoccupied with the 
task of getting rid of the Germans in the Middle East refused to be 
dragged into the business and left it to the Persians. However, 
finally, active patrolling had to be resumed to give moral support to 
the Persian commander in Kermanshah, while at the same time 
remaining on friendly terms with the Kurds. 

In Tehran itself matters were by no means satisfactory. The new 
Prime Minister Farouki produced a policy which was all right on 
paper, but it remained to be seen if it was to be sincerely imple- 
mented. It was agreed tiiat the German Minister and his staff 
should leave Tehran and that the German, Italian, Hungarian and 
Rumanian Legations should be closed; it was further agreed that all 
Germans still at liberty should be handed over to the British and 
Soviet authorities. The Legations were closed, but the Germans 
were not handed over. On September loth a British Note was 
presented demanding their surrender within 48 hours. Twenty-four 
hours after the ultimatum expired two trains left Tehran to hand 
over a third of the Germans known to be in Persia. 

At last after some shilly-shally it was decided by the War Office 
that a joint advance by British and Soviet troops should be made on 
Tehran as soon as the Russian commander could make his arrange- 
ments. Brigadier Boucher,^ tire B.G.S., flew to Tabriz to confer with 
the Russian commander who agreed that a simultaneous entry into 
Tehran should be made on September 1 7th, which was carried out. 
A day before this entry Riza Shah abdicated and left the capital. 
The Majliss then met and elected the Crown Prince Mohammed 
Riza Pahlevi to the vacant throne. Riza Shah was sent to Mauritius 
by the British Government. It was believed that the ex-Mufti of 
Jerusalem managed to escape to Rome after hiding in tlie Japanese 
Legation. German agents were at work for a long time, but they 
were gradually eliminated, and by October 17th it was considered 
safe to withdraw from Tehran after a joint parade by British and 
Soviet troops. 

‚Ä¢ On the whole the attitude of the population in southern and 
western Persia was not unfriendly to our troops; but economic

THE BATTLE OF SOLLUM 141 

A description of the escarpment which cannot be bettered is here 
included;^ 

In Eastern Cyrenaica the plateau drops to sea level at the coast 
itself, ‚Äò'and continues to do so until the tiny fishing village of 
Solium is reached. From there the escarpment, marking the edge 
of the plateau, sweeps inland, first south and then south-east until 
it dies away in broken ground round the old Roman cistern at 
Sofafi. Between the escarpment and the shore is an undulating 
area, a veritable hell of dust when the ‚ÄòKhamseen‚Äô wind blows, 
and reduced to quagmire when rain falls. There are but few 
passes for vehicles up to the plateau from the plain, the main ones 
being at Solium, Halfaya and Halfway House. When Sofafi is 
reached the scarp becomes less steep and there are numerous 
places where lorries can make their way to the top. 

This escarpment is steep bare rock, but the rim of the plateau is 
not like the edge of a cliff. Many gullies cut their way inland so 
that the top of the ridge weaves in and out endlessly. From below 
the whole presents the appearance of a steep, rugged range of 
hills, all of which are the same height. On the plateau the ground is 
comparatively smooth, roiling slightly and very gently. It is 
passable to vehicles everywhere until, about one hundred miles 
away to the south, the ground drops steeply again to the Siwa 
Depression. 

The estimated enemy forces in the forward area Bardia-Capuzzo- 
Sollum were 5,700 Germans with 100 medium tanks, 50 armoured 
cars, 20 field guns and 70 anti-tank guns, and 7,500 Italians with 
about 50 guns and 20 anti-tank guns. In the Tobruk-El Adem area 
there were 1 1,000 Germans with -120 medium tanks, 70 light tanks, 
36 field guns and 80 anti-tank guns, and 16,000 Italians with 120 
field guns, 32 anti-tank guns and a few tanks. 

The force Wavell had to deal with this formidable opposition was 
considerably inferior in every branch and in his own words ‚Äòthe pace 
and radius of the two armoured brigades was so widely different that 
It would obviously be extremely difficult.‚Äô The air forces to support 
his attack had not been available for preparatory air action and the 
reconnaissance of the enemy positions had been ‚Äòscanty and dis- 
appointing‚Äô owing to shortness of equipment and what equipment 
there was being faulty. The infantry was Savory‚Äôs t ith Indian 
Brigade (Briggs‚Äô yih Brigade was immobilised at Baqqush because its 
vehicles had been distributed to other formations) and the 22nd 
Guards Brigade under the command of the 4th Indian Division. 
The two infantry brigades and the two armoured brigades were

Valour was not enough. Wellesley‚Äôs ‚ñ† and the Mahrattas were 
baffled by the commanding positions the enemy held on the escarp- 
ment. The six I tanks ran on an uncharted minefield at the foot of 
the pass and four of them were knocked out 500 yards from tlie 
enemy. The Bengal Sappers and Miners went forward and under 
fire removed the mines, enabling the tanks to be rescued in the dark. 

In the small hours of that night the Scots Guards stormed into 
Musaid and at dawn pressed on in lorries to the heights.above Solium 
which they captured with a bag of over 200 prisoners. However, the 
enemy was bringing up about a hundred tanks, half of them heavy 
Mark III and Mark IV types, and it was clear tliat trouble was' on 
the way unless the nth Brigade could force the Halfaya Pass before 
the enemy could capture the passes down the escarpment east of 
Halfaya and thus cut off the lines of retreat. 

So on the morning of June i6th the nth Brigade tried again, the 
three battalions making desperate efforts to move forward but 
finding every approach covered by heavy and accurate enemy fire. 
At dusk the guns of the 25th Field Regt concentrated on two knolls 
that commanded tlie head of the pass. 

The Rajputana Rifles managed to cross the spur to the edge of the ‚ñ† 
Wadi Halfaya, but came under fierce fire from the other side of the 
gully. Their commanding officer, Lieut.-Colonel P, R. H, Skrine 
was killed and over 40 of his brave riflemen with him. Yet they 
pressed on for another 500 yards before they were held with only 
another 500 yards before them to the head of the pass. Down below 
the Mahrattas reached tlie bottom of tlie wadi, but there they too 
were held by the enemy fire. The nth Brigade spent that night 
on the cliffs of the gully waiting to win the head of the pass on 
the morrow. The stars were against the Red Eagles in that June. 
Away over in Syria the Royal Fusiliers that very day had been 
forced to surrender at Quneitra, and the rest of the 5tli Brigade was 
on the brink of the Mezze disaster. ‚ñ†

and fell side by side to maintain a tradition of martial fellowship

In spite of the fact that Rommel was prepared for our attack and 
able to concentrate the whole of his armour in the forward area 
unknown to the British Command for lack of air reconnaissance 
owing to the scarcity of trained pilots. Solium was for him a Pyrrhic 
victory. He was unable either to make any attempt to capture 
Tobruk or any move against the Egyptian frontier. Spellbound by 
German grand slams when they hold all the cards, we are inclined 
to forget how well British soldiers play bad hands. The battle of 
Solium was not one of the major actions of the war, but it added a 
little more glory to the glory of the Guards and to the glory of the 
4th Indian Division. 

The morale of the troops remained high and they had always 
well justified confidence that vwth anything like material equality, 
they were more than a match for any German troops. 

Thus wrote Wavell in his last despatch as Gommander-in-Ghief, 
Middle East after conducting six major campaigns between February 
7th and July 14th 1941, never less than three at one time and during 
the month of May five. Wavell was something more than a grea 
general: he was also a moral force.

These are heart-warming tributes from veterans; Anzac demands

During the lull, if the feverish battle to build up supplies against 
time can be called a lull, Briggs‚Äô 7th Indian Infantry Brigade moved 
out into the Libyan desert to garrison Siwa and Jarabub. The oases 
of Siwa, Jarabub and Jalo form a great scalene triangle of which 
Jarabub is the north-westerly apex about 60 miles from Siwa from 
which Jalo lies over 240 mUes due west. Siwa and Jarabub are the 
western pordon of the Great Qatara depression the emstence of 
which would one day fortify the flank of the El Alamein position. 
The oasis of Siwa was once the seat of the oracle of the ram-homed 
Jupiter Ammon whom Hercules and Alexander and such brave men 
as these consulted. The oasis of Jarabub contains a little Senussi 
university and the tomb of Mohammed Bir Senussi, founder of the 
sect which gave us so much trouble in the First World War and the 
Italians in the Second. 

The fort of Jarabub was held by a garrison of a thousand Italian 
and some Libyan troops when Wavell launched that dazzling 
campaign in December 1940. The garrison was cut off and it was 
captured without much difficulty by an Australian force on March 
2ist i94i.Jalo remained in enemy hands. The Germans and Italians 
made no attempt to recapture the oases after their successful counter- 
offensive, but soon after the 4th Sikh Regt entered into possession 
of Fort Jarabub it was bombed by the Regia Aeronautica and 
suffered more than 30 casualties. There were many raids after this 
from a low level, but none was successful after the first, although the 
shrine of Mohammed Bir Senussi was damaged. The inhabitants

These oases like all others were plagued by myriads of flies. The

The adventures of the a 9th Brigade will be told in due course. 
Meanwhile, we must turn for a while to the general situation in 
North Africa, to the inheritance of which General Sir Claude 
Auchinleck had succeeded General Sir Archibald Wavell in July. 
The need of taking the offensive in Cyrenaica was considered in the 
United Kingdom urgent. The rapid German advance in Russia 
suggested that the road to the Caucasus would soon be open, and 
that by the spring of 194Q the enemy might be in a position to cow 
Turkey and strike at Iraq and Persia from the north. That being so 
it seemed imperative to dispose of the menace to Egypt before trying 
to meet the menace from the north and north-east. 

This was the argument that Wavell had used in the spring; at 
that date Auchinleck had committed himself to the opinion that the 
loss of Egypt would be less grave to tire future of the British Empire 
ultimately than the threatened loss of Iraq with the loss of Persia as a 
corollary. Wavell had fully recognised that danger, but faced as he 
was -with the immediacy of the German threat on his western front, 
in the Balkans, and possibly in Syria he was not prepared to imperil 
the situation by weakening his position in North Africa, already too 
much weakened by the loss of men and material diverted to Greece. 
He was compelled to gamble on the inability of the Germans to 
launch a major offensive through Anatolia into Iraq for some time 
to come. Fortunately India was able to assume a considerable 
responsibility and fortunately Hitler was obsessed by his planned 
invasion of Russia. 

Now Auchinleck was faced with the immediate Axis threat to 
Egypt and he in turn was compelled to gamble. Iraq and Persia 
were now Wavell‚Äôs responsibility; but Auchinleck had to take the. 
risk of denuding Syria, Palestine and Cyprus of transport and aircraft 
in order to equip the Eighth Army which was bom after he came 
back to Africa from his talks in August wth the Prime Minister, the 
War Cabinet and the Defence Committee in London. He accepted 



150 EASTERN EPIC' 

the possibility of launching by November ist an offensive deigned 
to occupy the whole of Libya and if fortune was kind to drive the 
enemy out of Tripolitania. At the same time he insisted that the date 
of sudi an offensive must depend on the arrival of the troops and 
equipment he considered necessary for the success of such an 
offensive. In the end the date of the offensive was postponed until 
November 15th because the 22nd Armoured Brigade did not reach 
Egypt until October 14th, a month after it was expected. A furtlier 
three days‚Äô postponement was caused by the late arrival of the 
vehicles of the ist South African Division and therefore their lack of 
training in the mobile part planned for them in the operation. In 
tlie end the offensive was launched ivith one and a half armoured 
divisions and one brigade of I tanks, although Auchinleck‚Äôs original 
estimate for the armoured forces required had been three armoured 
divisions. Moreover, the armoured forces available were not all 
fully trained for desert warfare. It svill be borne in mind that these 
reinforcements arrived after a 12,000 miles voyage round the Cape. 
When British cricket teams visit Australia they are given a certain 
amount of practice against less pow'erfui teams before their first test 
match. 

‚ÄòWe were working to very close margins as regards equipment and 
training,‚Äô Auchinleck wrote in fais despatch, ‚ÄòThe same conditions 
applied to the building up of supplies and the construction of pipe- 
lines and railways. The essential preparations were bcirely complete 
when the campaign was launched, and the standard of training of 
many of the troops engaged left much to be desired. This was due to 
no fault of their otvn, but solely to lack of time and shortage of 
equipment.‚Äô 

For some time before the start of the offensive the Axis forces in 
Libya had been concentrated in north-east Cyrenaica for an attempt 
to settle once and for all wth Tobruk. There were the 15th and 21st 
Panzer Divisions, the goth German Light Division, five Italian 
infantry divisions, two Italian motorised divisions and one Italian 
armoured division. The whole of this army except the 6ofh Sabrata 
Division had been brought across the Mediterranean beuveen 
March and May when the Royal Navy was occupied in the Aegean. 
After May the Navy and tlic destroyed at least a third of 

their, supply cargoes. The fact that Rommel could not stage an 
offensive after the battle of Solium before November showed how 
Steadily and how thoroughly the destructive work had been done. 

ISbcn the British offensive knosvn as Cnuadrr started,‚Äô four Italian 
infantry divisions were concentrated rormd the perimeter of Tobruk,

The Eightli Army commanded by General Sir Alan Cunningham^ 
was organised for the offensive in two corps. XIII Corps under 
Licut.-Gencral Godwin-Austen- included the 4th Indian Division, 
the and New Zealand Division and the ist Army Tank Brigade. 
XXX Corps under Lieut.-GencralNorric¬Æ included the 7th Armoured 
Division, the 4th Armoured Brigade, the 1st South African Division

and destroy tlie enemy‚Äôs armour. That accomplished the Tobruk

Armoured Brigade and the Polish Brigade, was to sally out and in 
conjunction with XXX Corps to secure the ridges of Sidi Rezegh 
and El Duda, which would cut the enemy‚Äôs communications with 
the west. Simultaneously XIII Corps, whose first task was to prevent 
the enemy garrisons in Bardia and Halfaya and otlier frontier 
positions from moving east or south, was to move north and cut them 
off from the west, part of XIII Corps then moving west to help

For the first three days things went well, after the offensive started 
at dawn of November i8th, although not nearly so well as it was 
supposed they were going after the first reports 'had grossly exagger- 
ated enemy tank losses‚Äô in the words of General Aucliinleck. The 
Prime Minister naturally elated by the news from Africa, told tlie 
House of Commons on November 20th that ‚Äòall ranks of the British 
and Empire troops involved were animated by a long pent-up and 
ardent desire to engage the enemy whom they were now meeting for 
the first time at least equally well armed and equipped.‚Äô* 

This encouraging but terminologically not quite exact news was 
broadcast to the nation and the depressing reports following all too 
quickly undoubtedly lowered public morale which was to receive

Was the Eighth Army as well armed and equipped as the enemy? 
The answer is ‚ÄòNo.‚Äô The armoured brigades had bettvecn them 455 
tanlcs, of which 165 were of the light Stuart type soon to be classed 
not as a tank but as a reconnaissance vehicle: the other tanks were 
mostly Crusaders. Besides tliese the ist Army TankBrigade rvith XIII 
Corps had 120 Valentines and Matildas, and the 32nd Army Tank 
Brigade had 90 of these in Tobruk. One of IVavell‚Äôs problems had 
been the combination of Cruisers and I tanks in manoeuvre. ‚ÄòThe 
Cruiser tanks had a speed of 15-20 miles an hour and a radius of 
action of 80-100 miles, whereas the 1 tanks had a radius of action of 
only 40 miles and a speed of no more than about five miles an hour 
in acdon,‚Äô he had ivritten in his despatch.^ 

Against the 665 tanks of all types at the service of the Eighth Army 
the Axis had 505; but half of these were German Mark Ill‚Äôs and 
Mark IV‚Äôs both much superior in armament, armour and mechani- 
cal trustworthiness to any British tanks at that date, none of which 
had a gunheavier than the a-pounder, whereas the powerful German 
tanks had nothing lighter than a 4^poundcr and in the Mark IV‚Äôs a 
14-pounder. 

In other words the claim that the Eighth Army ivas as well armed 
and equipped as its opponents was to claim that a superior number 
oflight cruisers is equal in potency to an inferior number of battle- 
ships, which was a sanguine computation for a former First Lord 
of the Admiralty to reach. 

Add to this the lack of transport for the infantry which was 
numerically inferior to the enemy‚Äôs, the lack -of anti-tank guns 
capable of knocking out the enemy‚Äôs tanks, whereas the enemy had 
his deadly 88 mms., and finally the lack of training fi-om wliich many 
of the British and Imperial units suffered. In the air the enemy were 
sh'ghtly inferior, but the disadvantage as the battle progressed %vas 
offset by lack of landing grounds and aviation spirit in the fonvard 
areas. 

A measure of ill-luck entered into the final decision about the day 
to launch the offensive. Rommel was planning to attack Tobruk on 
November 23rd and had this date been chosen the enemy would 
have been caught at a disadvantage. Auchinleck had, indeed, 
considered the postponement of his date, but the almost continuous 
pressure from home to get going was always at the back of his mind

O N that morning of November t8th when after a night of heavy 
rain the advance was begun under a strong fighter cover, 
Briggs‚Äô 7th Brigade of the 4th Indian Division was in the fonvard 
area with the Central India Horse and Messervy‚Äôs Divisional 
Headquarters. Russell‚Äôs 5th Brigade was on lines of communication 
duty being short of veliicles. The 1st Royal Fusiliers had been left 
behind in S^Tia and its place was appropriately taken by the ist 
Buffs (East Kent Regt), which like its predecessor enjoys the privi- 
lege of marching through the City of London wth drums beating 
and colours flying, dating back as it does to a regiment raised in 
1572 by the London Guilds to help the Dutch revolt against Spain. 
The tith Brigade, also tvithout troop-carrying transport, was near 
the coast watching Halfaya which it had so nearly succeeded in 
capturing the previous June. Its present role was to deceive the 
enemy into expecting an offensive along the coastal plain. Brigadier 
Savory had gone back to India to command the 23rd Indian Division 
now being raised and had been succeeded by Brigadier A. Anderson, 
D.S.O., M.C. 

The task set to the 7th Brigade was the capture of the Omar 
defences on two humps of die desert about a couple of miles apart by 
the frontier tvire 15 miles south of Capuzzo. Libyan Omar was on 
the west, Omar Nuovo on the east; five miles north-east of the latter 
was Cova, another strong position, and these were succeeded by 
others in a north-easterly direction as far as the fortress of Halfaya. 
Six miles due north of Omar Nuovo was Bir Ghirba, another 
defended locality. The Omar defences were held by the 55th Savoia 
Division uith a cement of Germans. At titis point it may be stressed 
that the strength of the German cement was much more in its 
officers and N.C.O.‚Äôs than in the other ranks. The rank and file of 
German infantry in Cyrenaica were not noticeably superior to the 
Italians. 

The object of reducing the Omar defences was to deny Rommel a 
base for operations across the rear of the Eighth Army.

The 'optimistic reports of the offensive‚Äôs opening success seemed to

At noon on November sand the ist and 25th Field Regts concen-

Chapelle and Festubert. The battalion passed through Omar

yards between them and Libyan Omar. The leading squadron of 
tanks was stopped by a battery of 88 mm. guns 800 yards from the 
objective, several being knocked out. The second squadron turned 
aside and made for an already reconnoitred gap in a minefield; 
unfortunately the enemy had closed it with the result that four tanks 
and three carriers were destroyed. There were only five tanks in 
action when the 4/1 6th jumped from the lorries and went forward 
through the heavy machine-gun fire to reach the first line of trenches, 
which they attacked with the Italian hand-grenade captured in such 
quantities last winter. Subadar Ghulam Rasul led his company half 
a mile into the enemy‚Äôs position on the south. The Punjabis had 
penetrated 200 yards on the north. 500 prisoners had been taken, 
but when darkness came three tanks were in action, and nothing 
more could be done that night except to consolidate tlie ground won.

The gunners held their fire until the tanks were within 800 yards.

Eighteen devoted gunners were killed; 44 were woimded. Out of

The records of The Royal Regiment of Artillery are too bright

At 4 p.m. that day 25 tanks from the 15th Panzer Division with a

7th Brigade came over the low ridge south of El Adem and saw 
the airfield empty. That evening El Adem was occupied and 
contact was made with tlie 23rd British Infantry Brigade from 
Tobruk. 

Twenty miles westward the 5th Brigade found the Central India 
Horse held up by enemy rearguards in the neighbourhood of what 
was one day to be called Knightsbridge. One squadron had managed 
to get through north to the escarpment which overlooks the coastal 
thoroughfare where the enemy withdrawal was busy. The squadron 
in the best tradition of a cavalry regiment in tlie van of Allenby‚Äôs 
great offensive took their trucks down into the plain and shot up the 
enemy‚Äôs transport making a number of prisoners. That was all right, 
but the squadron had to get back, and completely surrounded in the 
darkness it was swept westward in the stream of retreating enemy. 
However, all of it except one section managed to break out with a bag 
of 150 Germans. Next morning Lance-Daffadar Janak Singh and his 
two trucks had to retreat with the enemy. Then he was chased for 
12 miles by armoured cars, and finally found his progress blocked 
by 20 of them. Lance-Daffadar Janak Singh decided that he must 
shoot his way through and out. So the old Chevrolet trucks with 
Bren guns and rifles blazing charged the armoured cars. One truck 
was lost, but Lance-Daffadar Janak Singh burst the barrier, dodged 
pursuit, and five days later was with the regiment again. 

That same night the rearguards in front of the 5th Brigade moved 
off, and the brigade moved on. The 7th Brigade reached the stone 
fort at Acroma. Their arrival had been anticipated by the dashing 
Messervy and some officers of divisional headquarters who had 
outrun even the cavalry screen. They captured two Italians asleep 
in the fort, and then went back to meet the Central India Horse and 
Colonel George on their way to seize Acroma. 

The 5th Brigade advancing on the left struck enemy defences 
west of Acroma, The Buffs captured one point witli over a hundred 
prisoners. Outrara‚Äôs seized another. The 3/ist Punjab Regt went 
through the middle to reach the main escarpment. 

Orders were received by XIII Corps to press the retreating enemy 
hard with the 7th Armoured Division, tire 4th Indian Division, the 
5th New Zealand Brigade and tire Polish Brigade. The New 
Zealanders were to advance directly to Gazala and hold the enemy 
there while the Red Eagles moved to Halegh cl Eleba and Tmimi to 
block his retreat. The 7th Armoured Division was to advance and 
protect the flanks of the infantry and be ready to cut the enemy‚Äôs 
lines of withdrawal.

The 4th Sikhs were close behind tlie Royal Sussex and passing

Position in the Middle East‚Äî feat of maintaining Russian supply 
route through Persia ‚Äî impending strain from Japanese onslaught ‚Äî 
India's growing industrial output. 

W E must now leave Cyrenaica to tell tlie melancholy tale of 
events in the Far East where, about the time that all three 
brigades of tlie 4th Indian Division began to advance after Rommel 
had withdrawn his panzers from the frontier, the Japanese were 
advancing like a relentless column of safari ants against the Gin- 
drinkers Line on the mainland opposite Hong Kong and the Nippon 
transports were approaching the Malay Peninsula through a strange, 
unholy and disastrous lull in the north-east monsoon. 

On our way to the Far East it will be convenient to pause and chronicle 
a little of what was happening in the true Middle East and in India. 

At the end of September 1941 Lord Beaverbrook and Mr Averell 
Harriman with various British and United States delegates visited 
the Soviet leaders in Moscow. Three days later it was announced 
that an agreement had been reached to fulfil almost every request 
for material made by the Soviet military and civil authorities. When 
we remember the last stand by the Buffs at Alem Hamza, when we 
remember tlie overrunning by panzers of the 2nd Mahratta Light 
Infantry at El Gubi, when we remember our glorious field gunners 
shooting it out with the monstrous Mark IV‚Äôs at Libyan Omar, it is 
difficult to feel much elation over the comparative enthusiasm of the 
factory workers of Britain in building tanks for Russia, though let it be 
added that the military and political authorities were much to blame 
for this mental attitude, the military through their insensate secrecy 
about units, the political through their professional optimism about 
the future. The Prime Minister‚Äôs broadcasts were loved and revered 
by the people of Britain because they believed he was telling them 
the worst not tlie best; it was a pity he encouraged them to suppose 
tliat at this date we had tanks equal to tlie panzers. ‚ñ† 

In October General Quinan, G.O.G. in Iraq and Persia, was 
given a new directive: 

You will take steps to develop such road, rail and river com- 
munication as are necessary to ensure . . . the maximum possible 
delivery of supplies to Russia. 



174 EASTERN EPIC 

In the feverish, the almost delirious activity in Persia to enlarge 
tlie port, to extend and improve tire roads and railway, and to 
provide tlie necessary transport India played a very big part. 

Actually, the shortest road distance from the south Russian 
border to Basra is over a thousand miles, and is about equal to the 
distance from the west Russian border to Antwerp. Within diis 
sleeve of land are nearly all the obstacles which Nature derises 
against travel: deserts with no water and no landmarks, deserts 
with soft and treacherous sands, malarious bogs; not one range 
but a series of ranges of high, precipitous mountains, often piled 
srith snow or drenched from die snow thairing, the home of bears 
and eagles; sandstorms, rainstorms, blizzards of snow and hail; 
the highest and the lowest temperatures that man can sunnve, 
sometimes hard against each other in space or in time. To these 
hazards humanity has added its own: nomadic herdsmen whose 
weapons belong to the twentieth century a.d. and whose politics 
to the twenties b.c. In mitigation man had made, by 1938, one 
suckling railway line; there was still no proper road from north to 
south at all. To build, across these wastes of steepling rock and 
mapless sand, a traffic route which would carry in vast quantities 
all the implements of war, appeared to need something like a 
five-year plan. But the Russians were not in a position to wait 
five years; from the time the Germans crashed across tlieir 
western border they ivanted supplies tvithin five weeks, or a good 
deal sooner if it could be done.^ 


While work to develop the existing port of Basra proceeded apace 
under superhuman difficulties the construction of a new port at 
Umm Qasr was undertaken. A large fleet of inland water craft had 
already been collected and organised with base depots at Shaiba. 
SuppliK from India to Russia norv went from Karachi to Basra fay 
sea and thence along the Baghdad railway to Mosul which was 
linked by road svith Tabriz, the terminus of the railway line from the 
^aucasus. Anofficr route of supply was the Trans-Iranian railway 
trom_ Bandar Shahpur through Tehran to Bandar Shah on tlie 
tu^aspian Sea whence tlie supplies were either sent by ship to Baku 
through the Caucasus, or shipped to the north 
coas of me Caspian Sea. There was a road route in the e-xtreme 
as o ^ Bersia which started from Duzdan, the terminus of the 
uaiuchistan railway and joined up wth the Russian Trans-Caspian 
1 way at Ashkabad. There was a road route from the port of 
avshiK in south-west Persia to Tehran through Isfahan. An alterna- 

Command 1941-1946. Hb 


RUSSIAN SUPPLY ROUTE 175 

tive to this -was tlie Ahwaz-Khurrambad road reaching Tehran by 
way of Qum and Kazvin through Mamadan. From Iraq Kazvin, 
Tehran and the Caspian Sea were reached by the Khanaqin- 
Kermanshah road. 

When all these names have been set down communication by 
road seems almost abundant, but it must not be supposed that 
those lines of communication either separately or together were 
anything but utterly inadequate for the traffic proposed for them; 
intensive work on the improvement and development of ports, 
railways and roads had to be undertaken immediately. By January 
1942 a new length of railway between Zenjan and Tabriz was 
completed, which gave direct rail communication through Tehran 
between the Persian Gulf and the Caucasus. In October 1941 the 
Trans-Iranian railway could carry only aoo tons a day, and if it was 
to serve as a life-line to the Soviets it would have to carry out at 
least 12 times as much tonnage to Russia alone. This meant more 
rolling-stock, more locomotives, more marshalling stations, more 
sorting yards, more crossing stations, more signalling equipment, 
more fuel and rnore water. The railway itself crossed mud-flats and 
desert to climb^by tunnel after tunnel across fearsome bridge after 
bridge through the mountains of Luristan. Then it dropped from 
7,000 feet to reach Tehran 500 miles from where it started. From 
Tehran another 300 miles of difficult country brought it to the 
Elbuz mountains with more steep gradients, spirals, tunnels a!nd 
bridges until it reached the mudflats of Bandar Shah a thousand 
miles from the mudflats of Bandar Shahpur. 

The Inland Water Transport which supplemented the railway 
owed much to India for the gift of twin-screw tugs, 500-ton barges 
and a small fleet of steamers that used to paddle up and down the 
Ganges and the Brahmaputra. 

These paddle-steamers had a draught of six feet, a freeboard of 
two. The voyage from Calcutta to Basra was over 4,000 sea-miles. 
They were escorted as far as Bombay by H.M.I.S. Pansy commanded 
by a lieutenant of the Royal Indian Naval Volunteer Reserve. 

The decks were speci^ly boarded for the voyage, the paddles 
were bolted to the wheels and sea-rudders were fitted. One of the 
steamers did not get beyond Calcutta Roads: another was sunk by a 
Nippon submarine. Their naval orders were, to attack any enemy 
submarine ‚Äòvigorously on sight,‚Äô for which attack they were given 
two rifles each and a hundred rounds. The distance from Karachi 
to Bahrein is about 850 miles, and 850 miles would see every one of 
those craft without any coal in their bunkers. Each could carry 



176 EASTERN EPIC 


22 tons of drinking water and the after-peaks were filled with water 
to feed the boilers. The Chakrata was commanded by Captain 
Martin of the Corps of Sappers and Miners with a British sub- 
lieutenant R.I.N.V.R. as his first officer and an Indian midship- 
man. The fireman and the engineers were Indian soldiers, the 
carpenter was Chinese, and the crew was made up of Indian banda- 
rees or toddy-gatlierers, stveepers, trimmers and seacunnies or 
helmsmen mostly from Chittagong. Captain Martin wrote in his log, 
a few days out from Karachi: 


Forepeak full of water and leaking into chain-locker. Ship 
pitting heavily and shipping water. Slow ahead . . . Mid- 
night, heavy westerly swell and strong wind and rough sea. Ship 
again pitching heavily and shipping more water. Slow ahead on 
engines ... 4 p.m. wnd and swell increasing . . . 6.30 p.m. 
-based dowm to Slow, Ship pitching and straining heavily. , . . 


In a little over three ^veeks the paddle-steamers reached Basra, 
t mariners of India. Captain Keates might have dipped 

the White Ensign of the old Superb to such men.

RUSSIAN SUPPLY ROUTE 177 

, twenty-foot width of metalling with three-foot earth berms on 
botlr sides. Extra soling was to be laid where necessary. 

Stone of varying qualities was to be had near parts of the roads. 
W ater, generally, was not. A limited number of shovels and wheel- 
barrows was available. There were reputed to be nineteen rollers 
in Persia, but this proved to be a flight of fancy.^ 

The first columns to travel \vith their loads up and down tliose 
roads were found from 51, 203 and Q04 General Purposes Transport 
Companies of the Royal Indian Army Service Corps, and it was a 
tough assignment. There were no staging-posts beyond Takistan, 
and the crews slept on the road. If a vehicle broke down it might 
have to be towed for 300 miles. Significant of the dangers of the 
route every column took its own doctor and ambulance-car. 

The hardships of the earlier drivers were equal to any that were 
suffered in Persia and Iraq, and in the shining history of Indian 
service in the second war there can be fewer examples of sustained 
endurance. Some of these men were Moslems who during tlie 
days of Ramadan, refused to profit by the indulgence which 
their Faith gives to travellers and would drive all day mthout 
even drinking a cup of water. Some were Madrassis who had never 
experienced cold weather and whose education in driving had 
been limited to six hours‚Äô instruction in a small vehicle on the 
left-hand side of an ordinary South Indian road. And now they 
were driving 5-ton Studebakers and lo-ton Mack Diesels up the 
ice-paved gradients of the Shah Pass, where, if you miss your 
gear change, your lorry has only to slip back a few feet and it will 
topple oyer and crash down a thousand feet into thegorge below.¬Æ 

Through icy air with the thermometer 10 degrees below zero, 
through hot blasts that crackled in the ears, through dust and snow 
and fog and heat, in temperatures that could vary as much as 50 
degrees in a few hours, and often liable to attack by the marauders 
of this wild land the columns drove on for six days and seven nights 
to reach Tabriz. Here sometimes Aey would rest for 36 hours, but 
sometimes only for 12, and even in that time the vehicles had to, be 
unloaded and 'serviced. Then back on tlie five days‚Äô journey to 
Khanaqin where tire men were given four days to rest and service 
their vehicles. In nine months many drivers of the 51 G.P.T. Com- 
pany who came from the warmth and beauty of Mysore did the 
double journey 16 times.

It is doubtful whether any historian will ever be in a position to 
assert positively on incontestable evidence that either the Persian 
supply route or the Arctic supply route to Russia was of ‚Äòsupreme 
importance‚Äô to victory in the Second World War, but none will

German invasion of either, which if successful would have cost us 
victory over Germany and Japan. Toward that achievement no 
body of troops contributed more than the Elephants of the 6th 
Indian Infantry Division, and we shall come back to them during 
the tale of that dark year of 1942 on the edge of which tiiis chronicle 
now stands. ‚Äò ‚ñ†

British planning has always underestimated the scale of the

Neither Germans nor Russians did come surging up the valley 
toward Thai on the North-West Frontier. It was probably just as 
well. Toward the end of 1941 a realistic exercise of the defence of 
the Frontier was carried out. An ‚Äòunnecessarily optimistic‚Äô estimate 
of the power of the German attack was revealed, and one critic 
observed: 

If the German undertakes this operation at all he will produce 

the force he considers necessary for the purpose. 

We shall see presently how fatally underestimated was the potential 
scale of the Japanese attack through Malaya and Burma, Alas, the 
British appreciation of the enemy‚Äôs strength is usually based on 
British standards and methods of maintenance'and not on those of 
the enemy. All too often we hear the complaint from the operational 
side that it was let down by the Intelligence; evidence is wanting 
that Intelligence is usually heeded either by soldiers or politicians be- 
fore it is too late, and whatever mistakes Intelligence made before the 
Second World War and during the first two years of its course 
Intelligence can console itself with the reflection that if it had been 
infallible it would not have made the least difference. 

Before they come to the tragic story of military events in Burma 
in 1942 readers may be reminded that when Burma was politically 
separated from India in 1937, which was inevitable sooner or later, 
it was at the same time separated militarily. In vain did successive 
commanders-in-chief urge the unified command of India and 
Burma, pointing out that if Burma were awarded the responsibility 
of defending itself it would fall on India and predicting disaster unless 
India was allowed to prepare for such a‚Äò contingency. No practical 
steps were taken. The strategic necessity of links by road and rail 
between the two countries had often been examined in the past 
when India and Burma were united; but vested interests had always 
been successful in obtaining a postponement of action, and civil 
administration had always gratefully availed itself of any excuse for 
such postponement. It was argued that the absence of communi- 
cations enhanced India‚Äôs security. That might have been a better 
argument if no Indian troops were to be committed to the defence of

The whole colony, including Hong Kong itself, its sister island 
Lantao, Kowloon, the New Territory and a number of smal 
islands covers an area of nearly 400 square miles. The mainland 
except for a broad strip of marsh and irrigated land running soutli-

tivated. A dozen heights reach 2,000 feet and one, Tai Mo Shan, 
exceeds 3,000. Betiveen them are numerous steep grassy rid^ 
streivn between boulders of ochreous granite and intersected by 
valleys and ravines covered ivith scrub. The coast line is indented 
ivith salt-water creeks and sandy coves of which Tide Gove on the 
eastward‚Äô side is die most considerable, the head of it silted up and 
become a stretch of paddy fields. 

The Kowloon peninsula which at Kowloon Point is just under a 
mile from Hong Kong is densely populated and forms the focal 
point of the New Territory‚Äôs road system. From the southern tip a 
railway runs north through Beacon Hill and a number of small 
tunnels, round the coast along Tide Cove, up to Fanling and then 
onward across the frontier to Canton 90 miles away to the north- , 
west. The colony‚Äôs one aerodrome, used only by commercial- and 
training planes, was at Kai Tak, cast of Kowloon City. As an aero-

a project was afoot after the -war to level one of the small islands 
.round Hong Kong and construct a less perilous aerodrome. 

At Kowloon a good road turns west to run along the south coast 
for about 10 miles before it turns north and east through flat 
irrigated land to Fanling, where it rejoins the east road which 
follows the route of the railway round the coast. The westerly road 
passes the head of Gindrinkers Bay which is four miles from the head 
of Tide Cove passed on the easterly road. This neck was the base of 
what was called Gindrinkers Line, of which more anon. A mere

1,500 feet high, but is divided into tsvo almost equal sectors east and 
west by the Wong Nei Chong Gap, through which runs a first class 
road connecting the northern and southern parts of the island.

HONG KONG 


185 

spread along the coastal lowland, much of it reclaimed from the sea, 
and round the lower slopes of Victoria Peak (1,804 feet). The 
population is over a million, mostly Cliinese. Between the island 
and Kowloon lies Victoria Harbour and the naval base which in 
peace time was of major importance to the Colony because all 
except the largest ships could be accommodated there. However, 
early in December 1941 the area was practically cleared of shipping, 
and the small harbour of Aberdeen, the home of Hong Kong‚Äôs 
pirates and smugglers once upon a time, became the base for the 
few small naval vessels that remained in these waters. 

There were several good reservoirs both on the Island and on the 
Territory, but tlie larger ones on which the city of Victoria depended 
all lay in the Tytam region east of the Wong Nei Chong Gap, and 
their capture by the Japanese was one of the reasons that led to the 
final surrender. 

In the days when the Maginot Line was still influencing military 
opinion a defence plan was adopted in 1937. This provided for a 
chain of redoubts and fortified positions on a slightly convex line 
between the head of Gindrinkers Bay and Tide Cove, and then 
running south-east from the south side of Tide Cove to Port Shelter. 
There were certain disadvantages such as lack of depth and the fact 
that Tai Mo Shan north-west and Needle Hill north-east overlooked 
the high ground in the Smugglers Ridge and Golden Hill region, 
and thus offset its command of the roads and mule tracks running 
south from the frontier. 

South of the great Jubilee Reservoir the Shing Mun Redoubt at 
the nortli-western end of the Smugglers Ridge country did cover a 
wide exposed area and the precipitous Shing. Mun ravine running 
east from the reservoir did provide a formidable obstacle to hostile 
transport. 

However, after a certain amount of work had been done on the 
Gindrinkers Line the defence plan was changed to one which 
abandoned the notion of a prolonged defence of the mainland. . 
Probably the Japanese occupation of Canton in October 1938 
brought home to the planners how difficult it would be to hold a 
back to the sea position against the large forces Japan would be in a 
position to use. It was realised that with the forces likely to be 
available it would be impossible to retain the harbour for the use of 
the Royal Navy, but it was also realised that so long as Hong Kong 
itself remained in our hands the use of the harbour could be denied 
to the enemy. So it was decided that a couple of infantry companies 
should carry out for two or three days a delaying action between the

By 9 p.m. on December 8th the forward troops began their 
pre-arranged withdrawal down tlie Fanling Road towards Tai Po. 
Demolidons were carried out in die narrow Pineapple Pass, and 
south of the Tai Po ravine the 2/i4th put in some good shoodng 
on the Japanese infantry moving in close column down the Shalo 
Tung track on the otlier side of the pale aquamarine water that 
washes the bay at the head of which stands the village of Tai Po. 
However, the enemy pressed on and infiltration on the left flank of 
the Punjabis compelled two further withdrawals to the high ground 
south-eeist, where Major Gray hoped to be able to remain for the 
night. Heavy casualties were inflicted on an attacking party, but the 
Japanese were making the most of the bright moonlight by which our 
intelligence supposed they would be bewildered, and in small 
columns, led by local guides, in one case by three Chinese women, 
along cross country tracks, they developed their pressure. Some time 
before midnight about 150 Japanese landed from sampans near 
Cheung Shui Tan behind the Punjabis, which involved a further 
retirement. Finally just before dawn of December gth the forward 
company, its task accompHshed, withdrew to Monastery Ridge just 
forward of tlie Gindrinkers Line and east of the Jubilee Reservoir. 
Here it remained ail day until withdrawn by orders at dusk. 

While the forward company of the 2/i4th was falling back before 
enemy forces estimated at three battalions other enemy troops were 
advancing down the Castle Peak road which runs round the west of 
the New Territory. The Au Tau bridge had been blown, which held 
up the enemy transport. Patrols of the Royal Scots after a clash 
with the enemy at Yuen Long were withdrawn to positions west of 
Tsun Wan War just above Gindrinkers Bay; but by dawn of the 9th 
tlie enemy moving rapidly through Telegraph Pass had closed up 
on these positions and the Royal Scots retired to their positions in 
the Line. About the same time the Rajput reserve company Wcis 
moved up to fill the gap along tlie Shing Mun ravine. 

For the rest of the day activity was confined to patrols and scattered 
shelling. Small bodies of the enemy were reported to be crossing 
Tide Cove toward Buffalo Hill. Lieut-Colonel Rawiinson of the

5th Rajputs ordered a day and night standing patrol on Headier 
Hill as a precaution, but no serious attack from this direction 
developed for another two days. There were frequent low level 
machine-gun attacks by the enemy‚Äôs air force and crude propaganda 
leaflets addressed to the Indian troops were dropped. 

At dusk the forward troops withdrew from Monastery Ridge under , 
mortar and small arms fire to a reserve position in the left rear of 
their battalion. G Company of the 2/ 14th Punjab Regt had carried 
out i6 major road and rail demolitions just ahead of three battalions 
of Japanese on whom they had inflicted some 100 casualties without 
loss to themselves. 


The whole of the Mainland Brigade was now in position behind the 
convex line from Gindrinkers Bay to Port Shelter. It was expected 
that the Mainland Brigade would hold this line for at least a week 
or ten days; what advantage would have accrued to Hong Kong 
itself if this dream had been fulfilled is not apparent. In the event 
the dream was not fulfilled, but the danger of high-lighting minor 
failures is that it blinds the eyes of the public and prevents their 
recognising the major responsibility of those in England whose 
myopia, mental laziness and moral cowardice presented Hong Kong, 
Smgapore and Rangoon to the Japanese years before a platoon of 
the Royal Scots was bombed out of the Shing Mun Redoubt on 
that moonlight night in December 1941.

It was clear by now that a vigorous counter-attack was necessary 
if the mainland defences were to hold much longer. This was 
considered impossible because of the serious gap that would be

Tliroughout the afternoon and evening of the 1 1 th tliere was a

rioting and looting. Many of the Chinese launch-crews and lorry 
drivers were deserting, but in spite of all difficulties, the guns, 
motor-transport and heavy equipment were successfully evacuated 
by dusk; at 7 p.m. the Royal Scots and Winnipeg Grenadiers began 
to embark, and they were both back on the island before midnight. 
A small party of Punjabis commanded by Lieut. Forsyth was stranded 
for the night at Kowloon Point and at dawn was joined by 20 
stragglers from D Company 2 /14th. Soon afterwards, just as a ferry- 
load of refugees tvas leaving, the first Japanese troops appeared. 
Three of them were killed and the patrol was driven off, but 
firing continued until the ferry-boat returned and the Punjabis 
could board it. Then they were able to turnoneor two lightmachine- 
guns on the enemy and the ferry-boat crossed over to the island in 
safety. 

Meanwhile, the other two Punjabi companies with D Company of 
the Rajputs set out from the Tai Po Reservoir area for the Devil‚Äôs 
Peak at nightfall on what was to be a most exhausting march. The 
moon now waning to a decrescent. would not rise till after midnight, 
and the night was, black. No mule transport had arrived and there- 
fore blankets and rations had to be abandoned in order to carry as 
much in the way of arms and ammunition as possible. The last 
meal had been eaten in the early hours of the morning and the men 
had no iron rations- * 

Lieut;-GoIoneI Kidd of the s/i^th Punjab Regt was in the lead 
and following the line of a water catchment the party reached 
Shatin Pass without difficulty. Then they lost tlieir way. 

Lieut.-Colonel Rawlinson of the 5th Rajput Regt with his 
headquarters at Customs Pass had been expecting the afi^ih to 
arrive by about 2 a.m. At 3.30 a,m. there was still no sign of them 
when he received orders to begin the planned withdrawal to the 
Ma Lau Tong line where theDevil‚Äôs Peak peninsula narrows between 
Kowloon Bay and Junk Bay. Heavy small arms fire was now heard 
from the direction of Tate‚Äôs Cairn which had been seized earlier by 
the Japanese coming from Tide Cove and Buffalo Hill, However, G 



196 EASTERN EPIC 

Company was able to disengage from the enemy with light casualties 
and the whole battalion was able to move toward its new line 
without mishap. 

At 4 a.m. the 2/i4th had still not arrived, but at last they 
appeared in Hai Wan three miles south of Ma Lau Tong where they 
were met by Rawlinson. The fear that they had been cut off by the 
enemy at Tate‚Äôs Cairn was relieved. In the darkness they had by- 
passed Customs Pass and had come down Jat Incline and Anderson‚Äôs 
Road. The whole party was utterly exhausted by its march of 
nearly i8 miles with arms and equipment, all carried by hand. Two 
anti-tank rifles had been abandoned by order; but all the medium 
machine-guns and mortars were brought back, and that march 
was one more example of the spirit of that wonderful Indian Army 
led by officers who these stout-hearted men knew would not let 
them down. 

At Hai Wan D Company of the Rajputs in the rear of the 
Punjabis was sent into reserve, while the latter went on down to 
the jetty area to lie up during the day. G Company was placed on 
Devil‚Äôs Peak to protect the 3.7 howitzer troop and give depth to the 
defence of the Ma Lau Tong line. 

At daybreak A and B Companies of the Rajputs were hold- 
ing forward positions south-west and east of Ma Lau Tong with 
C Company and battalion headquarters at Hai Wan. Three 
positions had already been prepared by the Rajputs in case of the 
abandonment of the Gindrinbers Line, and during December i2th 
improvements were made. Major Hunt‚Äôs howitzers were able to 
make things unpleasant for Japanese parties seen moving about at 
Kai Tak and in Customs Pass. 

Late in the afternoon the enemy began to close up on the Rajput 
line, and enemy patrols were reported in contact with the forward 
positions. A Japanese battxdion was working its way down the 
westerly slopes of Chin Lan Chu above Anderson‚Äôs Road, and 
shordy beforp 6 p.m the two forward companies were attacked.- 
The attack was broken up by machine-gun and artiUery &amp;e, and 
‚ñ†within half an hour the enemy was retiring in disorder with heavy 
casualties and ‚Ä¢without having penetrated the frontal stretch of wire 
at any point. A.6^ch howitzer battery at Tytam on the island 
shelled the retreatin^apanese with effect; by 9 p.m. all was quiet. 

The Punjabi headqu^ters \vith,C and D Companies were now 
embarking for the isla^. and it was decided to withdraw the 
Rajputs to the Hai Wan potion where they wotild be concentratei 
and where their flanks woul^bc less exposed to water-borne attacJ 



JAPANESE ATTACK 197 

This necessitated the evacuation of the howitzer troop which had 
been doing such good work. By midnight A and B Rajput companies 
covered by a platoon of D Company on Black Hill were clear of 
their Ma Lau Tong positions, and after the Punjabis had crossed the 
Lei U Mun Strait, A Company of the Rajputs and the howitzer 
troop less their baggage and mules prepared to follow them over to 
the island. Then B Company moved to a position on the right of 
C Company at Hai Wan. 

By 4 a.m. on December 13th the bulk of Major Hunt‚Äôs troop had 
been evacuated, and the question arose of the advisableness of 
withdrawing the whole Rajput battalion. Desertion by the Chinese 
crews of the launches was imperilling the water-transport, and as the 
Rajputs were not in close contact with the enemy Maltby ordered 
their immediate withdrawal to the island. 

Four motor torpedo-boats and H.M. Destroyer Thracian were 
sent to help the W.D.V. Victoria which was evacuating men and 
equipment; by 7.30 a.m. battalion headquarters and the last 
covering troops of the 5th Rajput Regt were withdrawing from 
the Devil‚Äôs Peak peninsula in broad daylight without interference 
from the enemy. The 2/1 4th had already disembarked at Pak Sha' 
Wan and were occuping their new positions in Victoria City. The 
Rajputs were taken by sea right round to Aberdeen whence they 
were sent to the Tytam area to rest for 24 hours and refit. Ten sepoys 
who had been stranded on Devil‚Äôs Peak managed to get hold of a 
sampan and cross over during the day, rejoining the battalion that 
evening. 

120 mules were abandoned on the mainland because the mule- 
lighter‚Äôs crew had deserted and the lighter holed by enemy fire 
could not put to sea. This loss was destined to have a serious effect 
on the island fighting when several guns fell into the hands of the 
enemy for lack of mule transport. Much ammunition and equipment 
was also lost, but casualties were fortunately light. 

The two Indian battalions had not been heavily engaged with the 
enemy, but they had carried out with exemplary discipline all that 
had been asked of them, and their morale was high in spite of what 
must have seemed to them a curiously hasty withdrawal from 
positions they had spent so much time and labour in preparing. 
That the last minute decision to attempt to hold the Gindrinkers 
Line shortened by a little the time that Hong Kong was able to hold 
out is possible, but whatever plan of defence had been adopted to 
defend the island it was doomed and its garrison was expendible.
