WITHDRAWAL TO THE ISLAND 199 

‚Ä¢Kong and Singapore Regt of Artillery, and the coastal defence forts 
with guns ranging from 4-inch tog-a-inch. The latter were directly 
under command of the officer commanding 8th Coast Regt R.A. 
and Fortress Headquarters. 

It was considered impracticable to concentrate any part of the 
garrison in one spot as a mobile reserve ready to counter-attack in 
any direction on account of the paucity of troops and the liability 
of the island to combined attacks from the north and south simul- 
taneously, No doubt several enemy landings on Lamma Island, two 
miles south-west of Aberdeen, during December rxth and 12th 
suggested a likelihood of such a method of attack by the enemy. 
Nevertheless, the lack of such a mobile reserve does appear as a 
very grave handicap, and one may fancy that, if General Maltby 
had had more time to consider how to use the Canadian reinforce- 
ments and if their transport had reached Hong Kong instead of 
being sent to Australia, the dispositions would have been different. 
Much depended on the pillboxes round the coast manned by machine- 
gunners of the Middlesex whose task it was to inffict maximum 
casualties on the enemy while he was most vidnerable on the water. 
On the high ground behind the pillboxes the five infantry battalions 
with their own reserves were entrusted with the counter-attack 
where enemy penetrations should be successfully made. The north- 
east sector was considered the most favourable to a hostile landing 
and here the Rajputs held two companies (B and C) in reserve. In 
the north-west sector, where a boom had been laid offshore between 
Green Isle and Sheung Wan, the Punjabis held one company only 
(B) in reserve. The Royal Scots, less one company which held a 
narrow platoon post between the Punjabis and Middlesex south of 
Mount Parish, were retained in West Brigade reserve until they were 
reorganised. 

In the interval between -the evacuation of the Territory and the 
first Japanese landings on the island the enemy‚Äôs shelling and bomb- 
ing were almost incessant. On the morning of December rgth a 
launch reached Victoria Pier wdth a staff officer of Lieut.-General 
Sakai, commanding the Japanese forces, who was the bearer of a 
letter to Sir Mark Young, the Governor, in which tlie surrender of 
Hong Kong was demanded under threat of severe shelling and air 
bombardment if it was refused. The demand was rejected, and the 
artillery fire from Kowloon and other parts of the Territory at once 
increased in severity and accuracy. The coastal defence and mobile 
batteries could not reply with any effect because the enemy batteries 
were too well hidden and too numerous.

EASTERN EPIC 

On December t3tli and 14th the Japanese fire was mainly directed 
against guns and communications in the north-west sector. Batteries 
on Mount Davis and at Belcher Point were put out of action. 
Serious fires were started at Kennedy To%vn and West Point in the 
area of A Company of the a/i4th. There was a particularly heavy 
concentration on Magazine Gap, about half a mile south of Fortress 
Headquarters which cut eight main cables and knocked out 195 
telephone circuits. The Royal Signals restored communications 
wthin 24 hours, but the problem of cut communications was acute 
throughout Hong Kong‚Äôs ordeal. Food distribution in the thronged 
city was another complication, and the civilian population under the 
terror of the bombardment was becoming disorderly in some parts. 
Fifth columnists attached to the Chinese quisling Wang Chong-Wei 
were active, spreading alarmist rumours, stirring up discontent, 
and even sniping from buildings. Signalling from the hilltops to 
direct the enemy‚Äôs artillery on to motor transport and concealed gun 
positions was frequent. 

By the end of the day on December 15th Indian troops were 
manning pillboxes and occupying positions right along the northerly 
face of the island, and these pillboxes were shelled all that day and 
the next. Alternative 'positions were prepared in basements and 
godowns on the landward side of the coastal road, but these were 
shelled and often hit. By the evening of the i6th more than half of 
the pillboxes in the nor^-east sector had been smashed up or badly 
damaged, and all crews in this area were ordered to occupy their 
alternative positions during daylight. Dive-bombing attacks were 
made on different parts of the island. 

In such conditions the Rajput reserve companies (B and C) were 
called upon to plan their counter-attacks, the former to prevent 
enemy penetration between Tai Hang village and Braemar, the latter 
between Braemar and Sau Ki Wan. On December 17th two air at- 
tacks on Sau Ki Wan and the city area were succeeded fay a brief but 
^tremely severe shelling of the central district, and the coastal road 
betweenBraemarandSauEa Wan. Then at 1 1 a.m. the bombardment 
ceased and soon afterwards two Japanese laxmches arrived with re- 
newed demands for surrender. To these Sir Mark Young replied: 

, The Governor and Commander-in-Chief of Hong Kong declines 
most absolutely to enter into any negotiations for the surrender 
m Hong Kong and he takes this opportunity of notifying Lt.- 
eneraf Takaishi Sakak and Vice-Admiral Masaichi Niimi that 
e IS not prepared to receive any further communications from 
them on the subject. 



FIGHTING ON THE ISLAND 


KOI 


At a p.m. the sheUing began again, and much enemy activity 
seawards ivas observed on both sides of the island, but particularly 
what looked like a concentration of small transport craft at Kai Tak 
and the Kowloon shipyards. However, for the first time several 
enemy batteries and three mortars were silenced by counter 
battery action from tire island, and that was some compensation for 
having to withdraw to new positions tsvo 1 8-pounder beach defence 
guns at Bracmar because a large paint factory close by had been set 
on fire that night. 

On the morning of December i8th the shelling of the north-east 
sector was ominously heavier than usual. The petrol and oil storage 
tanks at North Point were set ah'ght. The two 1 8-pounders in their 
new positions at Braemar police station were destroyed by direct hits. 
Battalion headquarters of the Rajputs was knocked about. By 
afternoon the road between Causeway Bay and Sau Ki Wan was an 
embranglement of tram wires and fallen standards almost impassable 
even to despatch-riders. ‚ñ† 

Repeated air raids added to the confusion. In a particularly 
heavy one on the Central District a bomb hit an underground 
miniature range in which 8o sepoys of the Punjab headquarters 
company were taking shelter. The walls collapsed; 24 were killed 
and 36 injured. Stanley Barracks and the Sai Wan observation post 
were dive-bombed during the afternoon. 

Just before 6 p.m. a party of 200 Japanese was seen moving down 
from Hai Wan to the Devil‚Äôs Peak jetty. The island batteries opened 
up, and soon afterwards the enemy using guns and mortars of all 
calibres began a terrific bombardment of the north-east coastal 
area. 

By this time Brigadier Wallis and Lieut.-Colonel Rawlinson were 
convinced that the enemy would attempt a landing in that sector 
during the night. A mass of smoke from the burning fuel tanks and 
paint factory was drifting easterly across the Tai Koo Docks area and 
blanketing observation, while 12 of the 16 Lyon searchlights had 
been blotted out and the North Point fixed beam, close to the 
burning oil tanks, was dead. Then a rubber factory at Sau Ki Wan 
was set on fire to thicken the smoke, and at 7^30 p.m. the Sai Wan 
Redoubt was reported unable to stand up to further shelling. . 

Half an hour later the shelling suddenly stopped. Then above the 
comparative silence was heard the rattle of machine-gun fire. From 
Pillbox 43 and PiUbox 44 tlie Rajputs at Tai Koo Docks were engag- 
ing Japanese troops in small boats towed by ferry-steamers across 
the narrow strait between Devil‚Äôs Peak and the island. Reports were

sex, a subaltern and a surgeon with rS Diehards, five Winnipeg

All through the afternoon large numbers of Japanese reinforce-

need to destroy all oil installations.‚Äô We must not gibe at such 
evidence of last minute foresight, but when we remember that 
bombed, shelled, hungry, exhausted, ill-equipped and desperate 
garrison, we may be allowed to wish that such foresight could have' 
been granted earlier, and about the future of men as well as of oil. 

On December Qand East Brigade was being forced back toward

The night of the asrd produced no change in the general situation, 
but the desperate outlook was beginning to seem devoid of any hope 
to the tormented garrison. Even water was beginning to run short. 
Yet during^ that hopeless night six ammunition lorries witli the help 
of an armoured car of those wonderful Volunteers managed to reach 
the Ordnance Depot at Little Hong Kong and bring back some gun 
and mortar ammunition badly needed. The hand grenades wanted 
urgently for the street fighting that was now developing in the area 
north of the Race Course were in the Reserve Depot at the Ridge, 
and the Ridge could not be reached. 

Throughout the 24th the enemy from his dominating positions on 
Mount Nicholson and Jardine‚Äôs Look Out was able to make things 
most unpleasant for the Middlesex and the Rajputs, and at 3.30 p.m. 
after very heavy artillery and mortar shelling with a good deal of 
dive bombing Leighton Hill was almost surrounded by the swarming 
enemy. The Diehard garrison was authorised to escape, if it could, 
through the streets leading to Canal Road, Two officers and 40 
other ranks of the Middlesex managed to do so, losing a quarter of 
their strength in the effort. These men of the old 57th were Captain 
Man‚Äôs Z Company, and consisted of spare men of the machine-gun 
companies with battalion cooks, bandsmen and storemen. If the 
glories of regimental tradition are to be maintained, as alas, when 
these words are being penned, seems uncertain, in the British Army 
of to-day, the name of Hong Kong may stand in the Die Hard 
chronicle of valour beside Inkerman and Albuhera itself whore the 
King‚Äôs Colour was cut to ribbons by the French bullets and out of 
595 of all ranks 447 were killed and wounded. ‚ÄòDie hard, my men 
die hard,‚Äô Colonel Inglis exhorted his 57th on that bloody field of 
Spain, and his spirit exhorted their successors all through the 
nightmare-of Hong Kong. 

The Rajput post south-east of the Race Course had to be with- 
drawn, but the other positions remained as they were, and shortly 
before midnight an attack on Mount Parish was repulsed by Jemadar , 
Shah Mohammed‚Äôs platoon of wounded men. 

About this time Christmas greetings were sent to all ranks by 
H.E. the Governor and Fortress H.Q,. 

Sir Mark Young wrote: 

In pride and admiration I send my greetings this Christinas 
Day to all who are fighting and to all who are working so nobly 
and so well to sustain Hong Kong against the assaults of the 
enemy.

During that night the enemy penetrated deeply into the Stanley 
peninsula, occupied the northerly slopes of BennePs Hill and was m 
fast increasing numbers in the Race Course area, where the isolate 
Rajput platoon at the cross roads north-east was withdrawn to a 
position west of the Canal. 

Soon after 9 a.m. on Christmas morning Major C. M. Manner,' 
a retired Gunner living in Hong Kong, who had been captured y 
the Japanese when the Repulse Bay Hotel was ovemm by them, and 
Mr A. L. Sluelds, both men W'ell known in the Colony, came acr^s 
from the enemy‚Äôs lines under a white flag and reached Fortress H.Q,. 
Here they told M^or-General Maltby of their march wth men, 
women and children from the Repulse Bay Hotel through the Wong 
Nei Chong Gap to North Point, and of Ae ‚Äòincredible‚Äô number 01 
guns and troops seen during the last half of their ‚Äòtrek.‚Äô They had 
been told by the Japanese that they could talk freely, and then went 
on to urge as their own opinion not suggested by the Japanese that 
it was useless to continue the struggle. They added that the Japanese 
commander would not begin any hostilities until noon while the 
garrison decided whether or not to surrender. 

An emergency meeting of the Defence Council was summoned for 
10 a.m. at which it was decided to fight on. 

The ‚Äòtruce‚Äô was not strictly observed by the enemy because 
Japanese planes operating from Canton bombed Stanley, Aberdeen 
and Moimt Gough. Japanese artillery also bombed the Gaps. 
However, in the city area all was quiet imtil noon when Japanese 
artillery opened up on a large scale. At 12.30 p.m. the Rajput 
platoon on Mount Parish was surrounded but managed to break 
out to the north-west after savage hand to hand fighting, and Mount 
Parish was occupied by the enemy. 

Communications by now had broken down almost completely. 
Stanley, Wanchai Gap, Magazine Gap and the Royal Scots were 
cut off. The coast road north was so knocked about by shell fire that 
none but nmners could now pass along it. Only sis guns of the 
mobile artillery were still in action, Mth an average of 160 rounds to 
a gun available. 


SURRENDER OF HONG KONG 213 

By r p,m, the O‚ÄôBrien Street line, established in the Canal area, 
was held by 60 of the Middlesex with small parties of Royal Navy, 
Royal Engineers and Rajputs; with the enemy‚Äôs attacks growing more 
intense all- the time two officers and 50 other ranks of the 2/i4th‚Äôs 
B Company were despatched to reinforce Lieut.-Colonel H. W. M. 
Stewart of the Middlesex who had sent several warnings that ‚Äòhis 
men though in good heart, were being slowly but surely over- 
whelmed.‚Äô Wanchai Gap was captured by the enemy between 2 a.m. 
and 2,30 a.m. The hillside by Magazine Gap was set on lire by in- 
cendiaries and the field cables were burnt. The commander of West 
Brigade reported that the area could not be held for more than 24 
hours at the most. 

At 2.50 p.m. Lieut.-Colonel Stewart reported that his forward 
positions were being shelled from Kowloon and North Point and 
that Captain Man of Z Company had telephoned, ‚Äòthe line is 
breaking.‚Äô 

At 3 p.m. Major-General Maltby comidered the situation. East 
Brigade and Little Hong Kong had been out of communication for 
some hours, but whatever their situation it could not affect that on 
the north-west of the island. Bennet‚Äôs Hill had been surrounded and 
even as he was corrsidering the situation news came that the garrison 
had been forced to capitulate. Two companies of the 2/i4th 
Punjab Regt and a handful of exhausted troops were all that stood 
between the enemy and the densely populated central district of 
Victoria. The enemy was still bringing in fresh troops. The garrison 
was worn out by 16 days of continuous fighting without relief for 
anybody; the ammunition for the few guns left was running out; the 
water supply was failing. Was he justified in exposing the garrison to 
certain slaughter by holding out longer? Was he justified in e.xposing 
the civilian population to the risk of retaliation by a barbarous 
enemy? Was there anything he could order that would avert the 
final collapse and fall of Hong Kong? 

Major-General Maltby picked up the telephone and asked Lieut.- 
Colonel Stewart how much longer in his considered opinion the 
men could hold the line they now occupied. 

‚ÄòOne hour,‚Äô Stewart replied. 

And those two words decided Maltby to demand no more of men 
who had already given all that they could give. 

At 3.15 p.m. Maltby with the concurrence of the Commodore 
advised Sir Mark Young accordingly, and at 3.23 p.m, commanding 
ofiicers were ordered to cease fire and surrender to the enemy as the 
opportunity presented itself. 



214 EASTERN EPIC 

The formal surrender of the garrison took place at Uie Japanese 
Headquarters in Tai Hang at 6 p.m., and Lieut.-CoIonel Lamb 
R.E, was sent to notify Brigadier Wallis of the capitulation. East 
Brigade was still holding Stanley Prison and the high ground to the 
southj and it was not till 2.30 a.m. of December a6th after Wallis had 
received written confirmation of the surrender from his brigade 
major that tlie white flag was hoisted at Stanley. 

The Japanese forces available for the attack on Hong Kong 
consisted of two first line divisions and another division in reserve 
numbering in all about 50,000 men. They were abundantly supplied 
with guns and mortars, and were supported by at least 70 planes 
based on Canton but under the orders of the military commander of 
the operation against Hong Kong. The combined forces of the 
garrison amounted to 12,000-13,000 including the sea and air 
forces. The Japanese casualties were heavy. Soon after the surrender 
a ceremony was held at the Kai Tak aerodrome to commemorate 
the 1,895 Japanese troops who were killed. This figure is believed to 
be underestimated; but even if it be accepted the Japanese casualties 
in killed and wounded must have been at least 6,000. Allied casual- 
ties amounted in all to 1,111 killed, 1,167 missing and 1,362 wounded 
‚Äî a total of 3,640 of wliich 1,164 were Indian other ranks. Of the 
17 British and Indian officers of the 5th Rajput Regt all were 
casualties, of the 15 British and Indian oflicers of the 2/ 14th Punjab 
Regt eight were casualties, of the 24 Britisli and Indian officers of 
the Hong Kong and Singapore Regt of Artillery 13 were casualties. 
These figures do not include the casualties of the Hong Kong 
Volunteer Defence Corps, all of whom British, Eurasian, Portuguese 
and Chinese fought so bravely and so well. Special mention must be 
made of the officers and men of the R.A.F. who when their machines 
were destroyed on the first day of the attack volunteered for service 
on land and fought gallantly beside the naval ratings at Aberdeen 
TOth 1 7 casualties out of a total strength of 86. 

In view of the fact that the Japanese were able to laimch powerful 
forces against Malaya and the Philippines simultaneously wth 
their Msault on Hong Kong it is difficult not to question the military 
expediency of defending Hong -Kong.^ That those responsible at 
home for the conduct of the war were completely confused about the 
situation in the Far East is obvious from the acceptance of the 
Canadian offer to send those two battalions across the Pacific in

SURRENDER OF HONG KONG 215 

November. If all their officers had been Napoleons and all their men 
veterans of the Guard they could not have affected tlie issue. It is 
not being wise after the event to assert that Hong Kong should have 
been declared an open town if not in 1939 at any rate when the 
collapse of France offered Indo-China to the exploitation of Japanese 
strategy. The alternative which was to make it defensible was out of 
the question, once the Second World War had started. One of the 
prime necessities was to give ffie island adequate air support, and 
that would have meant constructing at least two aerodromes. The 
existing aerodrome at Kai Ttik was completely unsuitable for any- 
thing except civil traffic and it was not satisfactory for that. Aircraft 
carriers to-day might take the place of aerodromes, but in December 
1941 there were no aircraft carriers available for Eastern waters. 
It was known before the war began that the Royal Navy would 
withdraw from the China Station in the event of hostilities; it was 
known that defence of the island from the air was impossible. To 
what purpose were British and Indian troops sacrificed without even 
the consolation of feeling that they had not given their lives, their 
healtli and their liberty in vain? No attempt was made at home to let 
the people of Great Britain know what the defenders of Hong Kong 
had to endure before they surrendered, and a tale of superb heroism 
was soft-pedalled for fear of public morale. The excuse of concealing 
from the enemy what he wanted to know was of course absurd. It 
was not fair to let it be supposed that in some way the commander 
and the garrison had failed. They did fail as human nature must 
always fail to achieve the impossible. What would have happened on 
the beaches of Dunkirk without the Royal Navy and without the 
little ships? The British Expeditionary Force would have surrendered. 
There was no Navy and there were no little ships at Hong Kong. 
The garrison of Hong Kong was nearly 1,500 miles from the nearest 
British base, and Singapore by Christmas Day, 1941 was well on the 
way toward another inevitable surrender. The fortress of Hong 
Kong, with a million civilians under incessant bombardment, with 
troops outninnbered by a ruthless and skilful enemy, with ammuni- 
tion running low and water running out, with the hospitals crowded 
with wounded, and with no possible hope of relief, for ail knew that 
Chinese help on any scale was an illusion, and with an exhausted 
garrison which had been fighting for 18 days a battle for which they 
knew there was only one outcome ‚Äî the fortress of Hong Kong! 
There were some, indeed there were too many, who dared to wonder 
at the time why the white flag was hoisted so soon. The anstver is 
becatise the white flag had been flapping from every flag staff in

^Vhitehall and from Parliament itself, for dght years before war 
came. 

What cannot be charged against those responsible for tlic loss of 
Hong Kong is the abominable behaviour of the Japanese to their 
captives. This was really unpredictable, even if their behaviour in 
China had already shown of what tlxc race was capable. The 
misery undergone by the prisoners of war and the interned in Hong 
Kong and at Kowloon was unallcviated. There were many deeds of 
heroism performed by Indians, British and Chinese during tliosc 
dark three and a half years of captivity. One must stand for all those 
which cannot be recorded here. In a grave of the cemetery at Port 
Stanley lies all that is mortal of Captain Ansari of A Company 
5th Rajput Regt who endured fearful tortures rather than reveal 
the names of the Chinese in the British and Allies Aid Group that 
were associated with him in the work of helping escaped prisoners 
and obtaining intelligence about the enemy. With him are buried 20 
of those he tried to save by his own deatlx. Captain Ansari had 
already been recommended for the Victoria Cross for valour in the 
field before he was taken prisoner, and for hb martyrdom he was 
awarded posthumously die George Cross. 

On the night of the surrender D. R. Holmes who was in Z Force 
operating behind the enemy with Chinese guerillas blew up a park 
of Japanese munition lorries just west of Kowloon, and this was 
typical of the indomitable spirit which fired the Volunteers of Hong 
Kong, the chronicle of whose gallantry awaits a pious hand.

T he Malay Peninsula is some 400 miles long and vari^ in breadth 
from about 250 miles in the middle to about 60 miles in the north 
and south. In area it is about equal to England and Wales with 
Cornwall and Devon cut off. In size, shape and position the Island 
of Singapore resembles the Isle of Wight. The population was about 
5,000,000 of which 2,000,000 were Malays, 2,000,000 Chinese and' 
1,000,000 Indians, mostly Tamils from the south. 

The middle of the peninsula is taken up by a great ridge of 
granite mountains completely covered to the summits with dense 
jungle and devoid of communications. On either side of this massif 
are coastal plains through which run the roads and railway and in 
which the rubber is grown and the tin is mined that made Malaya 
the dollar arsenal as it was called. At the northern ends of these two 
plains there is extensive cultivation of rice. 

On the west coast a good motor road runs 585 miles from Johore 
Bahru on the mainland opposite Singapore to the Siamese frontier 
and thence on for another 52 miles to Singora, on the east coast of 
Siam. The railway runs parallel with this road. The coast itself is 
mostly mangrove swamps penetrated by many rivers. On the 
eastern lowlands there is no through motor road, but there are 
stretches of good road between which in dry weather the country is 
motorable. The railway at Gemas forks. The eastern branch runs 
through to Kuala Krai, the railhead for Kota Bahru^ and on into 
Siam where it meets the western branch of the railway at Haadyai 
near Singora and continues as one to Bangkok. The east coast 
consists of an almost continuous series of sandy beaches, not unlike 
the west coast of the Adriatic. 

Lateral communications are scarce. There is a road from Patani 
on the coast of Siam to Sungei Patani in Kedah, 150 miles south- 
west; there is a road about 200 miles long running due east from 

‚Äò This is wrongly spelt Bharu in most of the boolts about the Malayan Campaign. 
Bahru means ‚ÄòNew.* Kota Bahru means N¬´v Castle. 



2i8 eastern Ejt.. 

Kuala Kubu on the trunk road to Kuantan on the coast; and there 
is a road from Mersing right across the peninsula to Batu Pahat, 
90 miles long. Finally at Kroh on the Siamese frontier a road 
branches off the Patani road and runs by Grik to Kuala Kangsar, 
50 miles south. 

The topography of Malaya is not complicated and the potentiali- 
ties of strategy were limited although they favoured the attacker. 
The administration of Malaya was a cat‚Äôs-cradle. 

First of all there were the Straits Settlements of Malacca, Penaag, 
Province Wellesley and Singapore, the last three acquired by pur- 
chase, the first by exchanging a bit of Sumatra for it with the 
Dutch. These formed a British Colony and were administered from 
Singapore by a Governor acting tlurough an executive and legislative 
council. Secondly there were the Federated Malay States of Perak, 
Selangor, Negri Sembllan, and Pahang administered by a Federal 
Government at Kuala Lumpur and governed each by its oivn 
Sultan with the help of a British Resident. Finally, there %vere the 
Unfederated Malay States of Johore, Kedah, Perils, Kelantan and 
Trengganu, each governed by its own Sultan with the help of a 
British Adviser. The Governor of the Straits Settlements was the 
High Commissioner for the Malay States Federated and Unfeder- 
atcd; he coiild never deal with Ae Federated States as a whole, 
but had to consult each of them tlurough its Federal Secretariat. It 
could happen that the Governor and High Conamissioner had to 
deal with 1 1 separate bodies all of which had to be in agreement 
before a measure affecting Malaya as a whole could be introduced. 
Those who have run obstacle races for tlie sport of bureaucrats at 
home will not fatigue their brains by imagining what a military 
command was faced with in obtaining permission to make some 
attempt to put the defences of the country in order. 

The problem was not simplified by the fact that nobody at home 
seemed perfectly clear how Malaya was to be defended or even if it 
were necessary to defend it at all. 

When in September 1940 the Japanese took advantage of the 
collapse of France to occupy Haiphong and Hanoi in French Indo- 
China and to support Siamese claims to Cambodia, the Indian 
Government strained its resources to despatch to Malaya a divisional 
H.Q,., tvvo brigades, a number of sapper and miner companies, and 
some administrative units. It could not send any artillery or signals 
because it did not have them to send.

In August X939 when the international situation in Europe was 
. darkening rapidly the lath Indian Infantry Brigade Group (Briga- 
dier A. G. M. Paris) to honour a secret understanding to reinforce 
Singapore with a brigade group if necessary was sent to Malaya at

Egypt. It consisted of the isnd Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders, 
the s/and Punjab Regt and the 4th Hyderabad Regt.^ 

In August 1940 the necessity for holding the whole of Malaya 
with air power as the chief implement was recognised by the Chiefs 
of Staff in that Far Eastern Appreciation which made the Prime 
Minister notify General Ismay diat the Fleet was the prime defence 
of Singapore. It was then laid down that the land forces in Malaya 
were to be responsible for the close defence of the naval base and the 
aerodromes and for dealing with any enemy land forces that might 
succeed in gaining a foothold in spite of the action of the Air Force. 
For this action to be effective it was estimated that a minimum of 
336 first line aircraft would be required, and it was accepted that 
this programme should be completed by the end of 1941. It was 
considered that when it was complete six brigades with ancillary 
troops would be enough for the total land garrison, but that mean- 
while three divisions were necessary. This strategic appreciation was 
made before the Japanese moved into Indo-China, and therefore 
when the tacdcal appreciation required for the Chiefs of Staff from 
the commanders in Singapore was made in October 1940 it was 
estimated that 566 first line aircraft would now be wanted and that 
they should be supported by 26 battalions, i,e, at least four divisions 
with supporting arms and ancillary services. The Chiefs of Staff 
accepted the Army estimate but would not go beyond the previous 
estimate of 336 first line aircraft.

The decision to base the defence of Malaya on land and air 
forces until such time as in the event of the United States entering 
the war the weak East Asian American Fleet could enjoy the ad- 
vantage of the great naval base at Singapore involved India in a 
strategic policy in the forming of which India-had had no say and 
over the execution of which India would have no control, in spite 
of the strain such a venture would throw upon material resources 
already strained almost unbearably. India had to find 19 infantry 
battalions for Malaya and Borneo, by the time Japan entered the 
war. England found four, Scotland two, and Australia six. Later in 
the disastrous campaign nine more English battalions and six more 
Indian battalions were sacrificed.

much of its fuel. The gtli and nth Indian Divisions were not only 
given the. impossible task of defeating an enemy trained to the 
moment for tire operation he had set himself to carry through and 
overwhelmingly better equipped with ample air and armour 
support; they were asked to perform that impossible task with 
inexperienced young ofiEicers, N.C.O.‚Äôs and odier ranks after some 
months of inadequate training for jungle warfare during which for 
security reasons they had had to exist in the continuous gloom of 
rubber groves, which within the experience of the present writer is 
the most depressing form vegetation can assume. Indeed, it fostered 
a form of mental sickness both among the British and the Indian 
troops compelled to endure it, and this rubberitis, as it was called, 
aggravated by the enervating monotony of the equatorial heat 
predisposed the victims of it to a melancholic outlook. 

It would be unfair to censure the commanders on the spot for 
what was an undoubted failure to train the men for jungle warfare 
as they should have been trained, as for instance in the island of 
Hainan and elsewhere the Japanese commanders were training 
their men specifically for the task in front of them for a few months 
hence. After August 1941 the troops in Malaya had to be kept busy 
building defences; money for civilian labour was refused to the 
Malaya Command, The departmentalism which at home the 
Prime Minister was for ever scarifying with his toothed phrases 
remained in spite of them powerfully inert. The aerodromes that 
the R,A,F. were constructing for those 336 first line aircraft promised 
by the end of 1941, not a single one of which materialised, were 
constructed to suit the needs of the air at whatever cost to the land 
forces which had to defend them. Their dispersion over the peninsula 
made a mess of strategy, and when within 24 hours the enemy‚Äôs 
air force had successfully denied them to our Air Force the unfortunate 
Army was still called upon to deny them to the enemy for as long as 
it could, stuck to the neighbourhood of those literally blasted 
aerodromes like flies on flypaper. 

And what an air force was mustered to meet the Japanese attack 
of 700 modern aircraft! 15 Hudson general reconnaissance, 17 
Blenheim I bombers, 17 Blenheim IV bombers, 27 Wildebeeste 
torpedo-bombers, 43 Brewster Buflfalo' fighters, 10 Blenheim I 
night fighters, three Catalina flying-boats, four Swordfish, five 
Sharks, but no pterodactyls. 141 mostly obsolescent or obsolete planes 
and not one out of the additional 336 front line aircraft promised 
by the Chiefs of Staff in response to the request by the Commander- 
in-Ghief Far East for 566. No reproach is implied for the failure of

Middle East and Russia upon a hard pressed homeland ww too 
great. Nevertheless, in piety to the dead and for justice to the si^- 
vivors of that fearful campaign it is necessary to bring home to the 
world that their lives and their liberty were not lost by their own fault. 

We must now examine in more detail the strategic disposition of 
the troops to meet the Japanese attack. Before General Perciyal 
left London he had discussed the advantage of anticipating an 
attempted Japanese landing upon the beaches of Singora and 
Patani by an advance as far as the Kxa Isthmus in southern Siam, 
and when he arrived in Singapore he was instructed fay the Com- 
mander-in-Chief Far East to prepare a detailed plan for the op^a- 
tion which was known as Matador. At the same time he was told 
Matador must not be carried out without reference to London 
because it ‚Äòcould only be put into effect if and when it became 
clear beyond all reasonable doubt Aat an enemy expedition was 
approaching the shores of Thailand‚Äô (Siam).^ 

The military advantages of the occupation of South Thailand, 
or of part of it, were great. It would enable us to meet the 
on the beaches instead of allowing him to land and esUblisn 
himself unopposed, it would provide our Air Force with addioonm 
aerodromes and, by denying these aerodromes to &amp;e enemy,_ it 
would make it far more difhcult for his air force to interfere with 
our sea communications in the Malacca Straits. It was a question, 
however, whether it was a sound operation with the mea^e 
resources available. No troops could be spared for the operation 
other than the iith Indian Division, strengthened by some 
administrative units. The proposal to occupy the narrow neck of 
the Kra Isthmus was rejected as being too ambitious and the 
. discussions centred round the occupation and denial to the enemy 
of the Port of Singora and the aerodromes at Singora and Patam. 

It is dear that Percival himself was not completely convinced 
about Matador, but it could not have presented itself to him at the 
time as the doud-cuckoo-land operation which we with the wisdom 
of posteriority can perceive it to have been. We are imder no illusions 
after the event what the Air Force in Malaya was in fact capable of 
' doing against overwhelming force. We know that the spearhead of 
the Japanese attack was the KLiku or. Chrysanthemum Division ‚Äî the 
rSth Division recruited from the descendants of the warrior dans of 
the Kyusha and considered except for the Imperial Guards Division, 
which was to follow it, the finest in Nippon. That crack division of

the Japanese Army commanded by Lieut.-General Mutaguchi was 
to give us three and a half years of continuous anxiety before Slim

General Percival like General Maltby in Hong Kong was depen- 
dent for his judgment about Japanese intentions and Japanese 
fighting efficiency on the Far East Combined Bureau, and that 
efficiency was always underestimated. Yet Lieut.-CoIonel Ward, an 
expert about the Japanese Army who came to advise the military 
authorities in Malaya, was insistent that a Japanese battalion was 
in training, discipline and intrepid efficiency as good as a crack 
battalion of the unmilked Indian Army of 1939, and that meant as 
good as any battalion anywhere in the world. People shook titeir 
heads over what they considered the ‚Äòdefeatism‚Äô of Ward‚Äôs opinions, 
and his expert knowledge was not invited again. 

It should be added here that Major-General Murray-Lyon and 
his junior commanders were strongly in favour of an aggressive 
forward policy because North Kedah was from a tactical point of 
view a most unsuitable terrain for defence and from a strategic 
point of view even worse, exposed as it was to an advance from 
Patani which might easily cut its only line of communication by 
road and rail at Sungei Patani or even further south by way of the 
Grik road at Kuala Kangsar. Look at the map. 

Murray-Lyon ‚Äôs nth Indian Division which was to carry out this

After due consideration it was decided that Matador would be put 
into effect if ‚Äòa favourable opportunity presented itself‚Äô between 
October and March, The operation would consist of an advance by. 
road and rail to capture Singora and hold a defensive position north 
of Haadyai Junction; simultaneously an advance would be made 
from Kroh to a defensive position known as The Ledge, favourable to 
demolitions on the road to Patani about 40 miles into Siam. Finally 
it was laid down that a start of at least 24 hours was required before a 
Japanese landing was expected. That allowance of 24 hours was 
really too sanguine: even a minimum of 48 hours would have been 
sanguine enough. Matador became a tonic for rubberitis. Maps were 
printed. Money in Siamese currency was collected, and the inevi- 
table pamphlets were composed for distribution to convince the 
Siamese that our adventure across their frontier was inspired by the 
purest altruism. This curious British belief in the power of such 
credentials when printed may be a relic of the bibliolatry which was 
so long rife in Great Britain. 

Finally, and this was the most tonic part of Matador for rubberitis, 
about 30 officers with faked passports in civilian disguise were sent 
to reconnoitre Siam where they met many undisguised Japanese 
officers and left the Siamese authorities and Japanese officers in no 
doubt about British intentions. 

Matador, however, might not be a feasible operation, and since the 
task of the 1 1 th Indian Division was to defend die nordjem Irontier, 
which included covering the aerodrome in Alor Star and others 
farther south in Kedah and Province Wellesley, a position had to be 
foimd somewhere north of Alor Star. This was finally chosen in front 
of the litde village of Jitra, 18 miles south of die frontier where the 
branch road from Perils runs into the main road. It was not an ideal 
defensive position; indeed it was not at all a good one, but it was the 
best available within the area, and much troop labour was expended 
on trying to improve it, labour always being interrupted by training 
for Matador. We shall return to Jitra later.

O N December and the darkening of the international situation in 
the Far East was illuminated for a while by the arrival ofH.M.S. 
Prince of Wales and H.M.S. Repulse. These two great ships had been 
sent by the Admiralty at the suggestion of the Prime Minisler 
who hoped by this display of Britannia‚Äôs naval might to persuade 
the Japanese to think twice before they ventured to defy it. It was a 
bold gesture by a bold man, and it expressed in a practical fashion 
Mr Churchill‚Äôs own fervid belief already expressed in words that the 
prime defence of Singapore was the Fleet. The records of current 
opinion at the time do not reveal that anybody in Singapore felt 
uneasy about the future of these two great ships. Wise after the event 
we can recognise that the gesture was rash as well as bold, but 
when the Prince of Wales and the Repulse came powerfully to their 
berths upon that dank hot December day on the verge of the north- 
east monsoon the consequence of that gesture was still hanging in the 
stars. 

On December 5th Far East Command was notified by the Chiefs 
of Staff tliat if Far East Command had information of a Japanese 
expedition approaching with the apparent intention of landing 
on the Kra Isthmus or of violating any other Siamese territory 
operation Matador might be put into effect immediately without 
reference to London. 

Next morning about 1 1.30 a.m. air reconnaissance watching the 
approaches to the Gulf of Siam reported having sighted Japanese 
w^ships and transports 156 miles south-east of Point Camo in 
southern Indo-China steaming west. This information, to which was 
added later information that there were two convoys and that their 
position was about 80 miles east-south-east of Pul Obi, reached 
General Percival at 3 p.m. in Kuala Lumpur where he was confer- 
ring with General Heath; At 3.15 p.m. he ordered Heath to assume 
the first degree of readiness and to instruct Murray-Lyon to be ready 
to move at short notice to carry out operation Matador. When 
Percival (by civil airline !) got back to his headquarters at Singapore

It will be noticed that Key kept his troops on the right bank of the 
Kelantan River, relying on patrols for the farther bank. Where the 
Kelantan flows into the sea the land on either side is veined with 
streams and dense with nipah palms which have no bald trunks but 
branch direedy from the moist ground in which they flourish. 
Behind the miles of sandy beaches south are sparse groves of coco-nut 
palms about a hundred yards deep, but behind them are a network 
of streams and thickets of nipah while all dotvn the coast the beaches 
are separated from one another by small creeks. The mangroves 
which infest the westerly coast of Malaya and the east coast farther 
south are not much in evidence in this north-east corner; but the 
beaches are continually separated by streams at the mouths of which 
are numerous fishing villages, the inhabitants of which for political 
reasons could not be turned out. The sand of the beaches is cut into 
a miniature cliff by the north-cast monsoon blowing across the 
South China Sea. 

These beaches were wired and mined and* had a line of fortified 
pillboxes about 1,000 yards apart, each held by oneN.C.O. and six

Those who criticise the judgment which led Admiral Phillips^ to 
take the risks he did should remember that the American Pacific 
Fleet had been eliminated from the naval scene, that the American 
air force in the Philippines had been as successfully annihilated as 
our own in Malaya, that the Admiral‚Äôs only alternative to immediate 
action was to fill his bunkers with oil and depart for the west or 
remain at the base in Singapore as a target for the Japanese au 
force. If Prince of Wales and Repulse could have struck a mortal blow 
at the Japanese navy and the Japanese transports the situation in 
Malaya might still have been saved and the High Command at 
home might have had time to send those vital air reinforcements, 
those 336 aircraft which had been promised by the end of the year. 
Prince of I Pales and Repulse were not lost by a raA admiral; they were 
lost by one democracy which like the fabled ostrich believed that 
safety first meant seeing nothing, by another democracy which 
believed that it meant a fortified line, and by a third which believed 
that isolation was the same as insulation. 

This ultimate cause ofall the disasters which overtook the demo- 
Grades as each in turn became involved in the Second World War 
must continuously be emphasised because that ultimate cause is too 
often obscured by blaming the men on the spot for a failure' to per- 
form the impossible. Nowhere more than in the Malayan Campaign 
was responsibility for disaster quite so successfully shifted in pubfic 
opiiuon to the shoulders of the men on the spot, who either dead or 
prisoners of an infledble enemy could not defend themselves.

General Percival says;^ 

There is no doubt that this change from an anticipated offensive 
to a defensive had a great psychological effect on the troops. 
Although the chances of being able to put MATADOR into 
operation had never, up to tlie last moment, really been very 
great, yet it is a fact that the offensive is always more attractive 
than die defensive and, when there is a possibility of both, people 
tend to concentrate on die former rather than on the latter. 
Perhaps we at Headquarters, who were in a position to appreciate 
the political factors more clearly, did not communicate our views 
sufficiendy to the forward troops, or perhaps they did not percolate 
through Corps Headquarters, or perhaps the degree of secrecy 
which it was necessary to preserve in this matter had its effect. I 
cannot say for certain who, if anybody, was at fault, but the fact 
remains that the nth Indian Division was much- more confident 
of being able to operate MATADOR than were commanders

at Malaya Command that the starting point of two battalions was 
Anak Bukit and that their transport was the train. 

If Murray-Lyon had failed to move those two battalions to Anak 
Bukit on December 7 th after the news of the Japanese troopships he 
might well have been blamed for. disobeying orders.

I was with my carriers in a hide near the 19th milestone. One of

I saw some of our trucks and a carrier screaming down the flooded 
road, and heard the hell of a batde a short way to the north. It 
sounded as though guns and machine-guns had got right into our 
position. The din was terrific. 

It is believed that an infantry attack from the east, supported 
by mortars, coincided with the tank blitz which now occurred. 
This and the subsequent sniping of the Jitra position about an 
hour later indicates that the Ghanglun position had been out- 
flanked in some strength.

JAPANESE INVADE MALAYA 253 

The last to leave was Moorhead himself with the rearguard of the 
four carriers. He was armed with a rifle and fighting with his 
wonderful men till the forward companies withdrew. The carriers 
were now under shell fire, one was silenced by a direct hit, another 
was knocked out sideways. Moorhead hung on imtil the companies 
were clear. Then he gave the order for the two carriers left to retire 
and jumped aboard the rearmost as it started. No sooner was he 
aboard than he saw a wounded lance-naik lying 50 yards back. 
He halted the carrier and ran back along the road swept by bullets 
and blasted by shell fire to hoist the lance-naik on to his shoulder 
and bring him back to the carrier. 

The enemy did not follow up the withdrawal. The Australian 
lorries with their veteran drivers were waiting for the battalion at 
the suspension bridge eight miles north of Belong. Some of those 
drivers must have thought of the days when they held the Turk at 
Anzac. The bridge was blown. The lorries went back. At 3 p.m. 
350 men, all that was left of the s/ifith Punjab Regt passed through 
the 5/1 4th Punjab Regt to occupy the left sector of the Kroh position, 
where they were joined by too first reinforcements. At midnight 
Krocol passed from Major-General Murray-Lyon‚Äôs command to III 
Indian Corps. 

He had pressed for this before hostilities began; if Matador had 
been put into operation the command of Krocol would have been 
even more difficult. The delay in giving Moorhead his orders to 
seize The Ledge was even less excusable than the delay in notifying 
Major-General Murray-Lyon that Matador had been abandoned. 
In the circumstances all that could be done was done. The fight of 
Ihc S/jflth Punjab Regt on the Patani Road added another glorious 
page to the annals of the old Indian Army. 

Whatever, regiment in Pakistan is now the heir of the s/xfith 
Punjab Regt, the old Allahabad Levy of long ago, let it remember 
always with reverence the battle of the Patani Road. ,

The details^ of that withdrawal from Jitra cannot be related in 
these pages which have to be starved as ruthlessly of tales of devotion,

starved of the means to defend themselves during those disgraceful

By the, time the witlidrawal from Jitra was finished the nth 
Indian Division was a shadow of itself. The 15th Brigade could 
hardly muster 600 men. We have recorded the state of the Leicesters. 
The 2nd Jat Regt mustered four officers and 187 men. The 1/14* 
Punjab Regt had only one officer and two weak companies, all 
survivors of the Asun blitz. The 6th Indian Brigade had lost more

Surrey Regt had lost two platoons. 

Without sleep for a week, without food from the morning of 
December 12th until they reached Gurun on December 14th and 
perhaps not a chapatti apiece then, muddied by swamps, soaked by , 
streams, the nth Indian Division needed rest as few troops have 
needed rest. There were no troops available to relieve it, and so it 
was called on to continue fighting and withdrawing for another 
lethal month. 

The loss of sea power and the lack of air power made the conquest 
of Malaya by the Japanese inevitable in a matter of .weeks. No 
general, alive or dead, could have hoped to postpone it by more than 
a month, and it is hard to believe tfaat any senior officer in Malaya 
supposed otherwise. Therefore it might, have been. better to relieve 
the I ith Division by sending Lieut.-General Gordon Bennett and , 
his two Australian Brigades north from Johore and replacing them 
thereby the iith Indian Division. To be sure that would have 
been to gamble over a Japanese attack on the island by sea with a 
landing at Mersing, but by now the naval base was almost as much .

At dusk next day Brigadier Paris reached Krocol H.Q,. to tell 
Lieut.-Colonel Moorhead that he was now under his command and 
order him to withdraw through the Argylls in position seven miles 
behind him at Baling and remain at Tawar in reserve. At midnight 
Krocol withdrew to Kupang. The 5 /and Punjab Regt reached 
Merbau Pulas (14 miles east of Sungei Patani) at 7 p.m. of December 
15th and was ordered to occupy at once a position covering the 
approaches across the Muda because the Kroh road must be pro- 
tected against a Japanese threat from the west as a result of the 
Gurun mess. A single company of the Argylls had been sent to 
block the Grik road which ran 93 miles from Kroh to Lawin on the 
trunk road. The road north of Grik, considered impassable for 
trucks except in dry weather, was nevertheless a menace after what 
the Japanese had accomplished in the way of transport along the 
road from Patani. With the Highlanders were some armoured cars 
of the Federated Malay States Volunteers. 

On this day the aerodrome at Butterworth was abandoned by the 
R.A.F., the ground staff performing the operation at top speed. 

The Krai position which was occupied by the nth Division on 
December 17th stretched 30 miles from Mahang to the coast. It was 
too long a frontage for the depleted division, and the thickly wooded 
banks of the river afforded the enemy too much cover. Moreover, the 
strong pressure of the Japanese along the Grik road, where Major 
Kennard‚Äôs company of Argylls was re-enacting the thin red line of 
the old 93rd, might in the end prove too strong and that would 
mean the division‚Äôs being cut off. Heath decided that another jump 
back would have to be made to the line of the Perak River as a 
preliminary to occupying a stronger position farther north about 
Kampar. He had just reached this decision when news came that 
Kennard‚Äôs company after another hard day‚Äôs fighting had been 
pushed back nine miles to Sumpitan. Heath had to take the rath 
Brigade away from Murray^Lyori, and send the 5/and Punjab Regt 
to Kuala Kangsar to give help to the hard-pressed Argylls on the 
Grik road. He notified Percival of the enemy‚Äôs attempt to get behind 
the nth Division and suggested that 'at least one fresh Australian 
Brigade‚Äô should be sent to Ipoh at once. Percival replied that they 
did not ivant to dissipate their forces in Johore and Singapore and 
that Heath was to aim at getting behind the Perak. Meanwhile, on 
December 19th the fortress of Penang had been evacuated after a 
savage bombardment of Georgetown by the Japanese air force in 
which the Chinese centre of the to'wn was destroyed and all munici- 
pal public services ceased tofimction. Unfortunately when the enemy

and many barges which after being deserted by their crews were

2/9th Gurkha Rifles, and the 12th Brigade to Lieut.-Colonel 
Stewart of the Argylls. Brigadier Paris replaced Major-General

Lyon was a victim to the failure of Great Britain to shoulder the 
responsibilities of Empire: he was unlucky, but at least he escaped 
death or long imprisonment by a barbarous foe like so many 
thousands of otiier victims. 

The defence of the Grik road by the Argyll and Sutherland High- 
landers supported later by the 5/2nd Punjab Regt was at once a 
briihant and a brave feat which cost the enemy heavy casualties, but 
here as elsewhere the limit of endurance for troops was reached.

‚Ä¢ smacked before they can ‚Äòconnect‚Äô with the simplest order,

WITHDRAWAL TO PERAK RIVER 263 

The first landings at Singora and Patani were carried out by the 
5th Division under Major-General Matsui. The Guards Division 
(Major-General Nishimura) landed at Singora on December 13th, 
and one i-egiment of this division was in action by December 2 ist. 

On arrival at the Perak River the Japanese strength amounted to 
‚Äòfive Divisions,‚Äô but ‚Äòthe actual fighting was done by small units at 
the head of the column because of the narrow road and lack of 
manoeuvre space; the British as well could use only small bodies of 
troops. But by the clever use of demolitions, road blocks, and small 
rearguard detachments . . . they were able to slow up the Japanese 
advance in the early stages and to inflict heavy losses in both men 
and material.‚Äô 

When the nth Indian Division was ‚Äòalong the Krian river . . . 
where the highway and railway bridges had been destroyed‚Äô tlie 
Japanese column which ‚Äòhad been marching at widely extended 
intervals‚Äô had the head of its main body at Prai . . . while the 
remaining divisions were strung out along the road to the north, the 
last one being in bivouac at Singora . . . The fact that General 
Yamashita allowed his command to become so strung out that it 
would require several days to assemble for battle showed that he had 
little fear of any offensive action on the part of the British.‚Äô 

No, indeed, for the nearest fresh troops, the 8th Australian Division 
was 286 miles to the south, and Yamashita, for all his divisions were 
strung out, was always able to put in fresh small units at tile head of 
the columns. 

Yet even now there was still a disposition in Singapore to cling to 
that depreciation of Japanese military skill which was responsible for 
so much deplorable rhetoric over the radio. Consider what those 
gangsters, as Lieut.-General Percival called them, had accomplished 
by December 23rd. They had forced the nth Division back 160 
miles from the Siamese frontier to the Perak River. They had 
occupied the State of Kelantan. They had swept the R.A.F. .out of 
the sky and the Royal Navy from the sea. They had paralysed the 
United States Fleet in Pearl Harbour and obliterated the United 
States Air Force in the Philippines. They were now driving the U.S. 
forces back along the Bataan Peninsula. Hong Kong was on the 
verge of falling and Wake Island had just been occupied, and on this 
December 23rd they were invading Sarawak where in all British 
North Borneo the 2/i5th Punjab Regt was the sole garrison.

The battalion whose successful disengagement owed so much to 
that devoted hundred lost contact with the enemy at Ngabaung. It 
was now operating independently of the Dutch, and it was decided 
to make for the south coast in two columns, one heading for Sampit, 
the other for Pankalang Boen, rao miles to the west. 

One column started on February 3rd, tire other on February 5th 
and after arduous days of marching through the equatorial jungle 
they reached their respective destinations at the same time. The 
Sampit column found the enemy there before it, and after a 
skirmish it set off westward to join the other column at Pankalang 
Boen. Marching on a compass bearing for six days through virgin 
jungle it was successful in uniting the battalion again. By the end 
of March officers and men were utterly exhausted. Since leaving 
Kuching they had marched over 800 miles tl^ough country as 
difficult as any in the world, and marched moreover for most of the 
time on half-rations, carrying their light automatics and rifles, their 
ammunition and equipment. 

On April 3rd the men of the afi^th Punjab Regt, still an example 
of soldierly order but baffled by the surrender of the Dutch East 
Indies of their hope of finding transport to Java, became prisoners 
of war. Sikhs, Jats, Punjabi Mussulmans and Pathans shared with 
the British officers who led them in a feat of physical endurance 
and moral strength not often paragoned in the chronicles of human 
valour. 

The a/rsth Punjab Regt came to Malaya with the 6th Brigade of 
the nth Indian Division. When it was sent to Sarawak its place 
was taken by the and East Surrey Regt, It was an honour even for 
the old Glasgow Greys, 70th of the Line, to take the place of such a 
battalion. ‚Äò ‚Äò ‚ñ† .

I T was on Christmas Eve that Major-General Murray-Lyon 
received orders to report at once to corps headquarters and han 
over to Brigadier Paris temporary command of the nth Indian 
Division. Colonel Hairison, the G.S.O.I. of the division writes: 

We all knew what that meant. The General was being relieved 
of his command. No doubt this was inevitable. In the face 0 
constant disaster troops are bound to lose confidence in their 
Commander, and the one vital thing was to restore that confidence. 
Perhaps a new broom would help. , 

Major-General Murray-Lyon ^ew what it meant too, but. tie 
took that knock like the man he is. He bade cheerful good-bye to 
liis Commanders and Staff at D.H.Q,., thanked them for what 
they had done, and left us. 

All who knew him well were sad to see him go. He had never 
spared himself during his year in command of the iith Indian 
Division in Malaya before the outbreak of hostilities: he had met 
and overcome many difficulties and some obstruction: he knew 
his officers and he knew his men, and they knew him and trusted 
him implicitly. The ‚ÄòDivisional sign‚Äô was a wheel tvith eleven 
spokes . It was intended to symbolise the wheels of the 1 1 th Divisicm 
revolving towards Singora, but those wheels never advanced. 
That sudden change of orders on the 8th December stopped them, 
and then the dam‚Äô things started going backwards. 

^ In those first two weeks of distister, Major-General Murray-Lyon 
did all that a Commander could do to restore broken confidence 
and to inspire his Division. He showed himself calm and unruffled 
throughout. He invariably went forward into the thick of it 
when affairs took a bad turn. He was a gallant leader. ‚ñ† 

On the same day Lieut.-General Sir Henry Pownall^ arrived in 
Malaya; a fortnight later he became Chief of Staff to General Sir 
Arcffibald Wavell as Supreme Commander of Allied South-West 
Pacific Command.

ACTION AT KUANTAN 269 

In the middle of December Whitehall captivated by tales of the 
Scorched Earth Policy in Russia ordered unrestricted Scorched 
Earth for Malaya. It might be rash to claim a record for the ulti- 
mate depth of official stupidity, but such an order for a country like 
Malaya inhabited by people of other races to whom we had guaran- 
teed our protection by treaties would be a powerful competitor. 
In the end after representing the state of affairs to London the Far 
East War Goimcii extracted permission to leave the civil population 
with the food already distributed and not to destroy the water 
supplies or power plants. 

News reached General Percival of reinforcements on the way. The 
45th Brigade of the 17th Indian Division diverted from Iraq would 
arrive in the first half of January. So too would the 53rd Brigade of 
the i8th East Anglian Division diverted first from North Africa to 
Burma and then diverted again to Singapore. The 53rd Brigade would 
be followed by the 44th Indian Brigade and the rest of the r8th 
Division. 50 Hurricanes were also being sent by the same convoy of 
American liners as the 53rd Brigade. It was stressed that these liners 
had only been obtained by special permission of the American 
authorities, and that everything must be done to protect this valuable 
convoy against air attack. 52 Hudsons were also promised: 15 of 
them reached Singapore. It is diffictdt to understand why the 
dangerous despatch of these aircraft was possible at the beginning 
of January and the safe despatch of them a month earlier impossible. 
The deeper the chronicler shall delve into the history of the Malayan 
Campaign the heavier he shall find the weight of responsibility on 
those at home for its disastrous outcome. 

Percival was naturally anxious to leave nothing undone that 
could be done to ensure the safe arrival of those reinibrcements, and 
therefore he insisted on the paramount importance of denying the 
aerodromes at Kuala Lumpur and Kuan tan to the enemy. It will be 
convenient at this stage to tell the story of Kuantan before we leave 
Malaya for a while and return to events in North Africa. 

Kuantan is a small seaport on the east coast of Pahang separated 
from the railway at Jerantut in Central Malaya by a road running 
for a hundred miles through desolate jungle. Here nine miles from 
Kuantan itself the R.A.F. had recently completed a large and well 
equipped aerodrome to the defence of which the Q2nd Indian Brigade 
had been committed. 

The and Frontier Force Regt had been detached from Painter‚Äôs 
22nd Brigade when hostilities began in order to reinforce Key‚Äôs 8th 
Brigade in Kelantan. So the 5th Sikh Regt and the 2nd Royal

Garhwal Rifles were entrusted with the defence of this reniote area.

River Kuantan to the River Balok. The Sikhs were west and south o 
the Kuantan River with tlie aerodrome in their zone. The vital 
ferry which was the only means of communication between troops 
operating on either side of the Kuantan was a slow and clumsy 
affair worked by Tamil coolies and unpleasantly vulnerable to 
hostile aircraft. 

Early on the morning of December gth the eight Blenheims wwe 
flown to Singapore: tlie Hudsons remained. Later that mornmg 
Japanese planes raided the aerodrome.

During the night of December g/ioth the Garhwali pillboxes on

. report of a landing at Kuantan which reached Admiral Phillips from , 
Singapore and led him to dose the shore with Prince of Wales and 
Repulse and thus next morning encounter the Japanese planes.

T he reader is reminded that many pages back Briggs‚Äô 7th 
Brigade of the 4th Indian Division which had been garrisoning 
the Siwa and Jarabub oases since August 1941 was relieved by the 
29th Brigade of the 5th Indian Division. The Jalo Oasis about 200 
miles west of Jarabub was still in Italian hands. When the operation 
Crusader was being planned Brigadier Denys Reid was ordered to 
protect certain airfields which were to be pushed forward westwards 
to provide fighter cover for the land forces in their advance along the 
coast, to capture Jalo and fiom there to harass the enemy as oppor- 
tunity offered, and to continue deceptive measures with the object of 
persuading the enemy that a large force was being concentrated in 
the south and thus induce him to divert part of his armour to meet 
such a threat. 

Reid was not allowed to reconnoitre towards Jalo until the very 
end of October, and 'even then he was forbidden to go himself. 
Therefore he sent Lieut.-Colonel Jenkins,^ commanding the

retreat. 

Eighth Army was a long time about giving the commander of thf

in oracular form.

It was out of the question for Reid to take his force as far as that 
tvithout more petrol, and he decided to devote his activity to light 
reconnaissance patrols until fuel was available for an advance. 

The course of events in Gyrenaica has already been recorded. On 
December igdi Ritchie had decided to send Bencol consisting of the 
22nd Guards Brigade to cut across the desert and upset the enemy‚Äôs 
retreat from the Gazala line. Simultaneously Reid was to link up 
mth Bencol in the Antelat-Agedabia area and help in this operation. 
Unfortimately the shortage of supply vehicles made it impossible for 
Bencol to start until December 20th, and December 22nd was fixed 
as the day for E Force to link up with it. 

Reid decided to make Giof el Matar his base for operations, 
German patrols were found to be active in the area south and west 
of Agedabia. They had been sighted round Gasr es Sahabi on 
December 17th, and this might mean that German troops had 
reinforced the Italian garrison at Giof el Matar. Agedabia itself was 
strongly held by infantry and tanks, and there were anything up to 
50 aircraft on the aerodrome there, a dangerous threat to operations 
by E Force against Giof el Matar, Long Range Desert Group with 
Special Air Service Troops raided this aerodrome on the night of 
December 21 /22nd and destroyed 37 enemy aircraft on the ground. 
This dashing success cleared the prospect for E F orce. 

Shortcol which included a company of the ^jznd Punjab Regt 
under Lieut.-Colonel Short of the South African Armoured Car 
Regt was sent on a day ahead of the main body on December 19th 
with orders to secure Saunnu by the evening of December 2isti 
Another column and Lieut.-Colonel Grobelaar was to make contact 
with Bencol east of Saunnu, Without giving details of some skilful 
and complicated desert moves it is enough to say that Shortcol, 
having captured Giof el Matar with 14 Italian prisoners, was sent 
forward to establish contact with Bencol in the Antelat area. It was 
in position near the Antelat-Agedabia track by 2 p.m. on December 
22nd, but reported to the. main body which had by now taken up 
defensive positions in and around Giof el Matar that it had not 

gained touch with Bencol. _ 

What had happened was that the Guards Brigade on reaching 
Antelat on December 22nd had found an enemy force with 30 tanks 
lying round Beda Fomm to cover the main retreat of the Germans 
and Italians along the coastal road. One battalion was driven out of 
Antelat next day. General Gott diverted 7 Special Group to the 
help of the Guards, and the enemy withdrew to Agedabia. The 
pursuit of the enemy by XIII Corps was thwarted by difficulties of

January, ig^. Priorities between Middle East and Singapore ‚Äî Rommel 
forestalls attack by 4th Indian Division ‚Äî conflicting appreciations of 
enemy intentions ‚Äî the Benghazi trap. 

B y December i8th two brigades of the newly raised 17th Indian 
Division, trained, so far as they were trained, for operations in 
the Middle East, had been diverted to Malaya. These were the 44th 
and the 45th Indian Brigades, of whose unhappy fate we shall all too 
soon be hearing. The Middle East Defence Committee was pointing 
out to the Chiefs of Staff that only three of a minimum of seven 
divisions considered necessary for Persia and Iraq would be available 
in the spring of 1942. Wise after the event we may be inclined to 
suppose that jMiddle East Command was unduly concerned about 
its Northern Front, but at the time it seemed absolutely certain that 
the Germans would strike at our vital oil and as the tide of Japanese 
success flowed strongly that India would be simultaneously attacked 
from the North-West and the North-East. The Committee estimated 
that the diversion of the i8th East Anglian Division to Malaya 
could be offset fay the recall of the 50th Northumbrian Division, but 
it was seriously concerned about the proposed diversion of air 
reinforcements not merely to' the Far East but to Russia and Turkey. 

Now that the situation in Malaya on that New Year‚Äôs Day has 
been exanuned it may perplex the reader to recall that on that 
date the Chiefs of Staff informed the Gommanders-in-Chief in the 
Mediterranean that the security of Singapore and of sea-communi- 
cations in the Indian Ocean were second only to. the security of the 
United Kingdom and tlie sea-communications thereto.^ When he 
recalls those 336 first-line aircraft promised by the end of 1941001 
one of which had arrived, he may wonder why in 1940 the security of 
Singapore was regarded with such complacency that the despatch 
of two brigades to the jungles by the Indian Government seemed an 
almost criminal evasion of its responsibilities to the campaign in the . 
Middle East. It is arguable that the policy of improvisation dictated 
by the neglect of our Imperial responsibilities during the previous 
decade made the task of those responsible for the conduct of the war 
an almost impossible one. What the ultimate judgment of history 

p. 178. 


10 



ago EASTERN EPIC 

may consider gravely reprehensible is the encouragement given to the 
R. A.F. to construct aerodromes for aircraft that there was presiunably 
no likelihood of being able to provide unless the security of Singapore 
was in very fact regarded as second only to the security of the 
Uiuted Kingdom; if it was so regarded no excuse can be found for 
those who imperilled that security by accepting the minimum 
demanded for it and their subsequent failure to honour the promissory 
note for even tlrat minimum. It is kinder to believe that the security 
of Singapore was not regarded as second only to the security of the 
United Kingdom and to read this telegram by the Gbiefi of Staff to 
the Commanders-in-Ghief of Middle East as sugar for the disagree- 
able pill tire latter had to swallow. 

The second paragraph insisted that the defeat of Germany must 
remciin our primary object and that we should not divert more of our 
forces than were necessary to hold the Japanese. If the Chiefs of

Gold Group was just preparing to proceed again after the halt 
when armoiued cars of tlie Central India Horse reported a group of 
vehicles approaching from the north-east. In a few minutes this was 
discovered to be a column of enemy transport escorted by four

25-pounders of the 3 1st Field Regt and the troops of anti-aircraft and 
anti-tank guns deployed to cover the retirement of the lorries and 
deal with the panzers. In the excitement the anti-tank guns opened 
fire at extreme range before the 25-pounders could get on to their 
targets with the result that the hostile column turned and made off 
into the north-west. It was soon evident that the whereabouts of 
Gold Group had been reported to the enemy because aircraft kept 
coming over in low flights to look at the columns. Strict orders had 
been given not to fire at die planes and when one of tliem fired a 
machine-gun burst without response the perplexed scouts flew away. 
It may be observed in passing that it seems strange that neither in the 
British, German, nor Italian armies had any method of recognition 
signals been devised for an occasion like this. A week earlier Reid 
and his merry men in E Force, whom we shall meet again presently,' 
had enjoyed seeing 21 Stukas by which they expected to be attacked 
drop ail their bombs on one of their own columns which was holding 
up the force. 

More alarming for Gold Group than hostile aircraft was the 
shortage of petrol. A certain number of vehicles had been destroyed 
to economise; every lorry now was carrying 35 men; everything had 
been jettisoned e.xcept rations, water and arms. When Gold Group 
got into contact with a troop of Royals searching for break out 
parties about 40 miles from Tengeder there was petrol for only 
another 30 miles and great was the relief when the Royals told them 
tliat there was plenty of petrol less than 10 miles away. 

Gold Group harboured at Bel Amia. Vehicles were sent to draw 
petrol next morning, and soon after midday of January 31st Gold 
Group reached Tengeder. Here orders were received to continue to 
El Adem by way of Bir Hacheim, and here Gold Group arrived at 
4 p.m. on the afternoon of February ist, having achieved its long 
march without a single casualty and with the loss of only 31 vehicles. 
Among tliese' was the water truck of the '4th Sikh Regt which had 
expired after running 45,000 miles in the Sudan, Eritrea and Libya, 
a noble vehicle whose demise was an inconsolable grief to its driver, 
Naik Besart Singh.

Silver Group had had a day of much fighting when on the evening 
of January 28th it received the order to break out. The columns 
passed through the Nauuaghia minefield at i a.m. of January 29th 
and by 7 a.m, had made 40 miles. A halt was then called for

foimd that a platoon of the Royal Sussex and a troop of 25-pounders 
were missing but that during the night a troop of anti-aircraft guns 
and a certain number of men of the Welch Regiment had joined 
the group. 

At 8.45 a.m. Silver Group started on the most dangerous part of 
its adventure. A mistake in navigation brought the columns too 
close to the escarpment at Eluet Abdulla, four miles north of Antelat, 
and the order was given to wheel sharply to the right. When direc- 
tion was being changed the carrier platoon of the Royal Sussex 
which was guarding the left flank saw a number of enemy vehicles 
led by two panzers coming down the escarpment towards them. 
Evans at once ordered the carriers to attack. There were only six 
of them became the front section had not seen the convoy and had 
gone on. The six carriers waited until the panzers were down the 
escarpment well ahead of their flock. Then they cut in, and the 
convoy which consisted of 20 Italian lorries, two staff cars and a 
number of motor-cyclists turned round and fled uphill. The escort- 
ing panzers behaved with typical German contempt for their 
Italian allies and went on their way. The carriers intercepted the 
last seven lorries, one of which turned, dropped its tail board and 
opened fire with a storm gun; this was knocked out by a Boyes 
rifle. 14. Italians were killed and 28 taken prisoners; the latter were 
loaded with the diesel oil found in one of the lorries, and the carriers 
now an hod^behind the main body hurried on to overtake it. 

Strangely, no general alarm was given, although this little battle 
was fought wim^ sight of Antelat, and Silver Group was able to 
cross the trails ^d get through the gap without interference. 
However, soon afteki p.m, two Messerschmitts flew over to investi- 
gate matters. Againsftorders an anti-aircraft gun opened fire and hit 
one of them. The oth^ German plane came back, machine-gunned

the column, and signalled for aid. An hour later two flights of

As a result of disobedience by that anti-aircraft gim 13 were

At 7.45 p.m. Silver Group set out in bright moonlight over hard 
sand; by 5.30 a.m. on Sunday 30th the group had covered 120 miles

The break-out from Benghazi by tire 7th Indian Brigade was a 
blend of audacity, coolness and skill deservedly blessed by fortune, 
and it displayed the qualities of the Indian and the British Armies 
at their highest level. 4,100 officers and men under the inspiring 
leadership of Brigadier Briggs, Lieut.-Colonel Goulder and Lieut.- 
Colonel Evans accomplished a military feat to which the annals of 
warfare offer few paragons. Three historic battalions with many 
mighty names among their regimental honours would have been 
proud to add Benghazi to the record. 

Those 4,100 brought with them 800 vehicles after 200 had to be 
destroyed either for mechanical defects or lack of petrol. One officer 
and 12 men were killed and 25 were wounded. Fourteen of the enemy 
were killed and 35 prisoners were brought back across the desert. 
One platoon of the4/i6th Punjab Regt was overrun by panzers when

The reason why Rommel was successful against XIII Corps was 
because when he counter-attacked from Agheila, XIII Corps was 
spread out from tire sea right round to the south of Agheila in 
small groups of columns. This was a dispersion of effort, for these 
columns were not able to concentrate to join i Armoured Division 
in the main battle south-east of Antelat. 

The first principle of war is concentration at the decisive time 
and place. The result was that 2 Armoured Brigade, Guards 
Brigade and Support Group, were beaten in detail. Fourth Indian 
Division had no troop-carrying transport at first, and when it 
got it, it was not sent to the help of i Armoured Division. The 
result was that i Armoured Division was attacked without a 
shot being fired by Fourth Indian Division, and Fourth Indian 
Division was attacked widiout a shot being fired by i Armoured 
Division. 

When control of the desert area was lost by XIII Corps, Fourth 
Indian Division had an extremely difficult withdrawal to make 
because the Germans were in a position not only to follow it up 
but tojhit at it from the desert, in flank and almost in rear. The 
Division piquetted its route all the way back as in Fronder war- 
fare, in order to hold enemy attacks from its rear and flank. This 
succeeded, and the enemy was held every time except once, la 
miles west of Carmusa, when the stubborn fighdng of 1 1 Brigade 
kept the way clear for 5 Brigade to draw out. 

You will notice also that the principle of security was neglected, 
for nowhere west of Tobruk was there a firm base on which XIII 
Corps could fall back, or behind which it could rally for a counter- 
offensive. In modern war these firm bases are an essendal part of 
one‚Äôs method of advance. 

There is no doubt that Fourth Indian Division showed up very 
well in the extremely diflicult conditions of this deliberate with- 
drawal. There was never a single sign of panic. Without sufficient 
transport and with other difficulties, the wididrawal went through 
most smoothly. This was a great credit to our Brigade Commands 
and Staffs, and to our Signals and Administration Services. 

These were the words of a soldier who was also an artist and in 
neither capacity content with the second best. He was fortunate in 
his brigadiers, two of whom would presently themselves conamand 
divisions with the greatest distincrion; he was fortunate in his staff; 
he was fortunate in his officers; above all he was fortunate in his men, 
Indian and British. The transport services wrought miracles; The 
chronicler drives his pen over the page, but he- does not always

body British. or Indian is driving a lorry. This conunent.by the i8th

WITHDRAWAL TO JOHORE 335 

been demolished. Three da)ra later it passed through the 8th
