The failure of the Japanese to exploit to the full the overmastering 
advantage tliey enjoyed in the air has led some commentators on the 
campaign to regard the collapse of our air defences as merely a 
contributory cause to the ultimate fall of Singapore. It cannot be 
emphasised too strongly that it was the fundamental cause. At this 
moment General Percival writes in his Despatch:^ 

It was clear that the Japanese intended to press on as fast as 
possible down the West Coast. It seemed probable also that a 
landing would soon be attempted on the east coast of Johore, 
probably in the Mersing area, from where the enemy could either 
develop another thrust towards Singapore or open the lateral 
road to Kluang. A direct sea-borne attack on Singapore was still, 
as before, a possibility, though it seemed probable that this, if 
contemplated, would be deferred until it could be combined with 
an attack from the landward side. Finally, there was the possi- 
bility of an airborne landing either in Johore or direct on to 
Singapore Island. 

In order to obtain our object it was necessary tliat we should 
continue to fight the enemy on the mainland. In view of the 
disparity in strength between the Japanese and ourselves the safe 
arrival of our expected reinforcements remained of primary 
importance. We estimated that the most important formation, 
the 18 British Division, could not be disembarked and deployed 
on the mainland before the end of the first week in February at 
the earliest, t.e,, more than three weeks alread. 

Our problem was greatly influenced by the fact that the road 
Jemaluang-Kluang-Batu Pahat is the only direct lateral com- 
munication in Johore and also by the fact that the newly con- 
structed aerodromes of Kahang and Kluang were situated on this 
road. It was obviously necessary to fight as long as we could north 
of this vitally important road. 

It was tlierefore decided to deny to the enemy the line Mer^ing- 
Segamat-Muar.

ENCIRCLEMENT AT BAKRI 


343 

Let us return to those two Australian battalions and what was 
left by now of the 45th Indian Brigade round Bakri. The road from 
Yong Peng runs westward for about six miles between marshy land 
with rubber plantations beyond on either side until it crosses a 
causeway, after which it runs on as straight as a Roman road between 
jungle-covered hills through what was called the Defile, seven 
miles beyond which, rising to sm-mount the Bukit Payong saddle, the 
road crosses a bridge at Parit Sulong over a sinister-looking dark 
stream called the Simpang Kiri about 14 miles from Bakri. 

Since January 17th the 6th Norfolks of Duke‚Äôs 53rd Brigade had 
been in position on Bukit Payong to command the Defile with a 
platoon forward to hold the Parit Sulong bridge. On the morning of 
the 19th Key visited tlie Norfolks and found these young troops who 
had been trained to operate in the desert completely mystified by 
the tropical scene. It was late to start instructing those yoimg 
East Anglians in jungle warfare against fight-hardened Japanese 
troops of the finest quality, but Key did his best to give them some 
elementary tips. 

Bad news came from Bakri, two miles south of which the transport 
lines had been attacked and the road behind the 45th Brigade 
blocked. Worse news came from the Defile which in spite of gallant 
work by G Battery of the 155th Field Regt and the carrier platoon of 
the 6th Norfolk Regt had been captured by the enemy. At one point 
six gunners led fay Battery Sergeant-Major Roadnight charged a 
Japanese platoon a hundred yards away and routed them with 
grenades and the bayonet. 

Key decided that an effort must be made to put the Japanese out 
of the Defile, and Brigadier Duke who now had Moorhead and his 
3/1 6th Punjab Regt in his brigade agreed to his making a night 
advance before the enemy had time to consolidate on Bukit Belah 
and Bukit Pelandok. ‚ñ† 

The Punjabis guided by Lieut. Sewell of G Battery who knew the 
way were to occupy Belah by dawn and under cover of their 
enfilading fire the Norfolks were to attack Pelandok. At 4 a.m. 
Moorhead and the Sikh company reached the jungle-track and 
began to scramble up the hill. Just before they reached the clearing 
at the top Moorhead with Lieut. Thatcher, his adjutant, went 
forward to the leading section. As they came up with it there was a 
volley of fire which killed four of the eight Sikhs in the section, and 
tlren the ‚Äòenemy‚Äô charged with a British cheer. The enemy was , 
D Company of the , Norfolks which unknotvn to anybody , was 
occupying the top of Bukit Belah. Moorhead managed to stop the 



344 EASTERN EPIC 

firing and ordered forward tlie rest of the Sihh company. HcAvas 
giving his instruedom when about a dozen grenades burst among 
the company. The Sikhs gave their war-cry; Moorhead and Lieut. 
Palmer, the company commander, rushed for^vard to stop any 
fighdng, supposing it was die Norfoiks again. 

But this dmc it was tlic Japanese. Moorhead fell wounded. Palmer 
fell at the same moment, and when lire latter revived his orderly 
was dressing his wound. Thatcher the adjutant was beside iiim and 
said that Moorhead had died of his wounds ten minutes after he was 
liit. Palmer‚Äôs orderly tried to carry liim back; he was killed, and 
Palmer fainted again. When he came to for the second time Thatcher 
was beside him, also wounded; he was killed later. A British gunner 
and two Siklis slightly wounded carried Palmer back to the regi- 
mental aid post. Here was Sewell also wounded and some 20 other 
men. Of that Sikh company only 10 wounded men got back to 
headquarters of tlie 3/i6th Punjab Rcgt. 

They reported that the company inspired by the exhortations of 
their dying colonel had gained the summit of Bclah, but there they 
had been counter-attacked from all sides by the enemy and were 
practically annihilated as also was D Company H.Q.. of the 6th 
Norfolk Regt. 

From The Ledge on the Patani road to the Defile thebahadursof 
the old 33rd Punjabis had fought in accord with all that was 
most glorious in the annals of the Indian Army, the influence of 
their colonel being continuously active whether he was temporarily 
away from them in command of a brigade or back with his beloved 
men. When Moorhead was gone from them for ever that influence 
stayed paramount until the end of the campaign and even aftertvards 
through the horrors of captivity, 

A havildar of the 3/i6th Punjab Regt when he heard of Moor- 
head‚Äôs death said: ‚ÄòMcradil iutgaya. Aisa bahaduTadmikabhinahinhongeJ 
My heart is broken. There will never be a man more brave than he. 

Let Pakistan and India remember that such a man led Mussulman 
and Sikh in amity once upon a time and let Britain remember that 
she wasted heroes like these because mammon took more from India 
than self-sacrifice tvas able to repay. 

The dawn attack by B Company of the 6th Norfolk Regt on 
Bukit Pclandok failed as was inevitable in the circumstances, and 
Duke represented to Key that his brigade, which now consisted of 
what was left of the 3/i6tlr Pimjab Regt and Norfoiks with the 2nd 
Loyal Regt sent as reinforcements from the Singapore garrison, was 
in no shape to attempt the recapture of the Defile.

345 

At Parit Sulong the two platoons of the NorfoDcs which had received 
no rations since the evening of January i8th and had been out of 
communication since the morning of yesterday abandoned their 
post and reached Batu Pahat on January sist. 

At 4.30 a.m. on January 20th orders were issued that the with- 
drawal from Bakri sliould begin. Australian troops formed the 
vanguard and rearguard of the column. Indian troops guarded the 
flanks of the guns and vehicles moving along the road. After

at the bayonet‚Äôs point by tlie n/igth Australian Battalion, which 
cleared two more road blocks that day. At noon the 2 /29 th Australian 
Battalion was fighdng equally hard with Japanese tanks and 
infantry pressing on from the rear. It was on this day that the 
4th Jat Regt restored a critical situation by a counter-attack which 
was led by Brigadier Duncan, and in which he was killed. 

It was 2.30 a.m, on January 21st when the exhausted column 
halted three miles north of Parit Sulong. Late that morning orders 
came that the 45th Indian Brigade would revert to Westforce. This 
did notupset Key who had never been notified that it had been placed 
under his command. On the following day the 53rd Brigade was 
placed under the command of Westforce. Key had already given 
orders for the 53rd Brigade to make another effort to recapture the 
Defile, to which Gordon Bennett agreed. 

In the end the counter-attack on the Defile was postponed until 
dawn of January 2and, and the 3/i6th Punjab Regt and and Loyal 
Regt to whom the task was entrusted had to spend the day in the open 
under almost continuous bombing from the air. January 21st was a 
bad day for the unfortunate 45th Brigade, but the two Australian

From The Times, June 23rd 1950: 

Melbourne, June 22. 

The war crimes court at Los Negros to-day found Takuma 
Nishimura, a former Lieutenant-General in the Japanese Army, 
guilty of the murder of 1 10 Australian and 35 Indian prisoners-of- 
war in Paritsulong in January, 1942, and sentenced him to death 
. . . Nishimura said he wtis sorry that through his carelessness 
the massacre had occurred. His counsel said the survivors of the 
divisional staff of the Japanese Imperial Guards had manoeuvred 
to put the whole of the responsibility for the massacre on him. 

When it came to Benedict‚Äôs turn he was taken by three Japanese to 
the bank at the same time as his company havildar-major by three 
other Japanese. Benedict knocked a rifle out of the hands of one of his 
escort, broke loose, and dived into the stream swimming along under 
water while the Japanese were firing. In the confusion the company 
havildar-major also got away. Benedict swam on until he found 
some fallen trees among which he was able to hide, and here, until 
darkness fell he watched the massacre of the wounded go on. 
Hearing a cry for help from the opposite bank, Benedict swam 
across and found two sappers, one of them Sapper Periasamy with his 
head half severed. He managed to get both these men across to the 
opposite bank and for 15 days he looked after them in the middle 
of the 2,000 Japanese with which the area was maggoty. Then the 
three of them made an attempt to rejoin our troops, but on February 
and they were recaptured at Muar, and later were prisoners of war in 
Sumatra where during the forcible construction' of the railway by 
European prisoners of war Lance-Havildar John Benedict never lost 
a chance to help them. All three men rejoined their unit at Banga- 
lore, and in the autumn of 1945 Major .Whitman the company 
commander, noticing the scar on the neck of Sapper Periasamy, 
heard for the first time of John Benedict‚Äôs heroism. He was awarded 
the JMilitary Medal and later was promoted to jemadar.-

defence works before the Japanese went to war. Air reconnaissance 
reported the arrival of a large convoy at Singora, and it has been 
ascertained since that this convoy brought two fresh divisions with 
the intention of landing them at Endau and Mersing. When the 
success of the west coast operations made this unnecessary the bulk of 
tliese divisions was sent to the Kluang area by land. 

The nevy defence of die a2nd Australian Brigade was concentrated 
round Jemaluang; Mersing was held only as an outpost. On January 
26th two enemy transports escorted by two cruisers and 12 destroyers 
approached Endau. Two attacks were made on this convoy by 
Wildebeestes, but the landing was not prevented and in that 
attack what was left of the Air Force in Malaya practically vanished. 
Two Bridsh destroyers, one of which was sunk, also attacked the 
convoy. 

The fresh troops landed at Endau at once marched south crossing 
the river west of Mersing. The 2/1 8th Australian Battalion was able 
to plant an effective ambush which disposed of about 300 Japanese 
from the leading battalion and enabled Eastforce to fall back toward 
Singapore Island according to plan, Westforce, which it will be 
remembered consisted of the 9th Indian Division and the 27th 
Australian Brigade, had been lucky in withdrawing successfully from 
Segamat. The Kluang area with its vital aerodrome was now seriously 
threatened, and on January 24th the 5th Sikh Regt was ordered' to

Great gallantry was displayed -by all in getting the wounded back 
to what there was of a regimental aid post. Jemadar Munsabdhar 
Khan after leading his platoon in a gallant attack crossed a bullet- 
swept stretch of open ground seven times to carry back seven of his 
wounded men. Sepoy Basta Singh, another hero of the fight at 
Kuantan Ferry, had his knee shattered at the beginning of the attack, 
and lying in the open under fire he saw a couple of Japanese sniping 
from, a tree-top 200 yards away. He managed to crawl over to a 
light machine-gun and shot the two Japanese out of their nest. Then 
later when two sepoys had been wounded in trying to convey him 
back he shouted to his platoon commander not to send any more men 
to his aid but to shoot him before the battalion went on. Jemadar 
Sher Khan led the pioneer platoon in the work of rescue and he 
himself carried back a badly wounded Sikh much bigger than himself 
for over 200 yards. This brotherhood between Muslim and Hindu 
soldiers was built up through the years by British officers of the Army 
in India who loved their men and counted a life in which they had 
led such warriors into battle as well spent.

ravines there were several stretches of swamp. 

There was the pidful picture of stretcher bearers floundering in

When dawn broke on January 30th the brigade was on the edge 
of a wide belt of undulating country under pineapple cultivation, 
which meant at any rate food of a kind. The brigadier told hi 
commanding officers to meet loim at the top of a high hill, at the end 
of the range whose lower slopes had been traversed during that 
horrible night. 

The intention, which was a survey of the country, was good; 
Parkin ordered his company commanders to meet him later on top. 
Climbing tliat hill on a blazing day after two days and nights of 
incessant effort without sleep or food was a severe strain on every- 
body. The brigadier himself failed to attend the conference, and the 
commanding officers decided drat the brigade should move across 
the pineapple land in open formation and make for a belt of rubber 
on high ground away to the south. The hill on which this decision 
was taken was ominously named. It was Bukit Hantu ‚Äî the hill of the 
ghosts. 

When the party descended the brigadier‚Äôs orderly reported that 
on his orders he had left him half-way up the hill in a state of 
exhaustion. The indomitable Parkin went up again with his own 
orderly and found the brigadier lying on the grass in the shade of a 
boulder. He told Parkin to take over command of the brigade and 
leave him. However, Parkin persuaded him to make another effort 
and with his orderly‚Äôs help he got him safely down to where the 
column was resting, and after another half-hour‚Äôs rest he declared 
himself ready to move on. 

There was much air activity, but the brigade camouflaged with 
tufts of grass passed across the pineapple land in open formation 
without being seen, and the eating of the pineapples was a tonic to 
the men. On the way across the plantation seven Dogras of the 
and Baluch Regt in Malay dress joined the column and said that 
the 8th Brigade had withdrawn from Sedenak two nights ago. Their 
information was mistrusted at the time; nevertheless, it was correct. 

Near dusk a Chinese offered to guide the column between the 
railway and the main road to Sedenak. About midnight this man 
disappeared near a hut in which there were two other Chinese who 
warned the brigadier that about 500 Japanese were in bivouac a few 
hundred yards ahead; indeed, the sounds of a carousal were audible. 
The exhaustion of the officers and men precluded any possibility of 
a nighr attack. The brigadier accepted the offer of one of the two 
Clrinese to guide the column round the enemy forces in the neigh- 
bourhood. Meanwhile, the whole brigade had fallen fast asleep, and 
without wailing to see if the men had been roused the brigadier and

his staff set off at once witii the new guide. Owng to this ill- 
considered haste B Company of the 5th. Sikh Regt and the A;A. 
platoon were left behind and lost. They did not surrender to the 
Japanese until April 15th 1942, exactly two months after tlie 
capitulation of Singapore. Eleven men of B Company were captured 
by the merciless enemy in March and these were all beheaded. . 

Finally after many perplexing changes in direction the Chinese 
left the brigade in a rubber plantation about a mile east of the 
railway, saying that it was now clear of the Japanese in the neigh- 
bourhood and could proceed straight ahead. 

Beyond the rubber was a stretch of very bad marsh, and the 
brigadier who now seemed determined to atone by haste for his 
collapse on the Hill of the Ghosts decided that this must be crossed 
at once without even a short rest. 

The bog through which we had to pass was like quagmire which 
dragged one down to one‚Äôs knees. ... I placed myself in the 
narrow flow of stream . . . and proceeded with the aid of the 
torch to conduct the stretcher teams across. This was a ghastly 
undertaking, far and away more frightful than on the previous 
night when condidons had been bad enough. It was accomplished 
because these men who were carrying the wounded showed the 
wU and courage to go through witli it no matter what the effort 
cost tliem. I saw the leading men of the first team step off into the 
bog and cautiously pick their way over the stream, soon to find 
themselves sinking slowly down until the mud had engulfed their 
feet as far as their knees. The men in rear had only reached the 
shallow waters of the stream and were therefore standing nearly 
two feet higher than the two at the forward end of the stretclier. 
This naturally dited the stretcher forward at a steep angle . . . 
shortly all four men were floundering in the bog. The man on the 
off fore position suddenly staggered and his knees were shaking 
wildly. He sank on one knee with a sliout of terror in his hoarse 
voice and the stretcher lurched over on its side throwing the 
wounded man against the head and shoulders of the spare fiJe^vho 
assisted as best he could at the side ... on the other side of the 
crossing the same difficulties tvere encountered. . . . And through 
tills hell passed 12 stretchers, la wounded men who -were by now 
gangrenous, delirious and half-mad, 48 gallantmenwhocarried the 
stretchers, 24 others who accompanied them. ... I must have 
stood and squatted in my position in the stream water for over an 
hour while the labours of the men and the sufferings of the ivounded 
went on before my eyes in a slowly moving picture of unforgettable 
misery.!

Chapter 30 

January-February, 1^42. Singapore Island ‚Äî Icyout of defences and 
disposition of garrison ‚Äî Japanese land under heavy bombardment 
wedge driven in defences. 

T he Island of Singapore is 15 miles from north to south and 26 
miles from east to "west with an area of about 220 square miles, 
roughly the size and shape of the Isle of Wight. On the north and 
west the island is separated from the mainland by the Straits of 
Johore which at the Putri Narrows near the north-west corner of the 
island are 700 yards wide. Near the causeway the straits are just 
over 1,000 yards wide. 

The greater part of the island was under rubber or covered with a 
scruffy type of jungle. The surface is imdulating v/ith many low small 
hills of which the highest point Bukit Timah, almost in the middle, 
rises to 581 feet. Communications were good. There was abundance of 
^cellent metalled roads and therewere many unmetalled estate roads. 
The main line of the railway crossed the Johore Causeway and went on 
down the middle of the island to the port and city of Singapore. 

The coastline of the western half of the island is almost entirely 
low and fringed with wide areas of mangrove swamp inset with 
numerous navigable creeks. The northern coastline of the eastern 
h^ of the island is similar. From Changi peninsula to Pasir Panjang 
five miles west of Singapore on the south the coastline is more or less 
regular with extensive sandy beaches and very little mangrove. The 
sea edges of the mangrove swamps could not be covered by direct or 
observed fire. 

The civilian population of the island at the time of the campaign 
was over 800,000 of whom two-thirds were Chinese. This was at least 
a quarter of a million in excess of the peacetime population. 

When the Supreme Commander arrived from India on January 
gth he ordered tliat plans for the defence of the island against 
attack from the mainland and the construction of defences should be 
urgently imdertaken. Until this date plans for defence had been 
based on repelling sea-borne attacks on the island and holding land 
attacks in Johore or farther north. Littie or nothing had been done 
to put the northern side of the island into a state of defence apart 
from arrangements to blow the causeway. 



ASSAULT ON SINGAPORE ISLAND 377 

On January 20th, the ChieE of Staff in London, with the grim 
and desperate deediness of a man who has suddenly woken up after 
oversleeping himself, brought to the notice of Malaya Command 
points of importance that would require attention if the troops on 
the mainland should be forced to withdraw to the island. 

Among these points were the use of fortress guns against landward 
attacks, the obstruction of land approaches to the straits and landing 
places, the diversion of some of the beach defences and machine- 
gun posts from the south to the north of the island, the control of 
boats and small craft, the creation of self-contained defensive 
localities and switch lines, measures against surprise night landings, 
the defence of aerodromes against air-borne attacks, the dispersal 
and control of the civil population, the suppression of fifth column 
activity, the use of personnel in fixed defences for tasks in local defence 
schemes, and the development of a good signal communications 
system within the fortress and to aerodromes in use in southern 
Sumatra, 

Most of these arrangements were already in hand, and the com- 
pletion of arrangements to defend Singapore Island was being 
urged on Malaya Command by Wavell after his visit on January 
gth. It will be remembered that on January ist the Chiels of Staff 
had drawn Auchinleck‚Äôs attention to the fact that the defence of 
Singapore was second only in importance to the defence of the 
United Kingdom itself. 

Mr Churchill‚Äôs account of these days is not available at the time 
when these words are being written. It may clarify what seems a 
nightmare of indecision, cross-purposes and myopia at home. 
General Percival, writing with considerable restraint and anxious 
not to give the impression of being too much concerned with his own 
reputation, says:^ 

The fact that no defences had been constructed on the north 
and west coasts of the island in pre-war days, and only limited 
defences even after the war started, has been the subject of much 
cridcal comment even in the highest quarters. It has been imputed 
to a lack of foresight on the part of successive general officers 
conunanding. Such criticism is most unjust. In the first place, 
general officers commanding had no authority to construct 
defences when or where they liked. The defences of Singapore 
were built up in accordance with a War Office plan, though of 
course recommendations of the local commander always received 
consideration. Then there was the quesdon of the object of the 

^ The War in Malaya, p. 254. 



378 EASTERN EPIC. 

defences. It was quite definitely the protection of. the Naval 
Base ‚Äî not the defence of Singapore Island. Now a very ordinary 
principle of warfare is tliat you site your defence in advance of 
the object to be protected; the distance in advance depends upon 
the range of the enemy‚Äôs weapons and increases as that rtmge 
becomes gre.atcr. Tlic Naval Base itself lies on the north shore of 
Singapore Island, and it would have been sheer lolly to have sited 
the defences also on the shores of that island allowing the enemy 
to bomb, shell, and machine-gun the Naval Base at svill. It would 
have been very nice no doubt to have had defences there in 
addition to Umse up-country, but finance prohibited that. As has 
already been stated, the expenditure on the defences in Malaya 
was always strictly controlled from home, and such money as was 
made available, apart from the defences on die south coast of the 
fortress, was of course spent, and quite righdy so, on defence 
works on the mainland. Even for these works there was never 
sufficient money available. 

It may be observed at tins point that in 1939 the managers of the 
Japanese estates which covered southern Johore had gone in for road 
building on a grand scale and that all these roads led to the coast of 
Johore. In the two years before the Japanese struck a convenient 
wealtli of motorablc roads was prepared for the attack on Singapore. 
Alas, in Whitehall tiie will to believe that Japan would not enter 
the war was too fervid for anybody to pay undue attention to 
intelligence reports of a disagreeable nature. Moreover, any attempt 
to prevent the construction of these roads would have upset die 
attitude of appeasement diat was laid down as our policy toward 
Japan. 

The fortress guns of the heaviest calibre in die fixed defences had 
an all round traverse, and many of die other fixed defence guns had 
arcs of fire over the mainland. So the gibe diat all the guns on the 
island were pointing the wrong way is not endrely true. 

However, the ammunition for the 15-inch guns was all armour 
piercing and die g ‚Ä¢ a-inch guns had only 85 rounds of high explosive 
to each gun. Therefore they were practically useless for offensive 
artillery action against the mainland. 

The food situation for the whole garrison after the withdrawal 
across die causeway and the arrival of all expected reinforcements 
was satisfactory. There was meat for three months, flour and tinned 
vegetables for four months, and enough other items for five months. 
The stocks of food for the civil population were enough for four 
months, with flour for six months and meat for nine months which 
could have been used to supplement army stocks. 



ASSAULT ON SINGAPORE ISLAND 379 

There was ammunition for pistols and Thompson sub-machine 
guns for I a days, for .55 anti-tank rifles for 23 days, for '303 rifles, 
grenades and mortars for six weeks, and for artillery for over three 
months; but it was calculated that there would be no reserve stocks 
of weapons and no spares when units had drawn arms to replace 
losses on the mainland. 

Much of the water supply for Singapore Island had depended on 
the Gunong Pulai catchment area in south Johore which was now in 
enemy hands. However, on the island itself there was a catchment 
area of 6,000 acres and there were two large reservoirs, MacRitchie 
and Peirce, wliich could provide 14,500,000 gallons daily. The loss 
of the 15,000,000 from the mainland would entail a measure of 
rationing. Moreover, the distributing pipes were close to the surface 
of the ground and easily put out of order by bombing from the air. 

The three northern airfields at Tengah, Sembawang and Seletar 
were now within range of observed artillery fire from the mainland, 
and the only airfield sdll free from artillery but not from air bom- 
bardment was at Kallang close to the city of Singapore. All that was 
left of the fighter units except one flight of eight Hurricanes and one 
flight of eight Buffaloes had already been moved to Sumatra. These ‚ñ† 
were based on this civil airport, but they did not last long. 

The general plan for the defence of the island was to fight the 
enemy on the coastal perimeter wherever he might land. 

A word about reinforcements. The bulk of the two remaining 
brigades of the i8th (East Anglian) Division had landed at Singapore 
on January 29th, but the transport Empress of Asia bringing the last 
units was sunk by enemy aircraft off the north-west coast and all the 
arms and equipment of the troops were lost. Wavell has-been criti- 
cised for allowing the troops of the i8th Division soft after weeks of a 
sea-voyage and trained for desert warfare to disembark at Singapore 
as a forlorn hope, and -with our knowledge of what was to happen in 
Burma it is natural to regret that they were not diverted again to 
Rangoon, to which they had originally been diverted from the 
Middle East. The only alternative open to Wavell at the time was to 
use those two brigades of the i8th Division in the Dutch East Indies 
where they would have been as ineffective as they were in Singapore, 
and if Wavell had sent them to Batavia, -ivith doubtful Dutch co- 
operation, the critics . would probably have - declared that -their 
presence in Singapore might have turned the scale and averted 
capitulation. These remarks apply equally to the landing of the 
44th Indian Brigade consisting of the 6/jst Punjab Regt, the 7/8th 
Punjab Regt and the 6/i4th Punjab Regt commanded by Brigadier ,

shore defences, support lines, gun positions, wiring and underwater 
obstacles, in other words to try to make up in eight days for 14 years 
eaten by the locusts since Singapore had been erected into Britannia‚Äôs 
throne from which to rule the Far Eastern sea. At the same time the 
sappers of the division were prepaying demolitions in the naval base.

but out of sight of the troops whose morale at this time was high and 
who were ready to die in defence of those impressive installations. 

On February 5th the Japanese artillery which had been preparing 
for action opened with unexpected weight. 

According to the Japanese sources already quoted it ‚Äòis said to 
have been the heaviest concentradon of fire ever put up by the 
Japanese Army. The guns used were of all calibres, but the main 
punch came from modern 240 mm. howitzers which had been 
specially built for this very purpose ... for three days the ardllery 
duel went on, and all the while Japanese bombers droned overhead 
in successive waves, unopposed by any enemy airplanes; and after 
the first day, with litdc if any and-aircraft fire to bother them.‚Äô 

This suggests a greater weakness in and-aircraft ardllery than in 
fact there was. 

For two days and three nights the artillery bombardment was 
concentrated on the naval base, the gun posidons and observadon 
posts of the 135th Field Regt, and of the 27th Australian Brigade on 
the left flank of the 28th Indian Brigade. 

The Hertfordshire Yeomen and the Sikhs of the 4th Mountain 
Battery replied gloriously. The cables of the 135th Fidd Regt were 
repeatedly cut, but communicadon between the guns and observadon 
posts was never interrupted. Lieut.-CoIonel Toosey liad spent many, 
months in England waidng for the Germans. He had duplicate 
and quadruplicate lines which the regimental signallers by night and 
day were repairing under fire. 

Not a single forward observadon officer abandoned his O.P. 
Jemadar Jogindar Singh of the 4th Mountain Battery and Lieut. 
Skene of the 135th Fidd Regt had an O.P. on Bukit Mandai, and 
the overhanging rock above reedved 25 direct hits by heavy shells. 
Neverthdess, the two officers remained calm and directed thecounter- 
battery fire of their own gxms so accuratdy that the enemy‚Äôs guns 
shelling the naval base were temporarily silenced on two or three 
occasions. 

Lieut.-Colond Toosey inspired all his men by his courageous 
direcdon and never ^vas a D.S.O. better earned. He was well backed 
up by his divisional commander who, when the original scale of 
20 rounds per gun a day for harassing fire was halved on February 
7th, used his discredon liberally to authorise a much higher expen-

with brigade. The enemy bombardment had destroyed all beach

Percival had good reason to be worried. Injustice to the Australian 
infantry it must be borne in mind that the a /19th Battalion had been 
shattered in the Muar fighting and that it now contained a large 
proportion of untrained reinforcements. This was also true of the 
a/agth Battalion which had been taken from the 27th Australian 
Brigade as 22nd Brigade reserve. The weight of the Japanese attack 
was formidable. It was learned later that 13,000 troops were 
landed on the island during the night of February S/gth and another 
10,000 shortly after dawn. 

The only reserve Percival had was Paris‚Äôs weak 12th Indian 
Brigade and even if he had not waited till 8.30 a.m. of February gth 
before he moved it forward to come under Gordon Bennett‚Äôs 
command, 250 Argylls, 150 Royal Marines and 440 4th Hyderabads, 
many of them newly arrived reinforcements, would not have affected 
the issue. 

The 44th Indian Brigade had repulsed an attempted landing by 
the enemy on its right in the creek of the River Bireh, but it was not 
engaged again. Percival debated the possibility of using this brigade 
to attack Ae Japanese right flank, but finally decided in agreement 
with Gordon Bennett to fall back to the left of the front it was 
proposed to establish between the head of the Kranji Creek, which 
had divided the 22nd Australian Brigade fron the 27 th, and the River 
Jurong. The withdrawal from the coast was effected that evening. 
The Kranji-Jurong position was not selected: it was the line to 
which the a2nd Australian Brigade had already been driven back. 

The 6/r5th Indian Brigade now commanded by Brigadier Coates 
was taken out of III Indian Corps and placed under Gordon Bennett‚Äôs 
orders. It was to move to a position on the Bukit Timah road near the 
racecourse with the object of denying to the enemy the petrol and 
food dumps east of Bukit Timah. 

By dusk the Japanese were in possession of the Tengah airfield 
which had been held by troops of the Jind Infantry, a good unit' 
of the Indian States Forces. It may be observed here that the 
defence of aerodromes in Malaya entrusted to the Mysore, Jind, 
Bawahalpur and Kapurthala States Forces never had the faintest 
prospect of success; it was merely one more of those liabilities with 
which the R.A.F. loaded the Army.

At dawn of February iith unaware that the counter-attack had 
been cancelled they captured their objective and by doing so found 
themselves in Japanese territory completely cut off. An attempt was 
made to march by compass to a position where there had been a 
British division, and for two days they marched by night and lay 
low by day with such Httle food as they could find until on. the morn-

original objective in the cancelled coimter-attacb. For two more days 
and nights they marched and layup tmtil on the night of February 
15th the Japanese guns were silent. 

On the afternoon of February i6th when it was clear that Singa- 
pore had capitulated a durbar was called for ail British officers and

V.C.O.‚Äôs at which it was decided that the main body should surren-

free to do so. The British officers, with the subadar-major and the 
two jemadars, succeeded after a series of strange and perilous 
adventures in reaching Sumatra. It may be asked why at least two 
of the British officers did not remain in charge of those who elected

an attempt to escape, and in the circumstances there was no point in 
any British officers marching the men in merely to surrender. This 
was the argument used by Lieut.-General Gordon Bennett, and it 
could be maintained that the moral responsibility of a lieutenant 
and a lieutenant-general for the men under their command differs 
only quantitatively. It is not for the writer to express an opinion. 

The situation was pretty desperate by nightfall of February i ith. 
A wavy line ran from the southern banks of the MacRitchic reservoir 
to the Chinese High School and from there to the Reformatory 
School and on to Pasir Panjang, if the perforations that hold together 
a sheet of stamps can be called a line. 

That day the Indian Base Hospital at Tyersall, which was a 
hutted camp, caught fire. The survivors of the Argylls and Marines 
spent the rest of the day rescuing hundreds of wounded from blazing 
huts, but about aoo of the wounded were burnt to death. 

In the evening a Special Order of the Day dated February loth 
reached the defenders of Singapore from Wavell: 

It is certain that our troops on Singapore Island heavily out- 
number any Japanese who have crossed the Straits. We must 
destroy them. 

Our whole fighting reputation is at stake and the honour of the 
British Empire, The Americans have held out in the Bataan 
Peninsula against far heavier odds; die Russians are turning back , 
the picked strength of the Germans; the Chinese, with almost a 
complete lack of modern equipment, have held back the Japanese 
for four and a half years. It will be disgraceful if we &gt;'ield our 
boasted Fortress of Singapore to inferior enemy forces. 

There must be no thought of sparing the- troops or civilian 
populadon, and no mercy must be shown to weakness in any 
shape or form. Commanders and senior officers must lead their 
troops and if necessary die with them. There must be no question 
or thought of surrender. Every unit must fight it out to the end and 
in close contact widi the enemy. 

Please see that the above is brought to the nodce of all Senior 
. Officers and by them to the troops. 



396 EASTERN EPIC 

I look to you and to your men to fight to the end to prove that 
the fighting spirit that won our Empire still exists to enable us to 
defend it. 

It is questionable whether at the time General Wavell wrote that 
order of the day he had realised the weight of the Japanese attack. 
He was presently to learn from bitter experience how swift was to be 
tire collapse of the Netherlands East Indies and how bloody the cost 
of a Burma as ill prepared to resist aggression as was Malaya. Tim 
order of the day was not ‚Äòfeatured‚Äô at home, but it was published in 
several papers and its publication gave the world an entirely false 
impression of the Malayan Campaign. 

There may have been 85,000 British, Indian and Australian 
troops on the island, but by the time this order of the day %yas 
issued the great bulk of those 85,000 consisted of administrative 
imits and half-trained troops soft after long voyages. There was 
indeed a scarcity of troops to resist the three crack seasoned Japanese 
divisions which, wth two and possibly three reserve divisions of 
firesh well-trained troops on the mainland, had landed tvith 175 
tanks under the drumfire of a powerful mass of artillery and with the 
support of 700 first-line aircr^t with which there was not a fighter 
left to interfere. 

The Prime Minister in a speech to the Home of . Commons in 
secret session stated that too,ooo British and Colonial troops in 
Singapore had surrendered to 30,000 Japanese. He may have 
sincerely believed this at the time, but when the stress of mortified 
emotion had relaxed and more accurate information was available 
he made no attempt to correct his mistake, nor did he mention the 
complete domination of the air by the Japanese. 

It does not suggest an overwhelming superiority in numbers to 
find that an infantry battalion had been hastily got together on that 
evening the order of the day was received under the command of 
Iieut.-Colonel Taylor R.E. consisting of Madras and Bombay Sap- 
pers and Miners who throughout the ivithdrawal had served the 1 1 th 
Indian Division with unfailing gallantry and skill. This battalion 
was sent to reinforce the 44th Indian Brigade and hold a sector of 
the Reformatory Road area. 

The comparison of what was happening in Singapore with what the 
Americans, Russians and Chinese were doing was certainly unjust 
and possibly injudicious. The Americans in the Bataan Peninsula 
, were outnumbered, but they did not have to fight any crack Japa- 
nese troops until after Singapore had fallen when many of those 
seasoned troops tyere transferred to the Philippines. Moreover, the 



SURRENDER' OF SINGAPORE 397 

terrain favoured the defenders on the Bataan Peninsula because it 
compelled the Japanese to attack frontally and the encircling tactics 
they used in Malaya were not feasible with secure flanks. Finally the 
Americans had for a last stand a genuine fortress in Corregidor. 

The last stand in Singapore would have to be made in a swarming 
city the unfortunate inhabitants of which were being killed at the 
rate of over 2,000 a day by Japanese bombs, the water of which was 
failing, and the prospect of which was a liideom massacre by the 
Japanese if the maddened enemy broke through. 

Neither of the other two comparisons is relevant to the situation 
in Singapore. Neither Russia nor China is the size of the Isle of 
Wight. 

From the garrison‚Äôs point of view Wavell was on the edge of 
absurdity when he spoke of the disgrace of yielding our boasted 
Fortress of Singapore to inferior enemy forces. Who boasted that 
Singapore was a Fortress? Not the luckless commanders of the 
Indian units, not the sepoys, not the lads from Norfolk and Suffolk 
and Cambridgeshire, and certainly not the Australians when they 
saw it. The boasting was done on instructions from home. The troops 
were like the poor dog who went to the cupboard for a bone; 
when they got there they found Britannia dressed up like Old 
Mother Hubbard and not less vague about the situation. 

So much having been said, let it be added with all emphasis that 
Wavell was throughout these days moral and physical courage 
incarnate and that the impression he made on all ranks was deep and 
abiding. 

Of him may be said what Tacitus said of Agricola: 

Quidquid ex Agricola amavimus, quidquid mirati sumus, 
manet mansurumque est in animis hominum, in aeternitate 
temporum, in faraa rerum. 

What we have loved in Wavell, what we have admired, abides 
and will abide in the hearts of men, in the procession of the ages, ' 
in the records of history;

In some units the troops have not shown the fighting spirit 
which is to be expected of men of the British Empire. 

It will be a lasting disgrace if we are defeated by an army of

spirit of aggression and determination to stick it out must be 
inculcated in all ranks. There must be no further thought of 
withdrawal wthout orders.

There are too many fighting men moving about in back areas. 
Every available man who is not doing other essential work must 
be used to stop the invader. 

We may view with abhorrence the bestial cruelty of the Japanese 
to their prisoners, we may be nauseated by their revolting lack of 
humour, but the last word we can apply to them as soldiers' is 
‚Äògangsters,‚Äô Not since Sparta has the world seen such selfless warriors, 
and their final defeat in Burma by the Fourteenth Army must count 
as a martial achievement second to none in the story of Imperial 
Britain and second to none in the campaigns of the vastest war 
mankind has so far suffered.

On February 16th the following Special Order of the Day was 
issued by Lieut.-General Percival: 

It has been necessary to give up the struggle, but I want the 
reasons explained to all ranks. The forward troops continue to 
hold their ground, but the essentials of war have run short. In a 
few days we shall have neither petrol nor food. Many types of 
ammunition are short, and the water supply, on which the vast 
civilian population and many of the troops are dependent, 
threatens to fail. This situation has been brought about partly by 
hostile air and artillery action. Without these sinews of war we 
cannot fight on. I thank all ranks for their efforts throughout this 
campaign. 

There is no doubt whatever that Percival‚Äôs decision to surrender 
when he did was the only decision possible. 

Here is an extract from a Japanese account of the last moments; 

The enemy still continued to fire stubbornly at the advancing

Before we pass to the equally tragic story of the Japanese mv^ion 
of Burma it may be as well to muster a few facts about the posiuon 
in the South-West Pacific. 

On December 8th 1941 the Allied land forces in mat 
amounted to the equivalent of eight divisions to deal with w ^ 
the Japanese had some 26 divisions within striking range. Durmg 
the campaign the Japanese usually had about three battles upsj 
28 cruisers, seven aircraft carriers, 71 destroyers, four sea-plane 
carriers and 34 submarines in the South-West Pacific and adjacen 
areas. 

After the loss of the battleship Prince of Wales and^ the battle- 
cruiser Repulse the Naval Commander-in-Chief was left in control 0 
Allied naval units amounting to one heavy cruiser, eight hght 
cruisers, two sloops, 23 destroyers and 36 submarines- Most of the 
British ships and some of the Dutch and United States ships were 
constantly employed on convoy escort and cover. 

Besides the British air force (and the U.S. air force in the Phihp- 
pines the numbers of which are not kno^m at the time of writing; 
there were six Dutch bomber squadrons and four fighter squadrons 
in the Netherlands East Indies. Against these the Japanese could call 
on 1,300 first line aircraft in the S.W. Pacific area of which about , 
300 were on their aircraft carriers. The Japanese naval and army air ' 
forces for the Malayan Campaign consisted of the 22nd Air Flotilla 
numbering 150 aircraft and the 3rd Flying Division numbering 550- 

After the Chiefs of Staff announced on January ist 1942 those , 
Netv Year‚Äôs resolutions of His Majesty‚Äôs Government which have 
already been quoted,^ the strategic result of them was the collapse of 
the offensive in Cyrenaica and the loss of Malaya and Burma, 
because they led to nothing more than tire piecemeal arrival of 
reinforcements too little and too late to influence the main issue. 

Several ships of the British, Dutch and U.S. naval reinforcements 
ordered to the South-West Pacific Command failed to arrive. Two 
cruisers arrived early in the campaign and two at the end of Feb-

ruary. There was also a reinforcement of five destroyers and three 
submarines. The 53rd British Brigade and the 45th Indian Brigade 
arrived early in January 1942. The former was equipped and par- 
tially trained for the jMiddle East, reallotted to tlie defence of Burma 
and diverted at sea to Malaya. The latter was without artillery or

On January 23rd one Australian machine-gun battalion and 

2.000 reinforcements for die 8th Australian Division reached 
Singapore. Their equipment and what training they had had was 
for the Middle East and many of them had not yet fired even a rifle. 

On January 25th arrived the 44di Indian Brigade from India 
equipped like the 45di Brigade and partially trained for the Middle

In the middle of January 232 Fighter Squadron R.A.F. reached 
Singapore with 51 obsolescent Hurricanes and 24 pilots most of 
whom were reserve pilots widiout batde experience. The gallantry 
of these young men could not save that squadron from swiftly 
being destroyed. 48 Hurricanes of a later model were flown off the 
carrier Formidable into Singapore on January 26th and were used to 
equip two of the original five fighter squadrons in Malaya. What 
were left of them had to be flown to Sumatra when the enemy 
had practically destroyed the Singapore airfields. 39 Hurricanes 
reached Batavia on January 31st and were assembled by 605 
Fighter Squadron, which was one of three squadrons jiist arrived in 
Singapore without aircraft. Anti-aircraft reinforcements mostly 
reached thC Dutch islands after the fall of Singapore. 

It seems likely that history will declare that February 15th 1942 
was the beginning of the end of European domination throughout 
the East. 

One immediate result of the capitulation %vas to expose some 

45.000 Indian troops to Japanese influence. On February 17th the 

45,000 Indian ranks in Singapore were separated from their British 
and Australian comrades and handed over to the Japanese in Farrar 
Park as prisoners of war. 

After a formal ceremony the assembled men were exhorted to join 
an Indian National Army by Captain Mohan Singh who was taken 



404 EASTERN EPIC 

prisoner by the Japanese on December 15th 1941 after the i/i4th 
Punjab Regt was overrun at Asun in that tempest of rain. 

About 5,000 men refused to break their oath of allegiance. The 
remainder dazed by the Singapore disaster and the apparent end of 
two centuries of British leadership in the Indian Army succumbed to 
the effect of moral persuasion and physical coercion, together wth 
a campaign of terrorism ruthlessly conducted against them for the 
next four months. 

No more will be said at present about the Indian National Army 
except to insist that the freedom of India and Pakistan was won not 
by the Indian National Army but by the two and a quarter millions 
of Indian volunteers, who besides playing such a great part in defeat- 
ing the Germans and the Italians, played the chiefpart in defeating 
the Japanese on land and thereby did as much to destroy Japanese 
confidence in ultimate victory as even the mighty achievements of 
the United States Navy. Nevertheless, it would be wilful blindness 
not to recognise the influence of the Indian National Army on 
political opinion in India, by giving it a military self-consciousness 
of which it had not dreamed since the Great Mutiny. 

And those Indian soldiers who had beheld the British Raj seem- 
ingly impotent against Japan in Malaya were to hear presently of 
equal impotence in Burma, an impotence which might open the 
direct road to freedom for India when throughout the East freedom 
from European domination was in the hearts of millions of Asians, 
It may be the verdict of history that Singapore was lost in Whitehall 
before a shot was fired in the Malayan Campaign, and that may be 
the verdict about the First Burma Campaign on the tragedy of which 
the curtain now rises.

O N April ist 1937, following on a report of the Indian Statutory 
Commission of 1930 (the Simon Commission) and the decision 
of Parliament in the U nited Kingdom, Burma ceased to be a province 
under the Government of India and was constitutionally separated 
from India. Until tliat date, as far as India was responsible for her 
own defence, the defence of Burma had been India‚Äôs responsibility. 
Between 1931 and 1936 the Government of India consulted with its 
local government in Burma about the defence of Burma after the 
impending separation. In July 1936 the Viceroy made his recom- 
mendations on Burma‚Äôs land defence to His Majesty‚Äôs Government. 
Nine months later the Government of India was no longer responsible 
for that defence, but tvas conditionally committed to reinforce 
Burma in an emergency. 

Before separation there were no distinct establishments in Burma 
for local naval and air defence. Provision for these after separation 
was to be settled between H.M. Government and the Government 
of Burma. India was notified that Burma would imdertake the 
protection of Imperial air routes through Burma, and of airfields as 
far as possible with the land forces at her disposal, but that it was not 
considered necessary to maintain a permanent air force in Burma for 
internal security or against local aggression on her frontiers. India 
was further notified that Burma, unable to maintain forces of her 
own for local naval defence, would rely on Singapore preferably for 
reinforcement and failing Singapore on India, 

India reminded Burma that sufficient airfields were essential for 
air reinforcement and the accumulation of armaments and main- 
tenance equipment most important. The Government of India 
considered that the local naval defence of India and Burma was a 
single strategic problem and that it could not be undertaken from 
Singapore. The Government of India would prefer to be responsible 
for the local naval defence of Burma at the expense of the latter. 
Control over all the armed forces in Burma was vested in the Gover- 
nor with the administrative help of a Defence Department, but there 



4o6 eastern epic , 

was little difference between the armed forces for land defence before 
and after separadon. The civil force of Burma Military Police was 
reorganised, two-thirds of it being allotted to a Burma Frohder 
Force commanded by an Inspector General under the Governor; 
the other third was allotted to internal law and order under the 
Home Minister. 

The Army in Burma commanded by a general officer under the 
Governor comprised; 

1 Headquarters Army in Burma, which was about the same 
size as the former Headquarters Burma District. 

2 Headquarters Rangoon Brigade Area. 

3 Two British infantry battalions. Four Burma Rifles bat- 
talions, each with its own training company for recruits. ^ 

4 One Indian mountain battery and one field company Indian 
Sappers and JVIiners. Both ffiese were on loan from India 
and the latter was to be replaced by a company of Burma 
Sappers and Miners in 1940. 

5 A minimum of ancillary units and services without provision 
for second line transport. 

6 One battalion of the Burma Territorial Force. 

These military forces were expanded between 1939 and the end of 
1941, but the additional strength was impaired by defects inherent 
in the organisation as it stood before separation. The small and 
independent military command now set up had been carved out of 
the experienced Indian organisation with its comparatively large 
resources; adequate though this may have been for peacetime 
conditions it was quite inadequate to deal \vith the expansion im- 
posed by a great war. The officers were drawn from the British 
service and the Indian Army with little hope of reinforcement in 
time of war except for the untrained resources of Burma. Before the 
outbreak of war %vith Japan and for some time afterwards Burma 
Army Headquarters was simultaneously a War Office, a G.H.Q,., a 
Corps H.Q_. and an L. of G. Area H.Q_. Matters of detail could have 
been worked out more quickly and efficiently by G.H.Q,. in India 
if the Army in Burma had been placed for command and general 
administration under the India Command. As it was, up to Novem- 
ber 1940 Burma was directly under the War Office at home; it was 
then placed under Far Eastern Command at Singapore. Neither 
arrangement even bordered upon common sense, but although three 
times in 1940 and 1941 successive commanders-in-chief urged the 
authorities in the United Kdngdom to place Burma within India 



DEFENCES OF BURMA 


407 

Coiamaiid, it was not done until December 15th by which time it 
was too late. 

A word about overland communications between India and 
Burma. For many years the construction of a railway had from time 
to time been discussed, but commercial interests were against it and 
military interests were much more concerned with communications 
on the North-West Frontier. 

On May itth 1936 the Viceroy Lord Linlithgowwith trulyremark- 
able prcsciencc*^ wrote to Sir Robert Cassells, the Commander-in- 
Chief, about the possibility of a Japanese invasion of Burma; 

. . . The position becomes infinitely more anxious if and when 
British naval forces based on Singapore are crippled or beaten. 
My contention is that . . . the first and most vital precaution that 
is witliin our power to effect is the construction of proper- com- 
munication by land bet^veen Bengal and Burma. I suppose it will 
be agreed that this should take the form either of a double-track 
standard-guage railway, or of an adequate military road. . . 
Even though the initial landing and occupation of Birrma by the 
Japanese were successfully accomplished, sucli an Indo-Burma 
railway or road would render possible the effeedve employment 
in Burma of tire Army in India, whether or not the control of the 
Bay of Bengal were in enemy hands.

When during 1941 the threat to India from Japan was approach- 
ing nearer the War OfBce could not get it into perspective. Spasmo- 
dic air raids were the most serious threat that seemed likely to the 
Chiefs of Staff Committee in London, and Far East Command must 
have first claim on air reinforcement. We have heard the melancholy 
tale of the way in which Far East Command was in fact reinforced. 
As for India, when Japan struck in December 1941, owing to her 
effort to help Malaya she had less aircraft tlian a year before. So when 
the air bases in Burma were captured the North-East of India was 
exposed to air attack on a serious scale. 

In November 1941 General Wavell, now Commander-in-Chief 
India, visited Burma; so dangerous did he consider the situation 
then that, although Burma was not under India Command, he 
ordered the despatch to Burma of another Indian infantry brigade 
and took up the now urgent question of building a road from Assam 
to Burma. 

Before going any further it may be as well to return for a moment 
to that quesdon of India‚Äôs control over military operations and 
administradon in Burma. 

Undl September 1940 Burma was under the War Office, In that 
month operational control was transferred to Far East Command 
which had no interest in Burma except as an air reinforcement 
route to Singapore. Administration remained with the War Office, 
In October' 1940, Auchinleck, who was then C.-in-G. India, made an 
effort to have Burma put operationally and administratively under 
India to ensure a single plan of defence for botli; he was unsuccessful. 
In September 1941 Wavell, now C.-in-G. India, during a visit to 
England made another effort to secure the change, but the Chiefs of 
Staff again rejected his plea on the grounds that the whole question 
had been fully considered when Far East Command was set up. 
By this time the Japanese had already invaded Indo-China, and that 
was a direct threat to Burma. Nevertheless, London was determined 
to sit on a fence and smile at what hir Churchill called ‚Äòthe inscrut- 
able glare‚Äô^ of Japan. 

On his return to India Wavell, visited Burma and Malaya where 
he found the civil and military authorities in both most anxious for 
India to assume responsibility for Burma. Accordingly on November 
I ith 1941 in a cable to the C.I.G.S. he once again recommended the 
transfer of Burma to the India Command. He pointed out that the 
defence of Burma, was vital to India but'not to Malaya. An enemy in 
occupation of Burma could bomb the principal munition factories in

India and the oilfields in Assam. Land reinforcement of Burma must 
come from India, and if India received the promised air forces air

were only some of the arguments which Wavell used. They failed to

However, a few days after Japan entered the war Burma was

in spite of his strong recommendation that the defence of Burma

new South-West Pacific Command (Abdacom). 

In his Despatch of July ist 1942 General Wavell wrote; 

From my headquarters in Java, 2,000 miles distant from Ran- 
goon, and concerned as I was with an immense area and many 
international problems, it ^vas impossible for me to give as 
close attention to the defence of Burma as was desirable; nor 
had I any reinforcements at my disposal to aid Burma. They 
must come entirely from India. Moreover, administration of the 
forces in Burma had necessarily to be conducted from India; 
and it is always wrong to separate operational and administrative 
responsibility. 

He could have added to this that communication between Abda- 
com and Burma, even by wireless, was irregular, inaccurate and 
slow. The unfortunate G.O.C. in Burma, Lieut.-General Hutton^ 
hardly ever received a message with any bearing on the actual 
situation and at the same time he was receiving messages from the 
War Office about the defence of Rangoon which contradicted those 
he received from Wavell. 

For six weeks this wretched handicap, Ibr which on all the evidence 
the War Cabinet and the Chiefs of Staff bear the grave responsibility, 
was obtusely imposed. Then Abdacom closed down, and on Febru- 
ary 23rd 1942 Burma was again placed under the India Command, 
to which Wavell returned on February 27th as Commander-in-Chief.

N O other division will grudge to the Black Cats of the 17th 
Indian Infantry Division the right to believe itself primus inter 
pares in Burma during the Second World War. It was the first to 
arrive in December 1941 and the last to leave when Burma‚Äôs in- 
dependence was recognised in 1947. It suffered heavy disaster in its 
earliest days to win an immortal renown in victory. 

The 17th Indian Division was raised in the summer of 1941 
Major-General H. V. Lewis and it was trained and equipped for the 
Middle East, being due to sail for Iraq in December 1941. Every 
battalion was Indian and every one was raised from new units. Of 
the artillery regiments one was British, the other Indian. All the 
transport was mechanised, and what wireless equipment there was 
was in lorries. The troops had done no training with the air, there 
being no aircraft in India for such luxuries. 

At the beginning of December while it was training at Poona the 
division was taken over by Major-General J. G. Smyth V.C.,^ who 
had raised the igth Indian Division at Secunderabad in October 
t 94 t&gt; from old battalions of the Indian Army most of whicli had 
been on the North-West Frontier since the beginning of the war. The 
19th Dagger Division was one day to win much glory in Burma. 

The 45th was the first brigade of the 1 7th Division to embark at 
Bombay, and as we know after sailing for Basra it was diverted to 
Malaya to be shattered in the Muar fighting. The 44th Brigade 
which followed it to Malaya fought in Singapore and became 
prisoners of war.

followed divisional headquarters in January 1942 soon after the

It may be wondered how the division was in action before its 
only remaining brigade reached Burma. The answer is that Jones‚Äô 
i6th Indian Brigade was allotted to the 17th Division, together with

Burma is the shape of a sting-ray ‚Äî a great squat lozenge with a 
long tail. The north-west facet looks to Assam, the northerly apex 
touches Tibet, tlic nortli-east facet abuts on China; the easterly 
front and south-east facets look to Siam; the south-west and westerly 
facets look outinto the Bay of Bengal. The tail province of Tenasserim 
shared the istJimus between Burma and Malaya until Siam took all 
the southern half and thereby prevented Burma from having any 
common frontier with Malaya. The mighty Salween flowing south- 
ward from beyond Lhasa with jungle-clad mountains west of it 
seemed to offer an impassable barrier to invasion from the east. The 
dark gorges of this rapid and mysterious stream have never been 
navigated to its source; it had only one bridge where tire single 
motorable road from Siam crossed the frontier at Tacliilek in the pro- 
vince of Kengtung and, traversing the Southern Shan States, joined 
the main Rangoon-Mandalay road at Mciktila. Strategic opinion 
had always supposed that in the event of a most improbable invasion 
of Burma by the Japanese in force such an invasion would have to 
follow this long road rather than the shorter but difficult tracks far- 
ther soutli. Therefore until such time as the Chinese armies, of which 
more in due course, could assume responsibility for the Shan States 
the tst Burma Division commanded by Major-General Bruce Scott^ 
and made up of two Burma Brigades and Curtis‚Äôs 13th Indian 
Brigade were on guard over this part of the front. 

Almost immediately after December 8th 1941 the Japanese 
occupied Victoria Point and its airfield at the tip of the Burmese 
tail, from which presently the airfields at Mergui and Tavoy were 
bombed. Rangoon was raided on December, 23rd and 25th. The 
material damage was insignificant, but in the first raid over a, 000 
people were killed, and the moral damage done was tremendous. 
There was a large and hasty exodus from Rangoon, and work in 
the port for some time almost completely stopped, so much of the 
Indian labour having fled. The Japanese lost many aircraft thanks 
to the American Tomahawks to whose dauntless pilots Wavell paid 
such a warm tribute. 

* Major-General J. Bruce Scott, C,B., D.S.O., M.C. (6th and 8th Gurkha Rifles). 



418. EASTERN EPIC' 

By the time Lieut.-General Hutton assumed command on 
December 27th it had become clear that the Japanese were prepar- 
ing to invade Tenasserim in some strength and all reinforcements 
reaching Burma were sent to that area so vital to the security of 
Rangoon. 

Early in January Hutton wrote an appreciation of the general 
situation in Burma which forecast the manner of the Japanese 
attack with remarkable accuracy. It pointed out the advantages to 
the enemy of an advance through Tenasserim with a clear grasp of 
his possible strength, mobility and tactical methods. Hutton seemed 
as early as this to have understood all the implications of the Japa- 
nese success in Malaya during that December. He was also sharply 
aware of the advantage of promptly using the Chinese Fifth and 
Sixth Armies, whose help had been offered to us, because it would 
allow the British forces to be concentrated in Tenasserim. Hutton 
was not informed of the proposed diversion of the i8th Division and 
the 44th and 45th Indian Brigades to Malaya; but he never con- 
sidered it practicable to hold Tenasserim as far south as Mergui. 

We should use up troops in small packets of supporting distance 
of one another. With our present weakness in troops we must 
endeavour to concentrate as great a strength as possible at the 
really vital areas.^ 

Unfortunately Far East Command was still obsessed by the need 
to maintain the aerodromes of the reinforcement route, and to this 
mirage military advantage had to be sacrificed. Moreover, tlic 
effectiveness of the fighter aircraft available in Burma was dependent 
on the warning system in Tenasserim. Finally, enemy aircraft in the 
Tenasserim aerodromes might paralyse the port of Rangoon. 

So in the end there was no concentration behind the Salween in 
the Martaban-Bilin area, and troops were used up in small packets. 

When Major-General Smyth arrived early in January 194*^ 1 ^¬Æ 
foimd himself with the responsibility of about 800 miles of country 
\vith the i6th Indian Brigade in the dense Jungle of the Da%vna Hills 
some 80 miles east of Mouhnein and the 2nd Burma Brigadescattered 
about a large and uiunanageable extent of country. To be more 
precise, the i6th Brigade consisted actually of the i/7th Gurkha 
Rifles and the 4th Burma Rifles, the 4th Frontier Force Regt being 
with the. 2nd Burma Brigade to stiffen it and the ist Jat Regt being 
still in Moulmein, in which Smyth set up his divisional headquarters.

Mergui and aoo miles north of them the 6th Burma Rifles were hold-

Smyth‚Äôs line of communication from Moulmein ran back by 
river steamer across the Gulf of Martaban, here four miles wide, to 
the rail and road head at Martaban through Thaton to Bilin and 
Kyaikto to the railway bridge over the Sittang River where the 
Burma Army took over. 

On January 17th the Mergui garrison was reduced by moving the 
two companies of the 3rd Burma Rifles to Tavoy where the situation 
was menacing. Mergui would be isolated if Tavoy fell. Finally the 
garrison was evacuated by sea to Rangoon after the aerodrome had 
been knocked about as much as possible and the stores destroyed. 

The Japanese invasion of Burma was led by the 55th Division less 
one regiment and it was closely fisllowed by the 33rd Division less 
one regiment. The former may have been a less seasoned division 
than the 33rd, which was a crack division of Chrysanthemum 
quality, but it was extremely well led. A Japanese regiment was the 
equivalent of one of our brigades and the fire and bayonet power of a 
Japanese rifle company was at least half as powerful again as one of 
ours. Every regiment of three battalions had a field or mountain 
artillery regiment of three batteries, each of three troops. Every troop 
had four 75 mm. guns. In addition to this every battalion had two 
70 nam. infantry guns and a machine-gun company. Rifle companies 
were armed with light machine-guns and 2'inch mortars. 

The 1 8th Chrysanthemum Division and the 56th Division with 
the remaining two regiments of the other divisions reached Rangoon 
in April. 

The Japanese received much help from the Siamese Army, al- 
though it did not take part in any serious fighting, being nsed for 
roudne dudes and thus allowing the Japanese to make the utmost 
aggressive use of their troops. There was hko the Burma Independent 
Army which did not fight in any battles but played the part of what 
in Eastern Europe were known as Pardsans. 

The Japanese struck at Tavoy on January ‚ñ† 15th. A forward 
position held by three companies of the newly raised 6th Burma 
Rifles disintegrated and by midday of January igih in spite of a 
stout resistance by the remnants of the 6th Burma Rifles and a 
detachment of the 5th Field Regt R.A. before they were overrun the 
town was in the hands of the enemy; his aircraft were landing on the 
aerodrome an hour later.

The Japanese did not continue due north. They crossed the fron-

railway of death. 

Jones, the commander of the i6th Brigade, had been ordered not 
to become involved in the risk of being cut off. Most of his troops 
were young and already shaken by enemy air-attacks. He was 
fighting in dense jungle which helped the Japanese to exploit their 
favourite tactics of by-passing on a wide front in superior numbers 
any position he held. So on the night of January at /22nd Jones

Kawkareik covered by the ist Royal Jat Rcgt. The mechanised 
transport with as many stores as could be carried was to make for

them slipped into the water when the moorings of die ferry boat gave

destroyed. The ne.xt disaster was that the destruedon of surplus

toward Paan on the Salween to cut the communications of Smy&amp;‚Äôs

Was Moulmein to be defended? Was it indeed defensible? The 
decision finally taken was to hold it for as long as possible with a 
mixed brigade group. This was after a visit to Burma from Wavcll 
who had had to fly 2,000 miles to make it and whose mind was 
already crowded with imminent decisions raised by the menace tt 
the Netherlands East Indies and the disastrous state of affairs in 
Malaya. Nevertheless, with a general‚Äôs eye he was able to note the 
opportunity afforded to tanks by the country between Rangoon and 
the Sittang River, and he diverted the 7 th British Armoured Brigade 
from Java to Burma. One asks how the Burma Army would have 
got out of Burma without that armoiued brigade. 

If Moulmein had been laid out with the intention of puzzling Ae 
defence it would have been a triumph of planning. Vital points like 
the aerodrome, the supply depot, the ammunition depot, and Ae 
quays of the Salween estuary on which communications with 
Martaban and the road and railway depended were all widely 
separated from one another and it required a great oblong peri- 
meter of nearly to miles to make them secure. This would have 
taxed the resources of a division: Smyth had a weak brigade 
which consisted of the 4th Frontier Force Regt, half the 3rd Burma 
Rifles, the 7th and 8th Burma Rifles, a troop of the 12th Indian 
Mountain Battery, the 3rd Indian Light Anti-aircraft Battery 
and a section of the Goth Field Company Indian Sappers and 
Miners. There was also a detachment of Ae Burma Frontier Force to 
defend the aerodrome. These were Sikhs enlisted in Burma and 
commanded by a former V.G.O. of Smyth‚Äôs old battalion, the 15^1 
Sik^, who had been severely wounded in the First World War. 
This gallant Indian ofldeer, being past the, age for military service, 
had managed to rejoin, and he and his men fought magnificently, 
holding the aerodrome for 24 hours after it had been isolated. The 
commander refused to surrender and fought his way out with many 
of his men ‚Äî a heart-stirring performance.

The old Moulmein Pagoda with its white glazed earthenware

machine-gunned them,andoneofthesmaIlersteameirswassunk. Large 
formations of enemy bombers were overhead during the evacuation, 
but mercifully they bombed Martaban instead of Moulmein. 

When the steamers reached Martaban all persuasion of their 
civilian crews to return and take off men left at the Post Office jetty

kation area was in vain. Indeed, without the cool help of the Indian

would ever have got away at all. There was a stone effigy of Queen 
Victoria in Moulmein erected in 1897 to commemorate her Diamond 
Jubilee. Sitting under a Gothic canopy on a sidewalk near the quay 
the Queen would have seemed to survey with added pride the Indian 
sepoys and gunners and sappers of whom she was ffiways so proud. 
The Piffers and the i2th Mountain Battery and the 60 th Field 
Company had not failed.

To counter this outflanking move on the north tlie 4th Frontier

434 EASTERN EPIC 

men was probably more valuable than the amount of damage done

It might have been wiser to recognise the necessity to withdraw 
from the Bilin line at least by February tSth, but the criticism of 
commanders on the spot by the High Command was apt to be a 
little unimaginative in tliose bitter days that marked the opening of 
the Japanese war. Percival had felt it in Malaya; Hutton could not 
help being sharply aware of it in Burma. The impulse was to deflect 
such criticism even at the risk of rashness. Hutton, and Wavell above 
him, both counted on far more than they received when the plan of 
campaign was decided upon in Burma. One cannot but feel that the 
news of the capitulation of Singapore cast a shadow over Rangoon 
and may have influenced the Army Commander to hold on at 
Bilin beyond the margin of safety. He could not be blamed for it, 
and indeed no blame rests upon any commander in the East for the 
series of disasters there; the blame rests entirely upon Whitehall. 
That Whitehall had no alternative to a gamble on Japan‚Äôs keeping 
out of the war may be true; but there is an inclination to suggest 
that prescience, even profound prescience, animated its mundane 
strategy. That is simply not true; the strategic policy was in fact a 
continuous improvisation exactly on a level with the improvisatioi 
of the men and material by which it was sustained. 

Hutton‚Äôs visit to the 17th Division on February 19th convincea

that night orders were issued for a general tvitlidrawal before dawn 
next day. 

The 48th Brigade was to cover the withdrawal and be reconstituted

3 haung a little west of Kyaikto. Nothing was done about strengthen-

B y 4 p.m. on February 20th a powerful enemy column witli 
elephants moving along the coast had reached Keinphan, a 
village less than eight miles from Kyaikto, welcomed by the villagers 
of Taungzun and Ka^vkadat more enthusiastically than a travelling 
circus. Large enemy parties of the 33rd Division were south of 
Kyaikto moving do^vn tracks to the great railway bridge over tlxe 
Sittang. The full strength of the 55th Division was pressing on from 
Bilin. The east bank of the Sittang offered no tenable positions and 
the only way of rvithdrawal rvould be over the river. 

The main road from Martaban stopped at Kyaikto, 16 miles 
from the bridge. After that the road had been traced through virgin 
scrub jungle and the cut brushwood had been pushed back on either 
side of the track, a foot deep in red dust, from which the tree stumps 
had not been cleared. The railway ran south of this track until 
track and railway met at Mokpalin Station. Then for a short way they 
continued north close together until the railway turned westward to 
the bridge and the road made a wide sweep to approach the river 
from the north-east. Here a ridge of high ground extended between 
the road and the river. A pagoda crowned the part of the ridge 
nearer to tlxe river and a huge stone image of Buddha presided over 
the easterly side. The railway emerged on the bridge from a cutting 
through the bluff above the river. The bridge painted the colour of 
stale blood was 500 yards long and had been decked over with planks 
to take road traffic. Immediately north of it was a ferry service , of 
three power-driven vessels. The river rapidly widened south of the 
bridge; the current was swift; there was a 16-feet tidal bore. Between 
the bridge and the quarries east of Mokpalin the country was hilly, 
covered with jungle and dense scrub. South of Mokpalin the land by 
the river was flat with stretches of paddy, and on the west side this 
paddy land spread for miles in a monotonous plain through which 
ran the railxvay and the tracks, the latter inches deep in dust at this 
time of the year.

The fog of war has often been thick, but it never lay more thickly 
than it lay over the 17th Indian Division during those two February 
days in 1942.

with the bridgehead. A few stragglers made their way into the latter

The enemy did not press hard against the bridgehead that m'ght, 
but there were almost continuous disquieting incidents. A Japanese

kept coming in with horrific tales of surrender, disintegration and

By 4 a.m. the 3rd Burma Rifles on the south-east sector of the 
bridgehead had almost all disappeared and the Japanese light 
machine-gun was firing at any noise audible on the bridge. A sapper 
officer reported to Hugh-Jones that the demolition of the bridge 
could only be guaranteed if our men were able to touch off fuses at 
two or three points along its length, running back toward the west 
bank after firing each in succession. It was obvious that unless the 
Japanese light machine-gun could be silenced, it would be difficult 
if not impossible to do this by dayfight and even if the machine-gun 
were silenced the bridge would still be under mortar and automatic 
fire for the whole of its length. So the small sandbag redoubt above 
the entrance to the railway cutting was called on to supply knee- 
high breastworks round each fuse to give the sapper firing it a chance 
to survive. 

At 4.30 a.m. Hugh-Jones called a conference at the bridgehead. 
He asked the opinions of the commanding officers and the staff 
officers from divisional H.Q,. who were there, after telling them that 
his orders were to prevent the Japanese from capturing the bridge 
intact. Therefore if it was decided to blow it it must be blown 
before dayfight for the sappers to be able to guarantee the 
success of the demolition. The reports of disaster which had been 
coining in ali night offered no hope that the remainder of the division 
would be able to deflect the enemy‚Äôs aim for the vital bridge. Once 
across the Sittang nothing stood betiveen him and Rangoon. The 
Army Commander had just returned from a fruitless attempt to get 
into personal contact with Chiang Kai-Shek at Lashio, and all the pre- 
vious day he had been anxiously impressing on Smyth the paramount 
necessity of keeping the Japanese on the other side of the Sittang

long enough to let him get the 7th Armoured Brigade, -which had

Immediately after Hugh-Jones and his G.O.‚Äôs down at the
