Cowan woke up Smyth. To quote the divisional commander: 

He wanted a definite order from me as to whether he should 
blow the bridge or not. What a horrible decision to have to make! 
If we blew, it was in the knowledge that two-thirds of the division 
was left on the far bank. If we did not blow a complete Japanese 
division could march straight on Rangoon. The decision was one 
that had to be mine and mine alone, and having made it I should, 
of course, take complete responsibility for it. It took me less than 
5 minutes to make up my mind. . . . Hard though it was there 
was very little doubt as to what was the correct course: I gave 
the order that the bridge should be blown immediately. 

The last troops on the east side to close on the bridge were the

At the western end we collected in the sandbagged redoubt. 
A series of terrific explosions, a blinding flash, a blast of hot air

world could hear. As far as we could see, two spans were down but 
tops of the girders showed above the s-wiriing tide.

Rangoon should be kept going as long as possible. So a plan, for the

Thousands of Indians set out on foot along the Prome road %vith 
what belongings they could carry with them, intending to cross the 
waterless Arakan Yomas to Taungup whence they hoped to reach 
Cliittagong by local boats. Many other thousands chose the way over 
the Chindwin routes to Manipur. Many other thousands followed the 
wild trails to Assam from north-east Upper Burma. In due course 
more shall be told of these ghastly odysseys. The reason why they 
went on to India was not fear of the Japanese but fear of the Burmans 
ifthe British withdrew. They had fled into the countryside to escape 
the bombs; here many of them tvere murdered and maltreated and 
robbed. Therefore all these many thousands of unhappy creatures 
were inspired by terror to continue that dreadful march whid 
surpasses in horror anything of the kind in recorded history. Nc 
was it only Indians who suffered in this macabre exodus: Brid; 
women and children suffered no less.

the block, but the enemy closed in behind them and it was afternoon 
before the block was finally cleared by the Cameronians and West 
Yorkshires with severe casualties. 

When Army Headquarters with the administrative part of the 
Rangoon garrison was halted at Taukkyan, five miles from the 
block established by the enemy where the road ran through a stretch 
of jungle, the outlook was bad. There were few fighting troops 
available; the 17th Division and most of the 7th Armoured Brigade 
were at Hlegu, seven miles to the east, or in hot action near Pegu. 

That afternoon squadrons from the 7th Armoured Brigade were 
sent to deal with the situation. By 4 p.m. the attempt to break through 
the black had failed. The and Frontier Force Rifles of the newly 
arrived 63rd Brigade was brought from Hlega to Taukkyan, but two 
attacks were repelled by the enemy with heavy casualties for the 
young and untrained troops. 

By now it was 5.30 p.m, and already dark owing to the black 
cloud of smoke from the burning refineries in Rangoon. Army 
Headquarters and the troops at Taukkyan harboured in a rubber 
plantation. The imperturbable and debonair Alexander never 
needed both of these qualities more. Within a perimeter guarded as 
closely as possible by tanks and infantry were crowded all kinds of 
administrative and office staffs to wliich were added civil officials and 
clerks, and as a final treat some women who had disobeyed the 
evacuation order and clung to their men folk. 

When night came Alexander gave orders to attack the block at 
dawn. After a concentration of artillery fire the tanks were to charge 
head on and simultaneously the 63rd Brigade was to attack, the 
I /loth Gurkha Rifles on the west flank, the ist Sikh Regt on the east, 
and the and Frontier Force Rifles up the road as a reserve behind the 
tanks of the Hussars. The i / 10th Gurkha Rifles had marched that 
night from Hlegu, and when at first light on March 8th the battalion 
advanced through dense jungle toward the main road it lost its way 
in the mist and became dispersed, many of tlie men not rejoining the 
main body for several days, and some of them having been deprived , 
of their arras by Burmans. On the other side of the road the ist Sikh 
Regt at its assembly point in open country was heavily bombed and 
machine-gunned by enemy, aircraft; this considerably disorganised 
the young soldiers whose first experience it was of air attacks. 

However, the inability of the untrained 63rd Indian Brigade at 
this date to deal with the dangerous situation was set off by what 
may be called the enemy‚Äôs whimsical abandonment of the block. It 
would seem that he had had no intention of cutting off our troops: 



456 EASTERN EPIC 

the road block had been put there to protect the left flank of the 
Japanese 33rd Division as it crossed the Prome road to approach 
Rangoon from the north-west. Inasmuch as the enemy must have 
known that we had evacuated the city on the previous day his hurry 
is difficult to understand, and no explanation put forward for his 
astonishing mistake is satisfactory. General Alexander could consider 
liimself a favourite of fortune; his decision to defer the evacuation of 
Rangoon might easily have involved the destruction or capture of the 
whole of his forces. That is not to censure his decision, for it may be 
doubted if any other British general arriving with such a directive 
in such a situation tvould have had the imaginadon to realise 
immediately that he must get his troops out at once if he wanted to 
save them to fight another day. Alexander may have been influenced 
by the impression at a distance that the men on the spot in Hong 
Kong, Singapore and Burma were affected by pessimism and there- 
fore liable to withdraw too soon. Gordon Bennett thought the same 
until he was in acdon against the Japanese himself. Presently, we 
shall find General Sdiwell, the American general supposed to be 
commanding the Chinese Expedidonary Force, firmly convinced 
that Alexander himself was incapable of aggressive acdon. The 
legend persists that the Indian and British soldiers in the Far East 
were defeated by their inability to cope with Japanese tactics. 
Japanese tacdcs were superlative, but even if the British and Indian 
troops had been properly trained for the task assigned to them die 
lack of adequate arms and equipment would still have turned the day 
against them. 

The loss of Rangoon decided the whole course of the campaign. 
The Burma Army was now cut off from its base and could hencc- 
fordi be supplied only with as much limited equipment, stores and 
reinforcements as could be flown in by air. Base and lines of com- , 
municadon installations and reserves had already been moved 
norUr of Rangoon, and this back-loading which must continue 
tiiroughout the campaign would place a fearful strain on the ad- 
ministrative machine and the transportation agencies. The destruc- 
tion of tiic oil refineries inevitably reduced the output of petrol and 
lubricating oils, and when the large stocks taken out of Rangoon had 
been consumed tise Allied Armies in Burma would be dependent oti 
die improvised refinery in the oilfields themselves.

peditionary Force and there was the construction of that road out 
of Burraa to As^m; to the Chinese armies and to the road we shall 
return.

By March loth the 1 7th Indian Division and the 7th Amoured

concentration must take place in the Prome area to secure alignment. 
This involved the loss of land 70 miles in depth in which there were 
large quantities of food, particularly rice which would be wanted 
for the Chinese, and that added to the already almost intolerable 
difficulties of the administrative services. 

Lieut.*General Slim arrived on March 19th to take over the 
command of Burcorps which consisted of the tyth Division and the 
7th Armoured Brigade; they were joined by the rst Burma Division 
commanded by Major-General J. Bruce Scott^ as soon as the Chinese

heavy fighting in the Sittang Valley before it joined Burcorps on the 
Irrawaddy front. 

Battalions from Curtis‚Äôs 13th Indian Brigade had been brigaded 
within the ist and and Burma Brigades. On March nth these two 
latter attacked Pyuntaza on the main Rangoon-Mandalay road, 
and Madauk and Shwegyin on the Sittang River. The attack on 
Pyimtaza opened successfully, but after the 2nd Rajputs had 
carried the town and a road block south of it the enemy counter- 
attacked in superior numbers and the Rajputs were compelled to fall 
back, having suffered considerable casualties. A line was eventually 
established north of Pyuntaza. Madauk was taken by the 7th Burma 
Rifles without much opposition. Shwegyin gave the 5/ist Punjab 
Regt some fierce street fighting, the town being occupied by Burmese 
insurgents. Lieut.-Colonel Marsland handled the action skilfully; 
the battalion cleared the to\vn, killing 50 of the enemy and taking 
90 prisoners, all in civilian clothes but formidably armed. 

When the time came for the withdrawal of the ist Burma Division

1 6th the ist Burma Brigade was in action at Kyauktaya, and the 
.5th Burma Rifles smashed up some lorries full of Japanese. The

before the rst Burma Division passed through the Chinese outposts 
along the Pegu River to concentrate near Toungoo before proceeding 
to the Irrawaddy front. The original order to concentrate in the

W HEN it became clear that war with Japan was inevitable 
sooner or later a supply base was established in Burma which 
was intended to maintain British forces operating in China against 
the Japanese. This pipe dream of strategy was replaced by the un- 
pleasant nightmare of a possible Japanese invasion of Burma, and 
arrangements sverc then made for Chinese help if the nightmare 
became an actuality. The size of the force was fixed at one regiment 
(aaytli Regt of the Chinese 93rd Division) because it was estimated 
that a larger force could not be rationed by us in the Kengtung area 
where these troops were to operate. When war svith Japan broke 
out the 227tli Regt at once moved into Kengtung to take over the 
defence of the Mekong River sector, and on January ist 194a 
regimental headquarters was established at Mongyaung, 

The reader is renainded that when toward the end of December 
1941 General Wavcll flew to interview Chiang Kai-Shek in Chung- 
king he was offered the Chinese Fifth and Sixth Armies (the 
equivalent of two divisions) for the defence of Burma and that Wavell 
at once accepted tlte 93rd Division of the Sixth Army and asked 
for the 49th Division to be moved close to the frontier at Wanting on 
the Burma road. The Chinese 55th Division, scattered and badly 
organised, was left where it was. The Fifth Army was concentrating 
round Kunming and Wavell asked for it to be retained there in 
reserve. Much ill-informed criticism of Wavell‚Äôs treatment of Chiang 
Kai-Shek‚Äôs offer was made in an attempt to excuse the preliminary 
mess that Britain, Holland and the United States between them made 
of Far Eaststrategy; now that ChiangKai-Shek‚Äôsinferior qualities have 
been revealed and the need to flatter him has gone it can be asserted 
that if Wavell had accepted his offer, so far from helping the situation 
the Chinese armies would have injured it, tliat is if they had arrived 
any sooner than they did, which is unlikely. 

‚ñ† On January igth when the Japanese, attack on Tenasserim 
developed, the rest of the Cliinese ggrd Division moved into Keng- 
tung and 10 days later it was decided that the 49th Division should

enter Burma through Lashio and take over the sector e^t of the,

Chiang Kai-Shek, while insisting that his troops should not mix 
with the Imperial forces, declared that they were under the com-

Chinese Sixth Army should take over the Karenni front also and thus 
free the ist Burma Division for operations south of Toungoo. This

At the end of February the Chinese Fifth Army began its advance 
into Burma. It could not move before because the last elements of 
the Sixth Army had not cleared Lashio, and the only way into Burma 
from China was along the Burma road, a most limited thoroughfare. 
The time to concentrate the Fifth Army was reckoned at 20 days. So 
when Rangoon fell only the 200th Division of the Fifth Army was in 
Burma. 

The fire power of a Chinese division was about equal to that of a 
British brigade^ the men without rifles were used for various fatigues 
and being trained were available to replace casualties. The Chinese 
Armies had no supply or administrative services. Their officers knew 
nothing about railway transport. Consequently the British, not- 
withstanding their own inadequate resources, had to improvise 
transport and administrative services for the Chinese; they also had 
to feed them. The fact that the British liaison officers were chiefly 
employed on administrative duties was bad for their prestige became 
the Chinese commanders regarded administration as unworthy of 
a fighting soldier. Hence the caterwauling by General Joseph 
StilweU in his diary about the Chinese contempt for the ‚ÄòLimeys‚Äô 

. who would not fight. The British had to move into Burma and there 
feed and maintain some 95,000 Chinese who now and then fought. 
Major-General Dennys, the British Military Attachd at Chungking, 
was to have been Chief Liaison Officer, but he was unfortunately 
killed in an air crash and his unenviable post was taken by Brigadier 
Martin. Very few of the liaison officers could speak Chinese, the 
Chinese interpreters were young students who caused a great deal of 
trouble; none of the Chinese could speak the Burmese language and 
their notion of communicating with the Bormans was to shoot as 
many as possible. Medical services were miserable, for drugs and 
doctora were equally scarce. So a number of British medical unitswho 
could m be spared were attached.to the Chinese. Invaluable help was 
given by Dr Seagrave of the Harper Memorial Medical Uni^ an

It had been laid down that the Chinese Sixth Army was to come 
under the command of Hutton; but when the Fifth Army atfrived its 
commander, General Tu, was officially described as Acting Com- 
mandcr-in-Chief of the Chinese Expeditionary Force. When Alex- 
ander succeeded Hutton he presumed that Tu was subordinate to 
himself. Then on March 14th General J. W. Stilwell of the United 
States Array arrived in Burma without any signal communications 
and with an inadequate staff, all devoid of any local knowledge, to 
be in independent command of the Chinese Expeditionary Force. 
General Alc.xander noted:^ 

Nominally I commanded all the Alied forces. General Sdiwell 
commanded the Chinese V and VI Armies but he had to issue all 
his orders through a Chinese Commander, General Lou. There 
was, moreover, a system of liaison officers working under the 
Generalissimo (Chiang Kai-Shek) and it appeared that no orders 
of a major nature issued by myself, by General Stilwell or by 
General Lou could be carried out unless they had the sanction of 
the Generalissimo, which had to be obtained through the latter‚Äôs 
Liaison Mission, whose head was General Lin Wei at Lashio, and 
who in turn had a forward liaison officer in General Hou at 
Maymo. Such an arrangement was obviously quite unsuitable for 
modern war since quick decisions for the employment of the 
Chinese forces were impossible to obtain and this, together tvith 
the almost total lack of knowledge of staff duties which existed in 
the Chinese forces, caused considerable delay in the e.Kecution of 
vital movements.

Alexander had flown to sec Chiang Kai-Shek toward the end of 
the month and in an attempt to relieve the pressure on the Chinese 
Fifth Army he had ordered a local offensive from Prome, die first 
objective being Paungde. The striking force consisted of the R.H.A. 
Battery, the 7th Hussars, the much depleted battalions of the West 
Yorkshires, the Duke of Wellington‚Äôs and tlie Camcronians; the ist 
Gloucestershire Regt which was now the reconnaissance unit of the 
1 7 til Indian Division was already observing Paungde. A Commando

with a reported advance up the west bank of the Irrawaddy by a ' 
large mixed force of Japanese and Burmans. Co-operating with the 
Commando was tlic Royal Marines river patrol with a detachment 
of the Burma Military Police. 

By the morning of March 29th the enemy was already at Padigon, 
she miles north of Paungde off the main road and on the railway. 
This suggested an outflanking march against Prome, and tlie greater 
part of the striking force under Brigadier Anstice was diverted to 
counter such a threat. Repeated attacks by the Camcronians with a 
squadron of the 7th Hussars made considerable progress but did not 
succeed in reaching Padigon. Meanwhile, the company and a half 
that now represented the and Duke of Wellington‚Äôs Regt operated 
against Paungde and killed many of the enemyj however, he was 
continually being reinforced, and in the end the attack had to be 
given up that afternoon for lack of weight. 

By now die Japanese who had advanced up the east bank of the 
Irrawaddy were discovered to be astride the main road at Shwe- 
daung and therefore behind the striking force, which was instructed 
to break out either by way of Padigon or Shwedaung as circum- 
stances decided and to fall back on Prome. Anstice decided oh 
Shwedaung; breaking off the actions at Padigon and Paungde, he 
concentrated his force at Inma. At sundown Major Pereira R.H.A. 
with a troop of the 414th Battery R.H.A,, a troop of the yth Hussars, 
and two companies of the Gloucesters was sent ahead to clear a road 
block which the enemy had established at Shwedaung. By then 
Major-General Cowan had sent the 4th Frontier Force Regt and the 
and Frontier Force Rifles supported by a battery of the ist Indian 
Field Regt to retake the town froih the north. The Piffers in some 
fierce fighting killed and captured a number of Burmese insurgents, 
but they could not penetrate beyond the northern outskirts of the 
town, which ran for more than a mile along the east bank of the 
Irrawaddy. At 7 p.m, Pereira‚Äôs Force struck a block two miles south 
of Shwedaung, Lightly held, this was soon cleared; but on the

outskirts of the town another block strongly held checked further 
progress. The rest of the striking force having now arrived, Brigadiw 
Anstice decided on a stem effort to break through the block at 2 a.m.

road block while it was being shelled by our guns. With his hands

ropes and make his way back to his own regiment through the

The 2 a.m. attack failed to force the block; at daylight it was 
resumed after the heavy river mist had cleared. The fighting was 
long and bitter and tlie block was not overcome until 10.30 a.m. 
when the enemy fell back toward the end of the town. Our troops 
followed up; the transport column moved forward. The latter was 
soon halted by another block and attempts to seek diversions were 
thwarted by accurate mortar fire which wrecked many veliicles and 
closed the side streets. On the flanks the progress by the troops rvas 
more rapid, though fiercely contested at every yard. However, that 
progress did not help the transport, which was heavily bombed from 
the air during the afternoon. Shwedaung was now on fire; our 
rearguard rvas fighting hard with fresh enemy units coming up from 
the south; our relieving forces to the north had not been able to 
advance. A last desperate effort was made to save the transport. The 
tanks managed to find a way round, but in the face of the heavy 
mortar and macliine-gun fire few unarmoured veliicles managed to 
get out. The remaining transport was then abandoned. The British 
infantry battalions ivith the 4th Frontier Force Regt and the 2nd 
Frontier Force Rifles fought their way through and out of tlie 
burning town sustaining severe casualties. Eight tanks and two guns 
were lost The enemy was the 215th Rcgt of tlic Japanese 33rd 
Division. 

On March agtli disaster overtook the Commando and the Royal 
Marines river-patrol at Padaung through the treachery of tlm 
inliabiianls who hid the enemy in their houses and helped him 
to make a surprise attack that night in the course of whiclt our 
force was destroyed. Next morning a dozen Royal Marine and 
Commando prisoners were lined up before a battalion on parade 
and charged by a section with fixed bayonets. A sergeant-major, witli

On the evening of April i st the Japanese began to close in on Prome, 
One may suggest that the 63rd Brigade should not have been given

At 3 a.m. after the withdrawal of the 63rd Brigade the 48th 
Brigade was ordered to break contact svith the enemy and withdraw ‚ñ†

night; it looked as if tite enemy was marching on Dayindabo wth

By 1 1 .30 a.m. the xyth Division was tramping through the hottest 
part of Burma at tire hottest time of tire year. The dust was inches, 
deep. The suir blazed down. Many of the men had not tasted water 
since the previous evening. There was a shortage of water-bottles 
and the rare water-holes on the line of march tainted by the cholera 
spread by the unhappy refugees on dreir via dolorosa to India could 
not be kept clear of parched stragglers. Toward evening the long 
column of troops was attacked by enemy bombers and casualties 
were heavy. 

The concentradon of the 1st Burma Division was not quite 
completed when die 17 th Division reached the Dayindabo area dttd 
night. On April 3rd it passed through the ist Burma Brigade and 
marched on to the area of AUanmyo and Ywataung, again heavily 
attacked by bombers. During April 4th the troops were able to get 
some hours of rest; they needed it. On the night of April 5/6th 
Allanmyo and Thayetmyo were evacuated. Prodigies of effort by the 
administrative services had managed to backload all stores and 
ammunition; both towns were burnt. 

Burcorps continued to withdraw northwards. By April 8th it was 
on the general line Minlila-Taungdwingyi covering the oilfields. 
This front was 40 miles long and with the forces at our disposal 
impossible to defend in depth. On April 6th Alexander had met 
Chiang Kai-Shek and asked him for a division to help in holding this 
line. The reinforcement was promised but it never arrived, and its 
failure to arrive compromised the whole plan of defence. This had 
provided for a series of widely-spaced brigade posts with their 
forward screen manned by units of tlie Burma Frontier Force. The 
centre of the line was held by the Corps Striking Force commanded 
by Major-General Bruce Scott. Tliis consisted of the ist Burma

T he task of denying the oilfields at Yenangyaung and farther

Rangoon. A word of admiration is due to the magnificently selfle^ 
way in which members of the staffs of the companies concerned 


on 


carried out that dangerous and distressing task. 

The demolition signal was given by Burcorps at I a.m

the Chauk oilfield where the scene was similar. Neither company 
had mortars or automatic weapons.

towards Lashio. The tanks shoiild be employed in the battle for

A new operational instruction agreed to by General Stilwell‚Äôs staff 
at Maymo was issued to Burcorps on April 23rd. West of the River 
Mu would be Burcorps, the ist Burma Division astride the River 
Ghindwin with a strong detachment covering the approach to 
Kalewa by way of the Myittha Valley on the west bank of the 
Ghindwin. Between the Mu and the Irrawaddy would be the 7th 
Armoured Brigade and the Chinese 38th Division. The Chinese 
2Qnd, 28th and 96th Divisions would be in and south of Mandalay 
and holding the crossings over the River Myitnge. All Chinese forces 
east of the Mandalay-Pyawbwe railway would move towards Lashio. 

This plan did not commit Alexander to immediately abandom'ng 
Kyaukpadaung and Meiktila; he still hoped to cover these places. 
By this time, however, he was realising the danger of hanging on too 
long and he had to consider the bottleneck of the great Ava Bridge, 
which was the only road by which tanks could cross the Irrawaddy. 
The approaches to the bridge ran through Mandalay and were most 
vulnerable to air attack. Japanese aircraft had maintained a steady 
attack on the city, wliich was already a burnt-out ruin. Alexander 
rightly dreaded the prospect of being compelled to fight in the loop 
of the Irrawaddy below Mandalay; he decided that as soon as his 
advanced forces were compelled to fall back from Meiktila the 
crossing of the Irrawaddy must be made and the Ava Bridge blown. 
Early in April steps had been taken to construct ferries over the 
mighty river, and it was by such a ferry that the ist Burma Division 
ultimately crossed. The obscure situation in the Shan States did not 
allow a decision to be made now whether the Chinese 22nd, 28th and 
96th Divisions should fall back northwards or strike east toward 
Lashio. 

On April 23rd Stilwell persuaded the Chinese 200th Division to 
make a counter-attack on Taunggyi by directing it himself .under 
heavy fire. Whatever strictures have to be passed upon the American 
General's attitude during these difficult days none can be passed 
upon his personal courage; that was always of the finest quality. The 
action by Taunggyi stopped that, motorised column of the Japanese 
56th Division for a space, but by April 29th it had driven on to 
capture Lashio, which cut the only serviceable line of communica- 
tion with China and left the Japanese at liberty either to threaten 
the rear of the Imperial and Chinese forces through Bhamo and 
Myitkyina or sweep down in strength on Mandalay.

had a foretaste of what would happen to its petals on the edge of 
another monsoon three years hence.

The traveller who has beheld these vast and solitary forests 
marvels that an army could pass dirough them without disaster. 
General Alexander \vrote in his Despatch: 

Anyone seeing this track for the first time would find it difficult 
to imagine how a fully mechanised force could possibly move 
over it. 

Vehicles foundered in the sandy beds of the numerous chaungs 
that the track crossed and recrossed. Traffic was blocked by vehicles 
slowly negotiating frail bamboo bridges. For miles the forest on either 
side was littered with abandoned vehicles which are now slowly 
rusting away under the shade of the towering primeval trees, man‚Äôs 
squalid Utde toys rebuked by nature. 

Through the nightmare beauty of this forest the Burma Army 
pressed on at the utmost speed attainable. It was not merely a 
question of reaching the Chindwin before the Japanese could cut 
the road to India; it must be reached before the breaking of the 
monsoon. If the rains came before the Army was clear of this country 
ffiat Army would be as helpless as driftwood in a torrent. The wind- 
ing chaungs with their sheer sandstone cliffs were difficult enough 
to traverse when dry; when the monsoon broke they would be 
impassable. The wonderful effort of the administrative services 
directed by the tireless Goddard had ensured abundance of rations 
and petrol along the route; there was enough to feed the refugees, 
some of them army famihes, who were tsiken to Shwegyin in military 
vehicles, many of the troops themselves marching on foot to allow 
this act of mercy.

One of the Stuart tanks of the 7th Hussars crossed the Chindwin 
and what is more re-crossed it again in January 1945 to avenge its . 
comrades; its name was the Curse of Scotland. Presumably it had 
kept some lorry out of a place on the steamer. Beside the track near 
the Basin she tanks of the 7th Armoured Brigade were still standing 
side by side in exact alignment five years later; they were painted 
the colour of yellow ochre to help them mingle with the desert scene, ' ^ 
for they were intended to be used against Rommel. They had done 
noble work in a greener land, and we may fancy them in a seeming 
stiff salute to the men of Slim‚Äôs Fourteenth Army on the way south 
to inflict upon the Japanese by far the greatest military defeat in 
their history. As the chronicler pens these words eight monsoons 
have broken above those Stuart tanks and a ninth will soon break, 
but without doubt they are still there standing stiffly in exact align- 
ment, for the termites which can fell the most powerful tree, cannot 
destroy those tanks, and they will still be standing there when the 
chronicler‚Äôs pen has rusted away.

The notion that Burma was lost without a fight must be sternly

On May 4th Stilwell noted:^ 

London radio. ‚ÄòGeneral Alexander, a bold and resourceful

But General Stilwell was Indifferent to the menace of an invasion 
of India if Alexander‚Äôs army had been destroyed; his narrowly 
circumscribed mind was obsessed by the menace to China. 

It is outside the scope of this chronicler to record in detail the 
Chinese fight, for which in any case material is almost completely 
wanting. 

The ability of the Japanese to pass through our thin line and cut 
off the ist Burma Division at Yenangyaung which had a fatal effect 
on the progress of the campaign was due to General Tu‚Äôs failure to 
carry out his orders by sending a division across the Yomas to 
Taungdwingyi. Stilwell‚Äôs despatch of the Chinese 38th Division from 
Mandalay to the help of Burcorps was too late to turn the day. 

It may be admitted that the Imperial forces might have been en- 
veloped after the fall of Rangoon if the Japanese had not been com- 
pelled to deal with the Chinese forces, and to that extent the Chinese 
intervention can be said to have prolonged the campaign in Burma. 

It must also be remembered that the Chinese could not understand 
our lack of equipment and supplies, our meagre air force and om 
shortage of transport. If Stilwell could have used his alleged know- 
ledge of the Chinese character to interpret the situation to them his 
appointment to command the Chinese forces would have been a 
boon. He, however, appeared as ignorant as the Ciiinese and his 
attitude of suspicion toward the British is evident throughout his 
diary; he would have been a brave and good soldier in the American 
Revolution. 

When the Japanese reached Myitkyina, General Tu with his 
headquarters and the remains of the Chinese aand and 96th Divi- 
sions turned away from the railway near Nabu and moved north- 
west through the Huka&gt;vng Valley to reach India. Sun‚Äôs 38th

at Nabu and fought an engagement with the Japanese at Wuntho. ‚Äô

May, ig42. Fall of Akyab ‚Äî the refugee problem ‚Äî horrors of the march 
to India‚Äî foresight and devotion of the Assam planters. 

I N the course of telling the story of the First Burma Campaign 
allusions have been made to the refugees, and any account of it 
would be incomplete without some account of the effect of that 
campaign on the million Indians living and working in Central 
and Southern Burma, whose industry for many years had filled the 
Burmans with a resentment which may be compared to the state of 
mind now all too painfully evident in South Africa. Let it be clear 
from the start that the Indians dreaded the Japanese invasion because 
they believed the Burmans would take advantage of it to persecute 
a hated minority whose presence in the country was one of their 
grievances against the British Raj. 

Thousands of Indians were sufficiently disturbed by the prospect 
to leave Burma in good time by sea for Calcutta and Chittagong, 
but the gradual paralysis of Rangoon made evacuation by sea 
impossible, and the next route followed by the refugees' was along the 
coastal belt to enter India by way of Cox‚Äôs Bazaar and Cliittagong. 
Akyab had been organised as a naval base under Commodore 
Graham R.N., conamanding Burma Coast, and here were stationed 
the R.I.N. sloops Indus and Sutlej with five armed motor launches of 
the Burma R.N.V.R. This force was continuously patrolling the 
many islands and creeks along the Arakan coast, a task for which it 
was quite inadequate, besides lacking maps and charts accurate 
enough to explore the creeks -witliout the risk of being stranded. The 
rnmn task, however, proved to be the evacuation of the Indian 
refugees, and it was due to the Royal Indian Navy that behvcen the 
end of March and the beginning of May no less dian 35,000 refugees 
were sent by sea to India from Akyab and the little island post of 
Kyaukpyu. At tire latter place Sub-Lieut. H. C. Brown of the Burma 
R.N.V.R. with the crew of his launch and the help of a fcsv military 
stragglers from the front in Burma restored order and handled many 
lliousands of refugees who had been attacked and robbed all the way 
through Arakan. 

It is convenient to complete the story of Akyab before returning to 
the refugees on their way to India by other routes. In view of the 



504 EASTERN EPIC 

importance of Akyab as an air base the garrison of the young and 
partially trained 14th Rajputana Rifles under Lieut.-Colonel O. C. 
Munckton \vas strengthened by H.Q,. 109 Indian Brigade the 
6th Jat Regt and the gth Rajputana Rifles and some anti-aircraft 
guns from India. This was on March i8th. On March 23rd the 
Japanese occupied the Andamans from which the garrison had been 
evacuated on March 12th. On the same day Akyab was heavily 
raided, the attack being repeated on March a4th. This was just after 
the devastating attack on Magwe. It was decided to abandon Akyab

Rifles with one section of the 67th Heavy Anti-aircraft Regt and

Continued raids on Akyab badly affected morale. One of the 
Commissioners went off with most of his civilian officers on March 
goth; there were numerous desertions among the troops and police. 
Arson in the port was rife; rice miUs were burnt; the oil installa- 
tions were menaced. On April igth deserters from the Burma 
Frontier Force and Militar y Police joined with a gang of Arakanese 
in massacring a number of Indians, mostly women and children, at 
Gopethaimg on the mainland. 

On April Gth H.M.I.S. Indus was sunk in an air raid. Morale 
among the troops and sailors deteriorated. Malaria increased; on 
April 2ist r42 men of the 14th Rajputana Rifles were in hospital. By 
this date the unrest had developed into open rebellion, and at the 
end of the month the Japanese were concentrating in the Minbya 
area rvith an evident intention to advance on Akyab on which air 
attacks were intensified. 

On May and the enemy was in Kyauktaw and Ponnagyun and at 
the latter place the Deputy Commissioner U Kyaw Khine, who had 
remained at his post and displayed the highest moral courage, was 
killed in his larmch. Patrols of the Rajputana Rifles up the creeks 
were met by machine-gun fire. Throughout May 3rd Akyab was 
severely bombed, in the course of which the garrison‚Äôs ammunition 
reserve was blown up. ‚ñ† 

Munckton‚Äôs orders were to rvithdraw the garrison overland toward 
Chittagong when every prospect of holding the port had vanished. 
Accordingly in the early hours of May 4th our forces left Akyab; the 
coast road by now being flooded and the inland route threatened 
with cutting by the enemy, Lieut.-GoIonel Munckton evacuated the 
garrison by sea after demolitions in the port had been carried out.

PLIGHT OF THE REFUGEES 

We must now return to the refugees. 

By far the greatest number of the Indian refugees, to which in due 
course would be added many Europeans, moved northward before 
the Japanese advance, and finally took any path that led into India, 
though such paths led across some of the most formidable country 
in the world. Yet before they could reach the north the progress up 
through Burma was purgatorial, for to fatigue and sickness was added 
the likelihood of being murdered by Burmans, should one straggle 
on the way. 

Thousands moved up the Ghindwin Valley, making for Kalewa 
and thence through Tamu to Manipur, but when the Army left 
Kalewa and it was occupied by the Japanese that route was ho 
longer available. Myitkyina was the centre of a large concentration, 
and here besides the Indians there were many women and men who 
had stayed at their administrative or commercial posts until the last 
moment. It is impossible to acquit the civil authorities in Burma 
of moral cowardice in failing to order the evacuation of civilians 
earlier. Both here and in Malaya far too much attention was paid 
to ofScial opinion at home. The bureaucrat's caution is too often 
inspired by consideration for his future career; the dread of being- 
criticised in Whitehall for accepting .the fact of the inevitable 
Japanese victory and taking appropriate action in time was respon- 
sible for an immeasurable amount of suffering. The refugees in 
Myitkyina expected to be evacuated to India by air, but the Douglas 
transports available, even though they would carry dangerous loads 
of 75 on every trip, were far too few to relieve the congestion. Any- 
way, the bombing of the Myitkyina airfield on May 6th put it out of 
action; thereafter the fearful exodus on foot began. 

Many of the refugees at Myitkyina, expecting to be flown out, had 
brought with them money and jewels and their most expensive 
clothes; some died in remote forests clad in evening gowns. 

Without the help of die several hundred European tea-planters 
and over half a million, garden-labourers the bulk of Alexander‚Äôs 
army must have perished miserably before it reached Imphal, for, 
that road from Manipur to Tamu would never have been made , 
without them. It was diey, too, who began to cut the road from 
Ledo tvhich was intended to take the place of the lost Lashio road to 
China. By May 1942 the Indian Tea Association had mobilised all its 
resources to help the authorities: it now turned itself into a charitable 
organisation to relieve human misery as far as possible by coming to 
the rescue of the. refugees. 

At the end of February the Government of India notified the 



5o6 eastern epic 

Government of Assam that a mass movement of Indian refugees 
had begun and that the largest number might be expected by way of 
Tamu. That was correct; over 1 50,000 passed through to reach Ae 
railway at Dimapur, and the dead strewed the path behind like 
paper in a paper-chase. Another 37,000-odd passed through the 
camp at Silchar and 22,000 more through the camp at Ledo at the 
end of that ghastly progress through the Hukawng Valley. 

The Government of Assam asked the Indian Tea Association s 
representative at Shillong whetlrer the European community could 
find men to organise camps for the refugees reported to be streaming 
north towards India. The Association had already released half its 
men for military service, but it immediately assumed a new respon- 
sibility. By March 3rd 12 men assembled at Dimapur with stores, 
transport and equipment where they were joined almost at once by 
a medical unit from the Assam Oil Company at Digboi. The Associa- 
tion was already at work repairing and improving the Manipur 
Road, then a single track running 134 miles to Imphal. In a day or 
two its labourers would be working against time to drive the road 
on from Palel to Tamu to save the Burma Army. 45,000 labourers 
were working on that road; 30,000 were working on the road from 
Imphal north. Thousands more were carrying food to the various 
camps. 

The camp at Dimapur was put in charge of Alexander Beattie, 
the Scottish manager of a big tea estate. He was to give his life for 
suffering humanity, for in July 1942 he died of typhoid. 

Mr Justice Braund, Refugee Administrator, Shillong, wrote in a 
letter:^

The peak month at Manipur was May when 51,000 refugees

Fortunately, Mr C. Gimson, the Political Agent at Imphal, had

transport between Imphal and Dimapur and on his advice a 
supplementary route from Bishenpur to Silchar with six camps 
was undertaken by the Surma Valley Branch of the Indian Tea 
Association; this route was in operation by the end of April. 

When the Japanese advance closed the Tamu-Dimapur route tlie 
only possible route for the refugees was through the Hukawng 
Valley and over the Pangsau Pass to Ledo on the first part of the 
road ultimately intended to reach China, on which the laboiu of

‚ñ†representative on the road operation that an' evacuation by this

creatures, but he asked the Indian Tea Association to assume respon-.

faced with so many urgent problems that he had no other course.

One of the worst obstacles on the way to Ledo was the.Namyung

and by the help of the rope the refugees were able to cross. The names

On May aoth a liaison officer of the Indian Tea Association,

children who, with hardly any food left, had been waiting four days

of one small raft and a rattan rope. The difficulty of that country 
may be imagined from the fact that nobody had explored the lake 
into which the Naungyang flowed since an American Baptist 
missionary had reached it in a Rob Roy canoe in 1885. 

Besides the refugees there was a motley train of British and Indian 
troops cut off in the fighting or compelled to leave hospital too soon 
to escape the Japanese; they were most of them just rags and bones, 
with hardly enough flesh on. their limbs to feed the leeches, as they 
staggered through the mud of this frightful journey. 

By the third week in May pilots of the R.A.F. under the direction 
of Brigadier Whitworth, who had at his disposal never more than 
two planes a day, were dropping supplies as regularly as possible. 
These pilots flew in unarmed planes over savage mountainous 
country, often through thick cloud on their perilous mission. They 
can be regarded as the forerunners of those pilots, Indian, British 
and American, who would one day supply the Fourteenth Army 
and secure Slim‚Äôs victory over the Japanese; it may be doubted, 
too, whether Wingate would have succeeded in obtaining approval 
for his Chindits without the example set by these pilots of what 
could be achieved by skill and daring in the menacing' air of that ' 
North-East Frontier, ' 

The organisation set on foot was in full running order by June ist. 
From Tipong to the Pangsau Pass the liaison officers of die Indian 
Tea Association had established a reserve of rations in every camp. 
There was a fully equipped hospital at 'Nampong. Refugees were 
taken from Tipong to Lekhapani by trolley cars, and on from there 
by train to Margherita.

M uch criticism at the time was directed against the civil 
administration in Burma, and in fairness to that and to the 
mihtary administration some brief comments may be included. In 
the first place^ it must be borne in mind that before December 1941 
die view of His Majesty‚Äôs Government was that war with Japan was 
improbable but that if war did come the invasion of Burma was a 
remote possibility and that the main danger would be attack from 
the air. The Government of Burma accepted this view of the future 
and tried to make its preparations accordingly. 

The recent separation from India and the ill-timed introduction 
of a^ large measure of self-government in consequence was a severe 
strain upon the administration at a moment of mundane crisis and, 
reflected gravely upon the statesmanship of those responsible. 
Nevertheless, in spite of a total lack of help from His Majesty‚Äôs 
Govenunent the newly created Defence Department and the Civil 
Admmsuation, still in the swaddling clothes of self-government, 
ma e painful efforts to prepare for war. Unfortunately the mood of 
teccid op^sm prevailed even after the Japanese entered Indo- 
Ghina in September 1940 and as late as that neither the Burma, 
Government nor the G.O.G. Army in Burma was warned to make 
^y prep:^Uons_ to meet a full scale invasion. The lack of any 
Duective in the ^cumstances was bad enoughj the failure to supply 
any material help worse. This mortal sin of omission is to be 
remembered when the civil and military authorities in Burma are 
OTUcised for them more venial sins of commission. It is necessary to

upon the War Office the need for an adequate staff and services.

SURVEY OF BURMA CAMPAIGN 513 

There had been little or no co-ordination between the civil and 
military departments. No arrangements had been made for the 
militarisation of transport and other essential services. The provision 
of an overland link with India had not been contemplated as an 
immediate necessity. No plans had been made to make use of the 
local knowledge of Government servants and commercial employees. 
Litde encouragement had been given to plans for raising irregular 
fighting forces from the Karens, Chins and other highlanders. No 
attempt had been made to provide an adequate number of guides 
and interpreters for the troops. Such few maps as existed were 
obsolete and on the miserable scale of four miles to the inch. So when 
invasion came the effort to repel it was dependent upon improvisa- 
tion which often collapsed. The majority of the European, Indian 
and Burman civil officers stuck to their posts, but too many of their 
subordinates fled from the bombing of hostile aircraft, and this led 
to a breakdown of the police and of essential services. Fears for the 
safety of the women and children added to the instability, and if the 
administration lacked the moral courage to confront the problem of 
evacuation this was the result of the failure of His Majesty‚Äôs Govern- 
ment to face its responsibilities in the Ftir East. When evacuation on 
a grand scale began it was beyond the power of the civil authorities 
to control, and this mass evacuation was a continuous hindrance 
and menace to the troops. The military authorities, sensitive to 
the charge of defeatism, had no more moral courage than their civil 
colleagues. 

Work on the road to link Burma with the Assam road began in 
December 1941 by trying to improve tire tracks between Kalewa 
and Tamu with local Public Works Department resources. The 
original proposal to the Government of Burma was the construction 
of a road from Tamu to Sittaung and thence to die railway at 
Wuntho. This plan was given up in January 1942 in favour of the 
easier alignment to Kalewa and on to Ye-U. The work was not 
given priority until after the invasion had started by which time 
the efforts of the P.W.D. staff to collect tools, plant, material, labour 
and rations were seriously affected. Many of the. labourers joined in 
the flight of the refugees; cholera broke out; the work on the Indian 
side of the frontier did not progress as speedily as was hoped, which 
meant that the Indian help could not- be forthcoming. 

Yet in spite of all their difficulties the P.W.D. staff managed 
somehow to improve the rough jungle tracks sufficiently to allow the 
Imperial forces to make their way out and without that devoted 
work by the staff of the P.W.D. it is certain that the Imperial forces 

17 . 



514 EASTERN EPIC 

would never have reached India. If the construction of that road 
had been undertaken and completed it might have compensated for 
the disastrous effect of the fall of Rangoon upon the operations of 
the troops by providing a line of communication for reinforcements 
arid supplies. 

In view of the difficulties by which it was faced it is a matter of 
astonishment that military administration did not break down 
completely, and no praise of the achievement of the administrative 
staff could be exaggerated. To Lieut.-General Hutton‚Äôs attention 
to these difficulties both as G.O.C.-in-C. and afterwards as Chief of 
Staff to General Alexander the ability of the military administra- 
tion to stand the strain imposed upon it was largely due, to that and 
to Major-General Goddard‚Äôs fantastic energy and extreme skill. 

There were never enough administrative units for the force they 
had to maintain. Transport, supply, medical, ordnance and labour 
imits were all too few. There was no secure base after Rangoon had 
fallen, and as the fall of Rangoon had never been contemplated no 
base in Upper Buriria had been established before active operations 
began. The Army had too much motor transport at the expense of 
animal transport, and the lack of animal transport in such a coimtry 
by which the troops were tied to the roads was one of the main 
causes of the Japanese success. Let it be added, in case anybody 
should suppose that there was enough motor transport, that there 
was a serious shortage of it. Units often disembarked without their 
transport, which might be in another convoy, and as often they 
would have to be sent into battle as soon as they landed ‚ñ†with im- 
provised transport, which led to the loss of much equipment and 
kit, and by lowering fighting efficiency lowered morale at the same 
time. 

Under the direction of the United States authorities hundreds of 
motor vehicles destined to equip the Chinese imder Lease/Lend 
were destroyed at Rangoon, permission to remove them having been 
refused by the Chinese. On their own initiative the Gloucesters saved 
150 new vehicles from the burning parks and equipped themselves. 

Vehicles for supply services had been hired before hostilities 
began, and these naturally became unreliable. A certain number of 
vehicles was then bought or requisitioned from Lend /Lease material, 
but the loss of transport from bombing and road blocks was heavy 
and after the fall of Rangoon this could not be replaced. The 
Chinese Armies were practically -without transport of their own, and 
as we had undertaken to supply them with rations an almost un- 
endurable strain was placed upon our supply transport. The 



SURVEY OF BURMA CAMPAIGN 515 

thousands of tons of rice collected at Prome were almost all lost when 
the town was abandoned. Wc have heard about the superhuman 
efforts made by the administrative services to supply the troops 
during the last phase of the campaign. The surprise attack on 
Monywa cut off the stocks there, but enough remained in the 
Shwebo area to maintain the troops as far as Shwegyin, and after 
crossing the Ghindwin they were supplied from India by those roads 
made by such a desperate last effort. 

The supply of petrol, oil and lubricants was a continuous anxiety. 
After the fall of Rangoon the Army had to rely on the oilfields which 
were not on the railway. Then the oilfields went, and that set a term 
to its ability to stay in Burma, whatever the result of the fighting. 

The arsenal at Rangoon had never been suitable as a base, 
intended as it was to maintain in Burma a force of only two brigades, 
and until hostilities began the ordnance staff was not told to pro- 
vide for more than one additional division. Stores and equipment 
were quite inadequate for the forces that arrived. If the Chinese 
Government had not released a supply of automatic weapons and 
3-ton lorries the situation would have been even worse than it was. 
When the campaign opened the ordnance staff at Army Head- 
quarters consisted of an administrative officer and two officers on 
the engineering side. The arsenal itself was run entirely by civilian 
clerks and labourers, most of whom disappeared from Rangoon after 
the bombing on December 23rd 1941 and never came back. There 
were no facilities for handling large quantities of stores and, being 
situated close to the Mingaladon airfield, the area was under con- 
stant air attack. A great dump of ammunition was built up in a 
rubber estate near Milestone 18 on the Prome road, but when Ran- 
goon was abandoned most of this ammunition had to be destroyed 
for lack of transport. 

When Sir Reginald Dorman-Smith arrived to take up his post 
as Governor of Burma early in 1941 he asked His Majesty‚Äôs Govern- 
ment for the services of a transport expert; the request was refused 
because Burma‚Äôs priority for such luxuries was low. So work on 
the co-ordination of transport had to be undertaken by the Burma 
Government from its own larder. 

In December 1941 Army Headquarters appealed to India to form 
a Transportation Directorate for Burma and send such personnel as 
were available. Two officers from Iraq reached Rangoon in January 
1942 to find no previous planning; their own previous ignorance ‚ñ† 
of Burma did , not make their task an easy one. A Directorate 
of Transportation and Movements requires men trained in military . 



ji6 EASTERN EPIC 

iudes. Regular officers were not available, but substitutes were 
bund in officers taken from their civil occupations, and they did 
jood work. 

The Burma Railways and the Irrawaddy Flotilla Company had 
all they needed in the way of organisation and equipment except for 
the emergency of war, when civilian labour could not be trusted 
under the strain of air raids and the steady Japanese advance. In 
January 1942 Army Headquarters asked India for Railway, Docks 
and Inland Water Traitsport units to make up for the mass deser- 
tions. It will be remembered that India had already been called 
upon to help almost to the limit of her capacity with the transporta- 
tion problem in Iraq created by the effort to feed the cold esurient 
Russians with material of war. Nevertheless, India offered three of 
the very few units left to her; she sent Headquarters No. 2 Docks 
Operating Group, No. 213 Docks Operating Company and Head- 
quarters No. 3 Railway Construction and Maintenance Group. 
Besides these a number of I.W.T. crews, engine-drivers and firemen 
were flown into Burma later in the campaign. An attempt was made 
to raise units locally wth staffs from officers in Burma, and a com- 
pany was rmsed fi-om casual labour in Rangoon by H.Q,. No. 2 Docks 
Operating Group. When not employed on dock work this company 
received military training with 300 Italian rifles. 

The Director of Transportation noted: 

Even this modicum of military training, the possession of 
uniform and arms, and the cohesion afforded by working as a 
unit with their ovm officers amply demonstrated tire value of _a 
military organization in war. The Company worked through air 
raid alerts whilst their civilian comrades were under cover. 
Later on, during the last two weeks in Rangoon, only a small 
proportion of tlte Company absented themselves at a time when 
there was a wholesale desertion of civilian labour. 

Yet even this gallant attempt at last minute militarisation was 
opposed by the transport organisation involved, and it remained a 
solitary attempt. 

On February 24th the Chief Railway Commissioner was re- 
, ported to have declared in Rangoon that ‚Äòthe Railways are finished 
and not another train can be run.‚Äô This was too much, and the 
Governor- sanctioned the militarisation of the railway -south of

for there was at any rate the consolation of knowing that a war

many of the subordinate staff of the railway and river steamers and 
the abandonment of such a large quantity of stores in Rangoon, the 
Army was able to live and fight until the last moment. 

The difficulties of the transportation services were intensified 
by the interference of the Chinese whose threats to use violence 
caused further desertions, and there was always the enemy air force 
which was particularly severe on Mandalay. The railways did not

The rapidity of the Japanese advance, the lack of labour and tlie 
paucity of engineering units prevented demolitions from being 
carried out on any large scale, and in the long run it was certainly 
to our benefit that no policy of ‚Äòscorched earth‚Äô was feasible. The 
behaviour of the Japanese whose arrival had been almost unani- 
mously welcomed by the population was already turning the 
Burmese against them before the Imperial forces had left their 
country, and when the latter came back in 1945 they received more 
help from the Burmans than the Japanese had received from them 
on the way in. 

The Burma Posts and Telegraph Department was not militarised 
until well on in the campaign, but throughout members of it were 
conspicuous for their devotion to duty. The Army sorely needed that 
devotion, for its own signal services were very short of equipment. 
Indeed, one of the chief causes of the enemy‚Äôs successfully rapid 
advance Avas the difficulty of maintaining communication in the field, 
which has already been noted. The gallantry of runners and liaison 
officers could not compensate for the failure to provide the signals 
with stiitable equipment. 

The medical services were equally handicapped, and the shortage 
of medical officers led to much suffering for the sick and wounded. 
The Indian Hospital Corps did well; the Burma Hospital Corps was 
less satisfactory. Medical conscription was instituted, but the country 
had been shattered by bombing and confused by the mass flight of 
the refugees before it became effective. . , 

Shortage of transport was acute. Two motor ambulance sec-

cars all of which broke their half-shafts. Three ambulance trains

At this point a word must be said about the famous and well- 
beloved ‚ÄòWasbies.‚Äô The Women‚Äôs Auxiliary Service (Burma) was 
formed in January 1942 to work on cypher duties widr the Army in 
Burma. Of the 350 original members nearly 300 were evacuated

they moved north with the retreating army. They left Rangoon by 
train, the railway being heavily bombed, and resumed dieir work 
again with Army Headquarters at Maymo. From here in April they 
moved to Shwebo. When the train was pulling out of Mandalay on 
the first night a coupling broke as it was going up a gradient and 
half the train went backwards. The stranded Wasbies were rescued. 
When at last they reached Shwebo Mrs Taylor, the Commandant, 
found a very dirty empty house in which the 32 girls in her unit 
^mped. The cypher work was carried on the town being heavily 
ombed all the while. In their spare tunc the Wasbies worked at the 
hospi^ dressing wounds, helping in the operating dieatre and 
carrying out the dead. 

At last, with the vvorsening of the strategic posidon, the Wasbies 
were ordered to Myitkyina. The train travelled about eight miles 
every day. There were no signals, and it was a single track line. 



SURVEY OF BURMA CAMPAIGN 519 

Every carriage was chock-full; sleep was impossible in the sweltering 
filthy carriages; the only water was a small ration from the engine 
boiler for drinking; food was usually a can of beans shared among 
eight. The railway was lined on both sides by unhappy refugees 
hoping to get places on the northward bound train. Just behind the 
train in which the Wasbies were travelling was a heavily loaded 
ammunition train which would have been a rewarding target for a 
Japanese bomber. 

When it was beginning to look as if the Wasbies would never reach 
Myitkyina their train was met by a small diesel truck in which was 
a senior official of tlie Burma Railway who transferred the girls to it. 
and got tliem through to Myitkyina, whence they were flown out to 
Assam and finally reached Simla in May 1942. Here the W.A.S. (B) 
Organisation in its original form was disbanded, many of the Anglo- 
Indian and Anglo-Burmese girls in it volunteering for service with 
the W.A.C. (India) of which they formed the first platoon. 

Mrs Taylor set about tlie task of reforming the unit as a canteen 
service for the troops of the Burma Command. The new Wasbies 
opened their first canteen at Shillong in September 1942, and from 
that time onwards the Wasbies served the troops with domestic skill 
and most admirable devotion. There will be more to tell of the 
Wasbies when we reach the years ahead. Meanwhile, a salute to 
those gallant women. 

After dre fall of Rangoon die medical services were faced by the 
prospect of cholera, which had started in the camps of the refugees 
and threatened to spread to the troops. Energedc preventive 
measures kept the disease under control and a general epidemic was 
avoided, for which the medical services functioning under every 
disability deserve the highest praise. 

One result of the lack of transport and the speed of the Japanese 
advance was that the retreating Army was hampered by the wives 
and families of many of the clerks, servants and other employees. 
These women and children suffered heavy casualties when Shwebo 
was bombed. They were then sent to Monywa to be evacuated up 
the Chindwin, but by the time their train reached Aloti on the 
morning of April 30th movement up tlie Chindwin had ceased. 
Another Japanese air raid inflicted further casualties, and in the 
event they accompanied the Army by the Ye-U-Shwcgyin track to 
Kalewa and thence on through Tamu to Assam. 

This train of women and children did not add to the efficiency of 
the Army in Burma which had already been impaired by the lack 
of so much essential equipment. There were other factors which 



520 EASTERN EPIC 

affected morale and discipline. Some of the Indian battalions con- 
sisted almost entirely of young recruits not even half-trained, and 
too many of their British officers were inexperienced emergency 
soldiers with hardly any knowledge of the languages spoken by the 
men. The shortage of troops involved frequent changes in the 
composition of brigades which was destructive of esprit de corps, that 
priceless quality for which the English have borrowed a French 
name to avoid being suspected of undue emotion. This esprit de^ corps 
remained high throughout the campaign in the qStli Gurkha Brigade 
and the 7th Armoured Brigade, both of which formations were well- 
. trained, if not for jungle warfare. The 48th Brigade recovered from 
the Sittang disaster in a most remarkable fashion and under the 
inspiring leadership of Brigadier R. T. Cameron would illuminate the 
annals of military glory in the months to come as brightly as during 
the dark days of this retreat they had illuminated them at Kyaukse. 

If almost all that could be left undone to prepare for tlie remote 
possibility of a Japanese invasion of Burma was left undone by us, 
all that could be done to prepare for that invasion of Burma was 
done by the Japanese. It was a vital part of the vast Japanese 
offensive against Allied possessions in the Far East, and Britain may 
consider herself fortunate that during the days of benevolent 
American and malevolent Russian neutrality she had Germans to 
contend with, not Japanese. 

For every operation undertaken ‚Äî Pearl Harbour, Hong Kong, 
the Philippines, Malaya, the Dutch East Indies and Burma ‚Äî ^the 
Japanese High Command trained their men to the hour for that 
particular operation. They used China as a vast Salisbury Plain on 
which to exercise their troops and test their arms and equipment. 
Every kind of operation was rehearsed many times in advance until 
those chosen to take part in it were perfect. Meanwhile, the propa- 
ganda and espionage were constant and the right guns, the good 
maps, the suitable rubber boats, outboard motors and landing craft 
were got ready. A captured film of the Japanese advance through 
Malaya staggers the onlooker by its presentation of ruthless energy 
and efficiency in the repair of demolitions. 

The Japanese were hampered by no rules of warfare. They wore 
any kind of dress that suited the occasion; they massacred their 
prisoners if it was convenient; they lived on the country; they moved 
, by tracks believed to be impassable; they were able alike to raise a 
‚ñ† Burma Independent Army of several thousands and enjoy the whole : 
resources of Siam; they seemed for a long while invincible. . 

The Japanese troops used in Burma and Malaya were ^pert 



SURVEY OF BURMA CAMPAIGN 521 

jungle-fighters to -whom the jungle was an ally and in which they 
seemed terrifyingly mobile to troops completely without jungle- 
training. The shock troops were individually intelligent and individ- 
ually courageous; the snipers were one and all as selfless as a V.C. 
Yet the main body of these Japanese troops often fled from the British 
and the Indian bayonets and were unable to stand heavy shelling. 
The Japanese artillery lacked initiative; their mortars and infantry 
guns were full of it. 

The Japanese air force was not impressive, even after the successful 
attacks on Magwe and Akyab when it had the freedom of the Burma 
skies. Let it be added that, in spite of failing to do as much damage as 
it should have been able to do, it could not fail without opposition to 
be a powerfully unpleasant influence. And let it also be added that 
the speed with which it retaliated for the losses inflicted upon it at 
Mingaladon caught the Allied Air Force completely by surprise at 
Magwe. 

Even as early as this, and in the middle of a brilliantly successful 
campaign, there was evidence of inherent weaknesses in Japanese 
tactics which were one day to destroy them. They were accustomed 
to advance on a fixed objective without having made any provision 
to exploit success; they displayed little initiative in pursuit; most 
serious of all, they could not deviate from a fixed plan. 

The only instance of the exploitation of a success by a rapid 
pursiut was when thejapancse 56th Division drove through Karcnni 
and the Shan States after it had destroyed the Chinese 55th Division. 
On the other hand, it was not Japanese initiative but our own delays 
which allowed the enemy to cut off most of tlic 1 7 th Indian Division 
on the east bank of the Sittang River, and when this had been done 
he was quite unable to c.xploit his success. If he had known how to 
use his two divisions against the almost unarmed 17th Division 
which then had only tlic support of the 7 th Armoured Brigade he 
might have been the master of Burma by the middle of March. 
Again, by moving on Rangoon instead of concentrating upon cutting 
off tlie greater part of the Imperial forces the Japanese missed a 
great opportunity. So they ^d at Ycnangyaung, Monywa and 
Shwegyin. Indeed, the more one studies thb First Burma Campaign 
tile more clearly docs one perceive in it intimations of ultimate 
defeat for the triumphant invader. At the time the Japanese 
conquest of Burma, following as it did upon so many other Japanese 
conquests, seemed as incomptcJicnsibly easy as all the rest of them. 
\Vc cm see now that the resistance was tough enough to avert the 
major calamity of an invasion of India, 'fhe 8,000 men of the Indian 



522 EASTERN EPIC 

Army and the i,6oo men of the British Army did not give their lives 
or their liberty in vain. Those who reached India after that long and 
hazardous retreat of 850 miles by the shortest route from Mouhnein 
to Tamu had not endured and suffered through four blazing months, 
continually harassed by an unopposed air force, to no purpose. 

It has been a melancholy task to relate the story of Hong Kong, 
Borneo, Malaya and Burma, and the melancholy is not lightened by 
the knowledge that these bitter tragedies were caused by lack of 
trained troops, lack of proper material of war, lack of air-support, 
lack of medicsil supplies, lack indeed of everything that could have 
enabled those men, sacrificed to pusillanimous economy and besotted 
tmreadiness, to defend themselves against the superior forces of a 
highly trained, a well prepared and a dauntless enemy.

I T is now time to take up the tale of events in North Africa, but on 
our way west it will be convenient to pause in India for a brief 
glance at the war effort there during 1942. 

Ever since the beginning of the war India had been sending troops 
abroad before they could be fully or suitably trained for the tasks in 
front of them; it has already been made clear that this was due to the 
failure of His Majesty‚Äôs Government, even after Hitler‚Äôs attack on 
Poland, to appreciate the potentialities of India and its discourage- , 
ment of every Indian attempt to play more than a minute part in the 
conflict. It was no matter for astonishment that the sub-continent 
as a whole was inclined to take a detached view of the war. The 
Japanese successes came as a profound shock, for it was realised 
that neither the armed forces nor the nation was prepared to meet 
the invasion now threatened. By March 1942 when Rangoon fell, 
there was not a single fully trained or equipped division in India; the 
Air Force was practically non-existent; the Eastern Fleet had lost 
control of Indian waters. 

Nevertheless, when the Japanese naval raid on Ceylon had stiU 
further crippled that Eastern Fleet, when 100,000 tons of shipping 
had been sunk in the Bay of Bengal, when the undefended east coast 
was open to attack, and when the exhausted troops were staggering 
back to Assam, the Comraander-in-Chief, India, offered and sent 
aid to the hard pressed Middle East Command. Wavell had had 
bitter experience of being hard-pressed in both eastern theatres of 
war. The 7th Armoured Brigade and the 5th British Division, the 
former back from Burma, the latter recently arrived from England, 
were sent to Iraq in September 1942, and the two Australian 
brigades in Ceylon were relieved by Indian troops. 

On April gtli 1942 seventy-five Japanese aircraft raided Colombo, 
Some harbour workshops were destroyed, slight damage was done 
to railway workshops and negligible damage to the. Ratmalana 
aerodrome. H.M.S. . Tensdos and S.S. Hector were sunk; H.M.S. 
Lucia was hit. However, the enemy‚Äôs aircraft suffered heavily at the 



524 EASTERN EPIC 

hands of the defending Hurricanes. He lost 26, probably 31 of them, 
and 35 were damaged. Twelve Hurricanes and twelve other of our 
aircraft were lost. 

On the following day Vizagapatam and Coconada were raided. 
A Japanese naval force consisting of four heavy cruisers and one or t\vo 
aircraft carriers with a number of lighter units, attacked merchant 
shipping in the Bay of Bengal, sinking off the east coast 25 merchant 
vessels with a gross tonnage of 121,461 tons. Four-engined bombers 
probably based on the Nicobar Islands were responsible for some of 


these sinkings. 

On April 9th Trincomalee was raided by a large force of Japanese 
aircraft. Many direct hits were made on the dockyard and much 
heavy damage was done. H.M. Aircraft Carrier Hermes, the Austra- 
lian destroyer Vampire, and the corvette Hollyhock were sunk; this was 
the end of effective action by the Japanese in the Bay of Bengal. 

In March as already related small ships of the Indian Navy h^ 
helped to evacuate refugees from Burma, and early in April H.M.I.S. 
Indus was sunk in Akyab harbour. H.M.I.S. Sophie Marie, one of the 
requisitioned auxiliary ships, struck a mine during the evacuation ol 


the Andamans in March. 

Soon after the loss of Burma the Royal Indian Navy began to lay 
the foundation of its coastal forces. The first Captain, Coastm 
Forces, was appointed in May 1942; three months later H.M.I.S. 
Cheetah, the first Coastal Force Base, was commissioned at Trombay 


outside Bombay. The Royal Indian Navy was beginning to grow. 
During 1942 12 fleet minesweepers were commissioned, and there 
were other additions. Training establishments were developed. 
H.M.I.S. Machlimar, the new Anti-Submarine Training School, was 
commissioned at Andherei near Bombay before the end of the 
year and also H.M.I.S. Valsura, the Torpedo and Electrical School, 
was commissioned at Jamnagar, a finely appointed and up-to-date 
establishment. Progress was made during 1942 with other new naval 
establishments. 


On October i6th H.M.I.S. Larfy Craddock capsized and sank in the 
Hooghly during a violent cyclone accompanied by a tidal wave; but 
the year 1942 was memorable for a naval action which will bear 
comparison -with any fought by a small ship. H.M.I.S. Bengal,' &amp; 
minesweeper of the Bathurst class under 1,000 tons and, besides her 
close-mnge anti-aircraft weapons, 'armed with a single la-pounder 
gxm, was on her maiden voyage to India from the builder‚Äôs yard in 
Australia. She was commanded by Lieut. W. J. Wilson R.I.N.R. 
and she was escorting the Dutch tanker Ondina, a 6,ooo-ton vessel

armed with a single 4-inch gun. On November nth 1942 south of

cruisers of 10,000 and 6,863 tons respectively, of greatly superior

Indian Navy would in the fullness of time follow the path of glory 
trodden for so many years by the Indian Army. 

At the end of 1941 India was informed by the War Office that the 
latter was anxious to further Indian expansion in every way. , 


By this means only can requirements for India, Middle East 
(i.e. North Africa), Iraq, Persia, Malaya, etc. be met. 


This is presumably the date, more than two years after the out- 
break of war, when Whitehall woke up to the fact that the war could 
not be fought to a successful conclusion without the help of Indiaj 
Rip Van Winkle hardly slept more soundly. 

The most acute problem was the provision of additional man- 
power for the British personnel, the limitation of which was seriously 
holding up expansion. It was proposed to convert certain additional 
British formations in the Middle East to Indian and to hasten the 
Indianisation of various technical units in the same area in order 
to release the British personnel for India. The shortage of Bridsh 
personnel had involved a general lowering of efficiency because the 
trained Indian personnel to take its place did not yet exist. Expan- 
sion continued, but the calls on India‚Äôs inadequate sources of skilled 
men grew hoarier and progress was slower accordinglyj by the end 
of the year the want of skilled personnel was imperilling the whole 
future of expansion. 

The shortage of officers, acute in India, was equally acute in the 
British Army and India was called upon 'to meet requirements 
including a proportion for the Indian Army‚Äô from British other 
ranks in India. It was pointed out that ‚ÄòBritish units in India before 
the war or arriving early in the war either did not contain suitable 
material or had been extensively milked.‚Äô Troops still under training 
for the defence of India were rushed off to Malaya and Burma rrith

improvised; their tale srill not be told in this volume. After the

evacuation of Burma the ist Burma Division was re-formed as the

Towards the end of 1941 a new recruiting directorate was set up

between the Services and contributed to the solution of the problem

In May 1942 the situation was summed up by the General Staff, 
India, in these words: 

Before these events (Japan‚Äôs near approach to India) such direct 
threats had not been seriously contemplated as an immediate

Our elaborate and detailed programme for the raising of units:

port; equipment; and training were all principally arranged vyith 
a view to operations to the West of India. These have requimd 
rapid and extensive revision which has involved considerable

formations as we have available. 

The immediate result of the War wth Japan was the diversion 
of formations to the F ar East and the acceleration of their despatch. 
In addition, in response to urgent requests from Malaya, 
forcements equivalent to the infantry of a division were collected, 
chiefly by withdrawal from active units. All of these had not

The effect of this accelerated despatch of formations was to 
leave this country witli very few troops and those not fully trained 
. . . .to ^ve the forces sent overseas a minimum scale of weapons 
and vehicles it was necessary to postpone still further the issue of

The system of military command was now reorganised by the 
constitution of three armies to deal with the threats of invasion to 
North-West, North-East, and Southern India; at the same time 
Central Command was created to relieve x\rmy Commanders of

and Rodriguez. The last tlnree passed to East African Command in

The lesson thrust upon His Majesty‚Äôs Government by the deplor- 
able result in the Far East of failing to appreciate the vital impor- 
tance of air-power seemed to have been learnt in March 1942. 
Machinery was at last set in motion to make the Indian Air Force a 
self-contained service, manned and administered by Indians. 

On March ist India had no airfields completed to the new stand- 
ard of runways and accommodation; there were 16 airfields with 
one all-weather runway, most of them under r,200 yards, and there 
were 20 airfields with only fair-weather strips. Now a programme 
to construct 222 modern airfields was given top priority, and by the 
end of 1942 no less than 150 of those new airfields were usable. 
The men and the machines waited for so long began at last to 
arrive from Britain, but although recruiting in India was intensified 
the problem of finding enough men of the right type for technical 
jobs remained acute. 

In March the Indian Air Force had four squadrons and the Indian 
Air Force Volunteer Reserve had six coastal defence flights. It was 
decided to disband the latter and expand the Indian Air Force to 
10 squadrons to be operational by the end of 1943. The increase in 
airfields and squadrons demanded an extensive development of com- 
munications by water transport and land lines, the latter of which 
was undertaken by the Indian Posts and Telegraphs Department. 

The Observer Corps which had started in a very small way on 
the North-West Frontier was extended to reach as far as Eastern 
India. There was no warning system in India at the beginning of 
1942; by the end of the year radar equipment enabled the major 
ports of India and Ceylon to be covered. The training of technicians 
expanded to six times as many; the first batch of pilots for the future 
went to Canada under the Empire Air Training Scheme, and another 
batch of 34 officers and technicians went to England among whom 
were some young pilots that were absorbed- into Fighter Command 
of the R,A.F. During this year of 1942 the Indian Air Training 
Corps was launched, and there were 17 technical and non-technical 
schools located all over India. 

By the end of 1942 the India Service Command had developed 
from a few obsolete aircraft and converted airliners in March to 29 
fully operational squadrons with modern aircraft and 20 squadrons 
at various stages of training and equipment but not yet operational 
on modern types. There were also two transport squadrons and 
one -photo reconnaissance unit. In all there were 1,443 aircraft and 



528 EASTERN EPIC 

the combined strength of tlie air forces was 4,000 officers and STfiOO 
men. 

After the loss of Burma the almost negligible air power remaining 
in India was concentrated in Ceylon where it taught the Japanese 
that lesson. Air operations during the monsoon may have been on 
a small scale, but they were carried out with skill, courage arid 
determination and they were an earnest of what was to happen in 
the years to come. Calcutta and Chittagong were both defended 
resolutely and in consequence suffered little damage. Large quanti- 
ties of supplies were dropped in the Chin Hills and also for the Karen 
levies and that gallant litde isolated garrison at Fort Hertz. 

The Japanese air force which had remained inaedve during the 
monsoon did a certain amount of damage in the Dinjan area durmg 
the last quarter of the year when the AmericaiM had first taken' over 
and where the warning system was ineffective. Small night raids 
were made on Calcutta which did very slight material damage but 
caused an embarrassing exodus of labour. 

Mention has been made already of the splendid work of the 
American Volunteer Group against the Japanese. On March 12 th

at Delhi; on April and offensive operations against the Japanese m 
the India-Burma theatre started from bases in Bengal. 

When the Burma road was cut plans were made for an air-ferry 
service over the Himalayas, and the United States-Assam-Burma- 
, China Ferry Command was formed to carry munitions and other 
supplies into Burma and to evacuate the sick and woimded and

By the end of July 1942 base units of the United States Air 
Forces were in operation at Kunming in China, Dinjan and Chabua

In November the United States loth Air Force was divided into ‚ñ†
