We have run ahead too far. In the first half of 1942 India was 
practically defenceless. That weary army so much in need of rest 
and reorganisation after the ordeal of the Burma Retreat had to 
take its place in IV Indian Corps to defend the 500 miles of 
Assamese frontier. The only other troops available for tliis were 
the rst Indian Infantry Brigade which was astride the Palel-Tamu 
road, having been moved hastily from the North-West Frontier, and 
one battalion of the 49th Indian Brigade. The story of the Fighting 
Cocks of Savory‚Äôs 23rd Indian Division of which these units tvere the 
vanguard in this fierce country must wait for celebration in another 
volume. 

Besides these troops, the local tribes of that wild frontier ‚Äî ^Lushais, 
Chins, Nagas, Kachins, and the rest of them ‚Äî were organised into 
levies to undertake guerilla operations against the enemy‚Äôs lines of 
communications if he tried to pass through their country. When the 
Japanese advance was halted the activities of these levies assumed 
an aggressive character, and the contingent known as V Force did 
magnificent work. Patrols penetrated deep into enemy-held territory 
to obtain information and to harass the foe. These patrols could 
cover 30 miles a day with full packs; they were masters of the 
surprise; they were able to lead army patrols on their first sorties 
into enemy territory; they planned ambushes; they provided guides 
and interpreters. Commanded by British officers familiar with the 
country, many of them political officers, V Force rendered a service 
to the army of inestimable value, 

IV Indian Corps was responsible for the Assamese frontier; to 
XV Indian Corps composed of the incomplete t4th and 26th Indian 
Divisions and a small garrison at Calcutta was entrusted the defence 
of Bengal, with a further 500 miles of land frontiers and sea coast, 
against a sea-borne invasion or an advance by the Japanese up the 
Arakan coast. 

The Sunderbans Launch Flotilla was raised early in the year by 
requisitioning 50 launches with armament and crews. The duties of 
this flotilla was to patrol the waterways between the Hooghly and , 
the Meghna and resist an attempted enemy landing. To help the 
flotilla a Sunderbans observer system of four land posts and nine 
barges for floating posts was set up with carrier pigeon lofts at 
Khalna for use in tlie. Sunderbans. 

The 70th British Division, less a brigade in Ceylon, was at Ranchi 
to deal with any sea-borne expedition that landed on the 300 miles 
of . the Orissa coast. This division had been sent from the Middle 
East Command; it was the only reserve in Eastern India. In the 



530 EASTERN EPIC 

middle of 1942 the 2nd and 5th British Divisions arrived from the 
United Kingdom, the latter being sent to the Middle East later. 

The difficulty of defending North-East India with such a smal 
number of troops was rendered immensely more difficult by the 
‚Ä¢wretched communications between Assam and East Bengal and 0 
both with the rest of India. The mighty Brahmaputra River, with- 
out a single bridge, with a level rising and falling during the year as 
much as 25 feet and wth a comse capable of varying itself by several 
mdes, cut off Assam from the rest of India. East of the river there was 
a single-line metre-gauge railway with very small engines and rolhng 
stock and "without a modern control system. There were waggon 
ferries at two crossings -with an extremely limited capacity. There 
was no all-weather road from India to the west bank of the Brahma- 
putra. The only west-east road in Assam ran from the Gauhati ferry 
to the north-east which made it impossible to supplement the railway 
tvith road transport; Indeed, all vehicles had to be sent to Assam by 
rail. River transport did not help because the river system merdy 
led to the railway system on the east bank, which remained the 
limidng transportation factor. In any case most of the Brahmaputra 
steamers had been sent to serve the rivers in Iraq. 

Communications were almost as bad on the Bengal front. The 
delta of the Ganges was unbridged and the railway to Chittagong 
was a single line metre-gauge. The enemy‚Äôs command of the Bay ,01 
Bengal imposed a further strain on railway communications because 
petrol, oil and lubricants could only be sent to Eastern India over- 
land. A pipeline from Bombay to Allahabad was put in hand, but 
pipelines are not laid in a day. Nor must it be forgotten that the 
IvCddle East had made heavy demands on India. By June t 94 ^ 
590,000 tons of stores, 3,100 vehicles, including armoured fighting 
vehicles and guns, 174 railway engines and 5,600 units of rolling 
stock had been sent to Middle East, and it became urgent to alle- 
‚ñ†viate somehow the strain upon the railways. In the end the United 
States agreed to supply locomotives, but the wheels and axles had 
to be supplied from Britain. 

A great burden of work was laid upon the shoulders of the engineer 
services of India. Dimapur (kno\vn- as Manipur Road) when it 
ceased to be a wayside halt for the railway was converted into a rail- 
head able to handle at first 1,000 tons a day and presently 2,000 
tons; depot areas were rnadc to hold 30 days‚Äô reserves for a corps 
of three divisions and line-of-connnunication troops. A new rail- 
head and base was made at Ledo. Another river post was made at 
Donaigon, the railway being extended to connect %vith it. More 



SITUATION IN INDIA 


531 

crossings were made on the railway and the control system was 
reorganised. 

As if tlie transportation problem was not already dilHcuIt enough 
it was further complicated by an unusually heavy monsoon that 
year which caused heavy flooding and landslides on the road to 
Imphal and made the Brahmaputra more unmanageable than ever. 
The floods were followed by the worst malaria epidemic India had 
experienced for years. Finally from August onwards political unrest 
found a target for self-expression in the communications to 
North-East India. 

All these difflculties of transport affected the well-being of the' 
troops. Reduced rations during that summer increased suscepti- 
bility to malaria and other diseases. The interruptions to road 
traffic delayed the provision of medical accommodation and equip- 
ment and impeded the evacuation of the sick, of whom no less than 

15.000 were evacuated from the Burma Army before the full fiiry 
of the monsoon and another c20,ooo during the last three months of 
the year. 

Disturbances in India diverted the training and equipment of the 
Army to internal security, and stopped the flow of reinforcements to 
the troops on the North-East Frontier whose ranks were thinned by 
sickness. 

The flight of refugees from Burma meant that India was called 
upon to deal with 400,000 of these unhappy people, and the great 
majority of them being South Indians a serious additional strain was 
imposed on the Bengal Nagpur railway. The arrival of these refugees 
in India added to the panic; thousands more fled from Calcutta and 
other cities in Eastern India. 

A last-minute attempt to placate India‚Äôs demand for independence 
was made by Hb Majesty‚Äôs Government when Sir Stafford Gripps 
was sent to offer full Dominion status to ‚Äòa new Indian Union.‚Äô He 
arrived in Delhi on March 23rd; the Japanese occupied the Andaman 
Islands on the same day. After three weeks the negotiations broke 
down. 

Nevertheless, recruiting figures for the month of May, when about ‚ñ† 

70.000 volimteers came forward, touched a new high record. , 
Over half of those recruits came from classes which had hardly been 
represented in the standing Army of 1939, and the response from the 
Province of Madras was particularly noteworthy. No more will be 
said in tliesc pages about these difficult days; tliey would require 
a volume to themselves if every point of view were to be fairly 
presented.

Further argument in any case would have been a waste of time

The enemy‚Äôs plan of attack was revealed by the capture of docu-

The Afrika Korps and goth Light Division Battle Group were to 
concentrate north of Segnali on the evening of May 26th. On the

was to capture Bir Hacheim, while the Trieste Motorised Division

northwards and, after destroying our armoured forces, were to

were to seize Sidi Rezegh and El Duda. On a8th May, the, three 
armoured divisions were to attack our positions between Gazala 
and Alem Hamza from the east, wliile four Italian infantry 
divisions, stiffened by two regiments of the goth Light Division 
and one tank battalion of the 21st Panzer Division, ‚Ä¢vvcrc to attack 
the same positions from the west. 

Tobruk was to be captured during the two subsequent days. 

That plan of attack did not go quite according to plan, but 
neither did the counter-offensive.

I T was the 3rd Indian Motor Brigade which received the full

The 3rd Indian Motor Brigade consisted of the and Royal Lancers 
(Gardner‚Äôs Horse), the 1 1 th Prince Albert Victor‚Äôs Own Cavalry

work in Tobruk as already related. In August the brigade had been 
re-equipped at Mena and early in September 1941 had gone to 
north-east Syria where it helped the Free French to restore order in 
the Deir-cz-Zor. In February 1942 the brigade returned to Egypt 
where in due course it was joined by the 2nd Field Rcgt of Indian 
Artillery and spent three months of intensive training in the desert. 
It was now commanded by Brigadier A. A. E. Filose (Central India 
Horse). 

‚Äò On May 22nd the brigade came under the 7th Armoured Division 
now commanded by Major-General Messervy, and was ordered to 
hold Point 171 about four miles south-east of Bir Hacheim, where it 
would act as a pivot round which the British armour would operate 
to thwart any attempt by the enemy to outflank the Gazala line. 

On May 25th air reconnaissance reported much enemy transport ' 
moving toward the southern end of the British line. On the following

the tanks turned away north and north-west; a little later they

in the trenches of Festubert, One by one the anti-tank guns were

to safety. 

In the middle of the battle a few carriers of the i8th Cavalry 
arrived and under the command of Lieut. Gillingham charged in a

In the middle of the surging tanks stood Admiral Sir Walter Cowan 
who was still 5 naval liaison officer‚Äô with the i8th Cavalry. He and' 
Colonel Fowler were called on by two tanks to surrender. The 
Admiral refused, and fired the last cartridges left in his revolver at 
the tanks. Finally he and Fowler had to be seized bodily and dragged 
off the field. The Admiral was repatriated in 1943, having been too 
much of a strain on his Italian captors as a prisoner of 7a. He received 
a bar to his D.S.O. he had won on the Nile over 40 years before, and 
he was elected Honorary Colonel of the iSth, Cavalry.

It was now a matter of urgency to abandon the tacdcal position

which had been garrisoning Knightsbridge had been ordered to

That the ist South African Division was able to reach the frontier 
with scarcely a casualty was due to the self-sacrifice of the British 
and Indian troops in El Adem and the two neighbouring boxes. The 
withdrawal of the South Africans was also helped by the daring and 
skilful handling of. tire 50th' Division which moving in a series of 
wide zigzags across the enemy-infested desert reached the frontier 
practically intact except of course for the loss of the 150th Brigade.

and if he overcomes my forces and gets astride the eastern heights 
from Tobruk, I will be faced with a decision to allow Tobruk to be

probably could fight its way out, but it would undoubtedly lose 
a considerable amount of equipment and transport and arrive 
on the frontier in a disorganized condition. Having regard to 
resources of ammunition food and water now in Tobruk and in 
ships in Tobruk, I feel confident that it could hold out for two 
months on its own resources.

The men were fairly bursting with confidence. Things were a 
bit chaotic, but it was war and it was fun. They had knocked 
everything for a six that had come up against them and had 
received almost perfect battle inoculation. Their overwhelming 
sense of superiority did not leave them until the end. . . . 
Battalion Headquarters was in the front line, protected by runners, 
signallers and one sorry looking South African six-inch howitzer. 
The Subedar Major and Subedar Marasindu with the aid of the 
handbook hurriedly unpacked and assembled a recently arrived 
spigot mortar. The German tanks which approached us were just 
as afraid of tlie spigot bombs as we were of firing tliem. To fire a 
spigot mortar, one jams the canister onto an instrument which 
resembles a blunt marline spike. The bomb hits some unpredict- 
able distance away, precipitates itself along the ground like a 
prehistoric monster, belching fire as it goes, until it finishes its 
career in an ear-shattering explosion. At least, that is the way they 
brAaved for us. They scared off any tank that looked as though it 
svished to try conclusions -with us.

When on June 26th the Middle East Defence Committee te ^ 
graphed to the Defence Committee in London an appreciation o 
the situation created by the impending fall of Tobruk (it had in lac 
already fallen when the telegram tvas sent) and indicated the proba- 



THE ALAMEIN POSITION 571 

bility of having to fall back beyond the frontier to Mersa Matruh, 
the Deputy Prime Minister sent tlte following reply: 

June 22nd 1942. 

The War Cabinet . . . feel . . . that sufHcient emphasis has not 
been placed on the difficulties which confront the enemy in staging 
a successful attack on the frontier defences. If the fighting on the 
frontier is to be merely a rearguard action, we feel that the 
Matruh position may be quickly overrun, but if a resolute and 
determined defence is offered by the troops detailed for frontier 
defence, you may arrest Iris advance altogether or, at the worst, 
gain time to build up an armoured striking force to operate 
offensively from Matruh. 

To the Deputy Prime Minister the Middle East Defence Com- 
mittee, with the Prime Minister still in Washington, replied next 
day with an unwonted sharpness: 

We realise only too well the desirability of holding the enemy 
on the frontier position, and it will not be given up lighdy. 

It is necessary, however, to realise the true value of these defences" 
in present circumstances. They consist of two main defended 
areas designed to be held by infantry and artillery assisted by a 
mobile reserve of armoured troops of sufficient strength to deal 
with an attack by enemy tanks either round the southern flank or 
through the gap between the two main defended localities which 
are thirty miles apart. We have not now got the minimum armoured 
troops essential for this purpose. In their absence there is nothing 
to prevent the enemy isolating the troops in these defences and 
destroying them piecemeal. The result would be that there would 
be insufficient troops for the Matruh position, and these would 
consequently be speedily overrun. The Matruh position requires 
an armoured mobile reserve equally with the frontier position. . 

We need time to reorganize an armoured striking force and 
meanwhile to conserve our strength and ensure the, safety of 
Egypt. This time we can get only by increasing the distance the 
enemy has to cover before he comes to grips with our main forces. 

, The telegram went on to outline the proposed action to be taken 
and wound up with this trenchant paragraph: , . 

We suggest that you invite Major-General Galloway,^ General 
Staff, War Office, to explain to you the effect on strategy and 
tactics of the almost, complete lack in the Western Desert of 
, obstacles to mechanized movement, and the resulting freedom of 
action conferred on the side which has the superiority in armour, .

The Matruh position consisted of a fortified perimeter round the 
watering-place, the shimmering blue lagoons of which \were an 
attraction to Egyptian holiday makers in times of peace. There was 
a more recently constructed covering position west of the town, and 
the inevitable ‚Äòcowpat‚Äô about 20 miles to the south on the high 
ground at Sidi Hamza. A deep nunefield ran south in front of the 
covering position as far as Charing Cross where it turned east and 
two other minefields ran north from Sidi Hamza to the coast. The 
gap behveen these groups of minefields was six miles, the closure of 
which was entrusted to the 29th Indian Brigade. 

Auchinleck had never been much enamoured of the Matruh 
position and now with insufficient troops to watch the whole length 
of the minefields and an open southern flank he decided not to 
stand at Mersa Matruh, but to keep the Eighth Army mobile and 
stop the enemy‚Äôs advance in the area between Matruh, El Alamein 
and the prowdential Qattara Depression. Matruh itself was to be 
abandoned rather than allow any part of the Eighth Army to be shut 
up in it. X and XIII Corps were to remain mobile; XXX Corps was 
to occupy the Alamein position. ' . , ,

often seem like foregone conclusions when they succeed; but at this

And then Aucliinleck sent this telegram, evidently in answer to 
sometliing the Prime Minister had observed to him but not given in 
his Despatch: 

I believe that practically without exception the troops in the 
Eighth Army are as determined to beat the enemy as ever they 
were, which is saying much, and that their spirit is unimpaired. 
As to accepting decisions brought about by enemy action, we do 
all we can by improving our tactics and leadership to prevent their 
recurrence; but as you know we are trying to train an army and 
use it on the battlefield at the same time. We are catching up, but 
have not caught up yet. As to using all my manpower, I hope I am. 
doing this, but infantry cannot win battles in the desert so long as 
the enemy has superiority in armour, and nothing can be said or 
done to change tliisfact. Guns and armour andjust enough infantry 
to give them and their supply organization local protection are 
what is needed. Masses of infantry are no use without guns and 
armour. We cannot have too many guns or too many tanks, and 
the tanks must be American medium tanks wliich can stand up to 
German tanks and not Crusaders with only two-pounder guns in 
them, though Crusaders with six-pounder guns should be all 
right. 

I thank you personally most sincerely for all your help and sup- 
port during the past year and deeply regret the failures and set- 
backs of the past month for which I accept the fullest responsibility. 

And it was to show how profoundly he felt the responsibility that, 
rested upon him that Auchinleck believed it was his duty to assume 
command in the field at an hour when complete disaster was, too 
easily imaginable and the very Pyramids seemed to be wobbling. _

It was on June 27th that Denys Reid was ordered to take up a

On the afternoon of June a8th the code word Benghazi was given 
to headquarters of the 5th Indian Division in Mersa Matruh. This 
meant that the loth Indian Division was to attempt to emulate the 
feat of Briggs with the 7 th Indian Brigade five months earlier. The 
effort of Russell‚Äôs 5th Brigade to open a way out south had failed. 
The loth Division must somehow find a path eastward through four 
enemy divisions. At 9 p.m., the smoke of demolitions hanging thick 
over Mersa Matruh, the moon almost full shining over the desert, the 
midsummer nightmare of that desperate retreat began, westward 
bound at first where not a leaguer flare was visible and all was still. 
After a few miles the formations split up in groups and the vehicles 
turned east to spread out over a hundred miles of desert over which 
sprawled the enemy, himself near exhaustion. After a night and a day 
of hairbreadth adventures three-fifths of the loth Indian Division 
reached safety.

At 7.30 p.m. of June 28th the 3/2nd Punjab Regt from a position 
on the escarpment sighted a large number of armoured vehicles 
approaching. It was thought at first that they were our own trans- 
port, but a few minutes later the force was identified as hostile; 
it was in fact the 15th Panzer Division with 60 tanks. 

Sweeping on paist the Punjabis the German force divided. Some of 
it moved west along the escarpment; some moved east; some tanks 
deployed along the top of the escarpment; some tanks began to 
descend the pass. 

Soon shells were falling among the B Echelon trucks of the 29th 
Brigade; Reid sent them back along the railway 27 miles. Now 20 
panzers came down the escarpment line ahead to overrun brigade 
headquarters and the Mahratta company near Fuka railway 
station. 

Two guns of the 32nd Field Regt hidden behind a low ridge 
knocked out four tanks, but machine-gun fire silenced them, and 
Reserve force was rounded up. Denys Reid and two of his staff lay 
low, hoping to escape when it was fuU dark. Unfortunately a Ger- 
man patrol spotted them in the brigadier‚Äôs truck, and so Reid was 
taken prisoner. In November 1943 escaped, and was shortly 
^erwards given command of the loth Indian Division then fighting 
in Italy where we shall meet that tough soldier again. 

Elements of Gleecol and Scotcol managed to get back to El 
Alamein, but Fuka was the end of a great brigade and it was never 
re-fbrmed. When the column of Briggs‚Äô divisional headquarters 
approached Fuka the German guns were shelling the positions of the 
25th Brigade. The guns paid no attention to the colunon, which 
wheeled away and halted below the escarpment west of Fuka. At 
8 p.m. the brigade wireless stopped, and Major J. N. Chaudhuri,^ 
a staff officer, was sent to find out what had happened. He returned 
to inform cfivisional headquarters that the 29th Indian Brigade was 
no longer in existence. Being now alone, Briggs asked permission 
from RlII Corps to withdraw south and then eastwards. Gott was 
not at hand; his chief of staff refused to let Briggs move. 

Briggs waited till i a.m. without any news from XIII Corps. He 
thm decided tliat a divisional headquarters was unlikely to be able

to fight another day. Closing down communication with XIII 
t-orps, he chose hxs course and set out by the light of the low 
s^er moon. p,e col^ travelled south for. 30 imles and then

Between El Alamein on the coast and the dark cliffs of the Qattara 
Depression lie 30 nules of desert in the middle of which about 10 
miles from the sea and a few miles west of El Alamein a narrow 
tongue of land rises very gradually for about i2 miles almost due 
east to a peninsula of high groimd ending suddenly in a bluff which . 
is a feature of the landscape for many miles roimd. This bluff lay 
behind the El Alamein position and was about 55 miles from Alex- 
andria: it was known as the Ruweisat Ridge. El Alamein itself was 
hdd by the ist South African Division; the 2nd New Zealand 
Division was near the edge of the Depression. Between these two 
divisions was a gap of about 15 miles commanded on either side by 
the Ruweisat Ridge. If the enemy could sweep up to the crest of the 
Ruweisat Ridge that was the end of the Alamein position. 

, The tSth Brigade of the 8th Indian Division had been summoned

overlooking the narrow depression from which it starts. The i8th

Brigade. Artillery support was forwarded by the guns left to the

from Tobruk. For two days after its arrival in this arid inferno the 
infantry of the i8th Brigade dug, wired and mined 24 hours out of 
the 24 on dry rations and three-quarters of a gallon of water a day. 
The heat was savage and the ground was very stony. Compressors 
did not arrive in time to dig emplacements; most of the mines came 
too late to be laid. 

On June 30th the South Africans were attacked in the Alamein 
box, but the enemy was repulsed. Early on the morning of July ist 
the Guides Cavalry, now an armoured car regiment, which had been 
acting as a screen, reported that large forces of tanks and lorried 
infantry were approaching the Deir el Shein. The i8th Brigade 
took up battle positions on a semicircle of about 6,000 yards, the 
4th Sikh Regt on the west and south, the 2 /5th Essex Regt on the 
west and north, the 2/3rd Gurkha Rifles covering the rear. 

Soon after 9 a.m. the enemy began to range on the Deir el Shein 
from the south-west, and presently a captured British officer was sent 
with a demand for surrender. This was refused. An hour later the 2 /5th 
Essex Regt was heavily shelled, and half an hour later 15 tanks with 
sappers started to open a gap in the all too meagre minefield between 
the 2/5th Essex Regt and the a/grd Gurkha Rifles, and then to help 
the enemy and handicap our men a dense dust storm annihilated 
visibility. Under cover of this storm the enemy penetrated the mine- 
field during the afternoon, allowing the panzers to surge through and 
overwhelm the Essex position. Then they turned on the 4th Sikh 
Regt; a pair of the tanks were knocked out by the 2-pounders but the . 
arms available could not halt such strength. Four of our 25-pounders 
were still in action when the panzers overran the guns. Many of the 
gunners were able to escape because the German tank crews found 
some beer in the mess tent and stopped to drink it. Many of the Sikhs 
also got away but seven officers and 500 men were captured. When 
darkness came the panzers and lorried infantry attacked the 2/3rd 
Gurkha Rifles which was severely pressed until by good fortune a 
heavy air bombardment close by gave the rest of the battalion a 
chance to get out, and make its way across the valley to the South 
African lines. Six officers and 255 riflemen were missing!. . 

The 1 8th Indian Brigade was never re-formed, but during its 
brief life the resistance it made at, Deir el Shein may have saved the

When what was left of the loth Indian Division reached Alamein 
most of the formations with the divisional and brigade headquarters 
had to be sent right through to the Delta to reorganise and refit as 
speedily as possible. At the same time, it was vital to form a battle

those precious hours gained by the i8th Brigade Robcol was able to 
become a cohesive formation, throw out lines of communication, and 
establish a good position on the ridge with well-sited guns. At i o a.m. 
the enemy started his attempt to seize the Ruweisat Ridge. For six 
hours the panzers tried to mount the high ground only to be driven 
back every time by the 25-pdunders. 

By nightfall seven guns had been silenced, and ammunition was 
almost exhausted, but it was the panzers which broke off the action 
to retire westward. This had not happened since the fall of Tobruk. 
The Essex company in its covering positions had never flinched under 
continuous bombardment all through that day. 

Early on July 3rd Robcol was reinforced by Colonel Noble 'with 
another company of the Essex and the battalion‚Äôs carrier platoon. 
Guns of the Royal Horse Artillery joined Robcol that afternoon. 
Robcol was now being reinforced all the while and presently became 
‚Ä¢ Walgroup. The Ruweisat Ridge was held.

a bold decision with the forces and airnour at his disposal. XIII 
Corps was ordered to siving north and attack the enemy on his 
flank and rear. XXX Corps in the north was to'hold its ground and 
prevent any easterly penetration.

Failures and casualties, minor successes and minor casualties, 
confusion and frustration were the order of one day after another. 
At times the commanders were gripped with the sense of helpless-

general feeling one of alternating depression, elation, cynicism, 
hope, anger, and pride. 


The background at what is called a high level emerges from three 
telegrams. 

On July 8th the Middle East Defence Committee sent a long 
appreciation of the situation to London in which they pointed out 
that almost the whole of M.E.F. land and air forces were concentrated 
in the west, that the German offensive in Russia if it proceeded ^ 
successfully as it had begun might mean a threat to Northern Persia 
by October 15 th or if the enemy changed his plans and came through 
Anatolia a threat to Syria and Iraq by September loth. To meet 
these threats there were in Persia, Iraq and Syria portions of two 
infantry divisions, some partially equipped Allied condngentsj 
and no. air forces of any consequence. In present circumstances 
unless we were prepared to accept the loss of the Delta it would be 
unpractical to transfer land and air forces to the Northern Front. 


In our view the issues before us are extremely grave. If the 
cainpaign in Russia goes badly for the Russians and you .find it 
impossible to send us necessary reinforcements in time, we shall be 
faced with a situation in which it will be necessary to decide: ‚Äî ‚ñ† 

-‚Ä¢ (a) Whether our forces and as much of our base installations 

. M po^ible should be deliberately transferred from Egypt to the 
rsorthern Front to secure the Persian oilfields with the conse- 
quenual loss of Egypt, or 

(b) Whether we should continue our present policy and risk 
the loss of the Persian oilfields. ^ . 

'We have not got the forces to do botli, and if we try to do both 
.we may fail to achieve either. We request your guidance and 

. instructions on this issue.

‚Äò Farther south and west General Quinan had chosen a final line of

There were hardly any localities in Northern Persia where the 
enemy could construct airfields quickly, but there was an awkwardly 
level area in the valley between Ardebil and Tabriz and another 
round Denkoran on the Caspian coast. Moreover, south of this the 
country about Kazvin, Tehran and Hamadan was dangerously 
accommodating for airfields. This country would have to be held at all 
costs to allow the R.A.F. to provide fighter cover for the troops in 
action in the north and bombers to attack the enemy‚Äôs communica- 
tions. If the airfields were lost the enemy would enjoy what might 
well prove a fatal advantage. 

In these circumstances the only feasible plan was to hold a 
defensive line north and east across the enemy‚Äôs lines of approach 


and maintain a mobile force on the Araxes.

T . _ ^ most unpleasant time. It has been well described by

¬£^cept in a few sandy hollows, there was no cover. A slit trench 
coma only be cut with an air drill out of solid stone, or blasted 


the p explosives. A shallow saucer-shaped sangar preserved 


‚Ä¢ appearance rather tlran the reality of protection. The sun beat 
upon the solid rock and the glare struck the eyes like a knife. 

very passing vehicle ploughed dust into the air, to choke moutli 
and nostrils and to reveal movement to the enemy. Water and 
uel were precious and were issued sparingly. Labour, on the other 
and, was unsparingj always there were loads to carry, mines to 
ay, Wires to string. At the rocky tip of the ridge, where stony 
pimples gave the enemy spy-ground, there was always bickering, 
always shellfire or panzers threatening, always Stukas swimming 
the west, with the rhythmic pumping of the Bofors as prelude 
th monstrous blast and leaping cloud as they struck. Yet 
these dangers and discomforts were Jess than the horror of the 
clotted masses of flies which maintained their filthy siege as long 
^ warmth was in the air. This living carrion pestered men to the 
hnuts of their endurance.

the armour went through, the golden sun of the morning behind it. 
The Second Battle of Alamein was won. 

The Red Eagles began to flap their wings to take off in pursmh 
and one flying column with a rifle company, the carrier and anti-tank 
guns of die I /and Gurklia Rifles with a company of the Rajputana 
Rifles Machine-Gun Battalion and detachments of gunners and 
sappers rounded up over a,ooo of die Brescia Divbion in a day. That 
was on November 5th. The next day rain fell very heavily and the 
armoured divisions leading the pursuit were held up just east of 
Mersa Matruh by die condition of die ground. 

Undue caution has been attributed to Montgomery‚Äôs pursuit, but 
this unfortunate downpour was probably responsible for the failure 
to cut off Rommel‚Äôs retreat. The depressing part of that pursuit for 
the 4th Indian Division was that on November 7th it was withdrawn 
from offensive operations and given the job of turning in salvage 
from the batticfield. The quota laid down was 250 tons daily; the 
division, hoping to be the sooner in action again, salvaged 1,500 tons 
every day. There was a lack of imagination in giving this task to the 
infantry of Sidi Barrani; it strengthened a suspicion that General 
Montgomery had a prejudice against the Indian Army. 

Early in December the i6ist Indian Brigade left the division ui 
order to join its otvn 5th Indian Division in Baghdad, after a spell of 
garrison duty in Egypt- 

On December 10^ the 4th Indian Division moved to the Tobruk 
area with divisional headquarters at El Adem. Here Brigadier 
. Russell gave up the command of the 5th Brigade he had led so 
wisely and so well to take over the command of the 8th Indian 
Division. He was succeeded by Brigadier Bateman- who had been

Everyone in this Division is feeling most apprehensive as to its 
future. We know that this theatre of war‚Äî the Mediterranean‚Äî is 
becoming a theatre of United Kingdom and American armies. 
VVe feel that there is a good chance that wc may thus be relegated 
i?. peaceful theatre of war. We feel most strongly that tliis 
Di^ion docs not deserve such a fate. 

standard of training and its fighting spirit are probably 
‚Ä¢ugher to-day than they have ever been. I do not think anyone 
Would deny that it is the most experienced Division in the Empire, 
having been the only formation that has fought at Sidi Barrani, 
has fought all through the desert and mountain campaign of 
Eritrea, in the Syrian campaign, in tlic summer attacks last year 
Western Desert, throughout the Tobruk operations a year ago 
to Agcdabia and through the ivithdrawal from there, as well as 
laving had considerable elements fighting successfully in die 
'jazala-Alamein operations, and now having been engaged m this 
recent battle. 

‚Ä¢ further it looks as though mountain fighung ^y yet dei,xJop. 
t dunk we have more experience than most in this sort of wanarc. 
Cur men, British and Indian, arc tough. The Indians come troni 
the high Himalayas and the Punjab and arc used to extremts ol 
cold. Ihc Division is a very seasoned one. Among its Indian 
troops it has more than 1.100 who have been on active 
TOnunuously for two years and over. Almut 75 per ceiiU oi.iu its 
rndian troops Imve been on continuous active service for over a

6o4 eastern epic 

Its British troops have if anything a higher proportion of men 
who have seen similar periods of continuous active service. 

Lastly, perhaps 1 am allowed to say that Fourth Division has 
represented India in active operations in the Middle East for two 
and a half years, not without success. Should it not continue so to 
represent her in the Middle East. 

I do hope that these considerations will favourably influence 
anyone who might consider sending Fourth Division to some 
peaceful area. Can we be assured that this will not happen? I 
should find it hard to explain to my officers and men that they are 
no longer needed, after all they have achieved and in view of the 
high spirit and expectations with which they entered these present 
operations. 

General Horrocks^ forwarded this letter to General Montgomery 
with this comment: 


Although this Division has only, been under my command for a 
short time I have had the opportunity of going round a good 
many units. I concur with the remarks in the attached letter. 
There is no doubt that this is an experienced Division, more 
^perienced probably than any other Division in the Middle 
East. It is imbued with a fine fighting spirit and in my opinion it 
would be^ a tragedy if this fine Division was not given a further 
^portunity of representing India alongside United Kingdom and 
Dominion forces. 


^ Neither the letter nor the comment apparendy made the slightest 
impression on General Montgomery.
